chunks.original_text: 诚为学死者之真归，草经之要览也。 今之学者多取傍门，非类而证之。 或以天庭、至宝、玉壶、圭丹、混元胎之类，妄乱穿凿，终莫际其探根固蒂之要。 又有叶文叔者，以太极大衍之数释而辨之，复撰为图，附於卷末，谓之《悟真篇外传》，此乃帘瞻幕影，定马为乾，非惟素乱真经，＇致使学者为之惑误。 仙翁有言曰：靡肯自思己错，却将错路教人。 误他永世在迷津，似惫欺心安忍。 其文叔之谓乎。 殊不知金丹一粒，即太极之一气。 圣人假借二八之物，擒此一气，於一时中，变成一粒。 殊不出一时辰中，饵之立超圣地。 故仙翁曰：一时辰内管丹成。 又曰：一粒灵丹吞入腹，方知我命不由天。 岂虚语哉。 文叔不达斯理，反以一时为非止一时。 若以非止用一时而言之，是非三年必九载矣，岂为至简至易，而仙访何故有都来片饷工夫永，保无穷逸乐之语耶。 又以一粒为一日，以为有一日之丹，妄引真一子日食一粒之语为证，尤不晓真一子之意也。 若以日食一粒，与一日有一日之丹而推之，三年九载必三千有余粒矣，岂仙爷独以一粒之语而诳人乎。 举此两 瑞，足知文叔不得金丹之术明矣。 是以妄乱笺注，讹谬非一。 抑不知太极大衍之数，其实运火之托象，似是而非也。 若以托象求金丹之至道，是描龙致雨、画饼充饥，不亦难乎。 余固不才，幸踵仙翁之颜铸既承，真荫寅夕不忘，安忍缄默坐视红紫乱朱，而不能广仙翁之意辞，而辟之以级将来，而松未悟者耶。 是以不惧天谴，直泄天机，课解真文，谨依仙翁之秘旨，曰：夫炼金丹大药，先明天地未判之前混沌无名之始气，立为丹基。 次辨真阴、真阳，同类无情之物，各重八两，立为炉鼎。 假此炉鼎之真气，施设法象，运动周星，诱此先天之始气。 不越半个时辰，结成一粒，附在鼎中，大如黍米，此名金丹也。 取此金丹一粒，吞归五内，擒伏一身之精气，犹猫捕鼠，如鹧钢乌，不能飞走矣。 然后运以阴阳之真气，谓之阴符、阳火，养育精气，化成金液之质。 忽尾闻有物，直冲夹脊双关，历历有声，逆上泥丸，触上颚，颗颗降入口中，状如雀卵，馨香甘味美，此名金液还丹也。 徐徐咽下丹田，结成圣胎，十月胎圆火足，即脱胎沐浴，化为纯阳之躯，而无饥渴寒暑之患，刀兵虎兕之不能伤，而为陆地神仙。 方始投於静僻之地，兀兀面壁九年，以空其心，谓之抱一。 九年行满，形神自然俱妙，性命双圆，与道合真，变化不测矣，此名九转金液大还丹也。 丹虽分三，道实一揆。 必自小而中，自中而大，此修丹入道之次序也。 余故分为三卷，上卷以炼金丹，为强兵战胜之卫。 中卷以运火金液丹，为富国安民之法。 下卷以九转大还丹，为神仙抱一之道。 谓之三乘大法，以应《阴符经》之正义，此乃无上无极上品天仙之甲科，至真之妙道也。 五师宗祖口口相传，惟此一法耳。 其要至简至易，不逾片言。 圣人恐泄夭机，故以乾坤、炉鼎、龙虎、铅汞之类，以至不可胜举之异名，无过比喻金丹法象而已。 余今钻集异各，一一指其至当，罔敢遗漏纤微。 又恐学者未明作用之妙，是以观缕再三，复撰《悟真直指详说》《三乘秘要论》《三乘秘要诗》附於卷末，罄竭精微，可谓大泄天地之真机，全露仙舫之秘旨矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Indeed, this is the true refuge for earnest seekers and the essential compendium of the foundational scriptures. Yet many of today’s scholars pursue heterodox paths, seeking verification through incongruous methods. Some recklessly conflate terms like "Celestial Court," "Supreme Treasure," "Jade Flask," "Jade Cinnabar," and "Primordial Embryo," distorting their meanings through forced interpretations—never grasping the core of rooting deeply and securing the foundation.

Then there is Ye Wenshu, who attempted to explicate and distinguish the numbers of the Great Ultimate and the Great Expansion, even crafting diagrams to append at the scroll’s end, titling it *The Outer Transmission of the Wuzhen Pian*. This is like mistaking the shadow of a curtain for the sun, or misidentifying a horse as *qian*—not only does it disorder the true scripture, but it leads earnest seekers into confusion and error. The immortal sage once said:

*"None will reflect upon their own mistakes,
Yet they teach others the wrong path.
Misleading them for lifetimes in delusion—
How can such deceit be borne?"*

Does this not describe Wenshu? He failed to understand that a single grain of golden elixir is none other than the primordial *qi* of the Great Ultimate. The sages borrowed the substances of the two eights to capture this *qi*, transmuting it into a single grain within a single moment. It does not exceed half a *chen*; ingested, it instantly elevates one to the realm of sages. Thus the immortal sage declared:

*"Within a single *chen*, the elixir is complete."*
And again:
*"Swallow a grain of numinous elixir,
And you will know your fate is not ruled by heaven."*

How could these be empty words? Wenshu, not comprehending this principle, insisted that "a single moment" did not mean *only* a single moment. If one argues that it does not require merely a single moment, then it must take three years or even nine—how could this align with the Way’s utmost simplicity and ease? Why would the immortal sage speak of "a mere moment’s effort yielding eternal bliss"? Further, he misconstrued "a single grain" as "a single day," positing the existence of a "daily elixir," and falsely cited Master Zhenyi’s words, "consume one grain per day," as evidence—yet he utterly misunderstood Zhenyi’s intent. If one were to follow this logic—consuming one grain per day, with each day yielding a new elixir—then over three or nine years, one would accumulate over three thousand grains. How could the immortal sage have deceived others by speaking of just *one* grain? These two examples alone suffice to show that Wenshu never grasped the art of the golden elixir. Thus his annotations are riddled with errors, and his misinterpretations are manifold.

What he failed to realize is that the numbers of the Great Ultimate and the Great Expansion are merely symbolic representations of the firing process—superficially plausible, yet fundamentally flawed. To seek the supreme Dao of the golden elixir through such symbols is like trying to summon rain by painting a dragon or sate hunger by drawing a cake—how could it not be difficult?

Though I am unworthy, I have followed in the footsteps of the immortal sage, inheriting his true transmission and never forgetting his profound teachings, even for a moment. How could I remain silent, watching the crimson and purple obscure the vermilion, without broadening the sage’s intent to dispel confusion for future seekers? Thus, undeterred by the fear of celestial retribution, I dare to reveal the celestial mechanism, elucidating the true text in accordance with the immortal’s secret instructions:

To refine the great medicine of the golden elixir, first clarify the primordial *qi* of the undifferentiated chaos before heaven and earth separated—this is established as the foundation of the elixir. Next, distinguish true yin and true yang, the emotionless substances of the same kind, each weighing eight ounces—these form the crucible and furnace. Using the true *qi* of this crucible and furnace, employ symbolic methods to circulate it through the celestial cycles, enticing the primordial *qi* of the beginning. In no more than half a *chen*, it coalesces into a single grain, adhering to the furnace, as large as a millet seed—this is the golden elixir.

Take this single grain of golden elixir and swallow it into the five viscera, where it seizes and subdues the essence and *qi* of the entire body, like a cat capturing a mouse or a sparrowhawk seizing a crow—rendering them unable to flee. Then, employing the true *qi* of yin and yang, known as yin talismans and yang fire, nurture the essence and *qi*, transmuting them into the substance of golden liquid. Suddenly, at the base of the spine, a presence is felt, surging upward through the double passes of the spine with a distinct sound, reversing its course to the muddy pellet, striking the upper palate. Droplet by droplet, it descends into the mouth, resembling sparrow eggs, fragrant and sweet—this is the golden liquid returning elixir.

Slowly swallow it into the cinnabar field, where it coalesces into the sacred embryo. After ten months, the embryo matures and the fire is complete; then, through the process of shedding the embryo and bathing, it transforms into a body of pure yang, free from hunger, thirst, cold, or heat, impervious to blades, tigers, or rhinoceroses—becoming an earthbound immortal. Only then does one retreat to a secluded place, sitting in stillness for nine years, emptying the heart—this is called "embracing the One." After nine years of practice, form and spirit naturally attain perfection, nature and life unite, merging with the Dao in truth, becoming unfathomably transformative—this is the nine-times-cycled great returning elixir of golden liquid.

Though the elixir is divided into three stages, the Dao remains one in principle. One must progress from the lesser to the middle, and from the middle to the greater—this is the sequential path of elixir refinement and Dao attainment. Thus, I have divided this work into three scrolls:

The **upper scroll** refines the golden elixir, serving as the defense of a mighty army and the strategy for victory in battle.
The **middle scroll** circulates the fire of the golden liquid elixir, serving as the method for enriching the nation and pacifying the people.
The **lower scroll** details the nine-cycled great returning elixir, serving as the Dao of the immortal’s embrace of the One.

Together, these constitute the three vehicles of the great method, aligning with the true meaning of the *Yinfu Jing*. This is the supreme, boundless, highest-grade celestial immortal’s first-rank, most authentic and wondrous Dao. The five ancestral masters transmitted this method orally, and it is the *only* true teaching.

Its essence is utterly simple and effortless, conveyed in but a few words. The sages, fearing the revelation of celestial secrets, employed terms like *qian* and *kun*, crucible and furnace, dragon and tiger, lead and mercury—along with countless other metaphors—to do nothing more than illustrate the symbolic methods of the golden elixir. Now, I have gathered and examined these diverse terms, pointing out their precise correspondences without daring to omit even the most minute detail.

Yet, fearing that seekers might not grasp the subtleties of their application, I have repeatedly observed and refined my explanations, composing *The Direct Pointers to the Wuzhen Pian*, *The Secret Essentials of the Three Vehicles*, and *The Secret Essentials of the Three Vehicles in Verse*, appending them to the scroll’s end. In these works, I have exhausted the profound and subtle, fully revealing the celestial mechanism and laying bare the immortal’s secret instructions.

chunks.original_text: 愿贻同志，俾易研精灼然直际，悟真之真永为正眼法印，而不惑於邪宗曲派之说也。 时皇宋乾道癸巳中秋，象川无名子翕葆光谨序。 空玄子曰：无令子分为上中下三卷，谓之三乘大法，以应《阴符经》之正义。 盖本乎金华真人解《阴符经》旨。 金华解曰：强兵战胜之衍者，是金液炼形之衍也。 乃积阳魂而消阴魄，以阳兵战阴贼也。 以五行相克、八卦相荡，归根复命，赫然成丹。 还丹百数，俱要在神水华池。 故人生於天地之问，不知天地之理，被阴邪所盗，光景易迁，精神耗散，所以衰谢。 圣人乃设其法象，诱真阳之气，结成神丹。 延驻其形神合其道，如国被寇侵扰，须以强兵制御。 惜其珍宝资其国用，复令丰盈之后，乃行神仙抱一之道。 赞曰：华池神水，玉汞金铅。 乾坤资用，日月烹煎。 屯蒙发火，进退精研。 抽添沐浴，九转一年。 坎离贯首，功行三·十。 持之勿怠，化形而仙。 富国安民之法者，是炼气之法也。 《老子内经》日．．一身之设，一国之象也。 圣人以身为国，以心为君，以精气为民。 民安国泰，民散国虚。 人若惜精爱气，所以长生也。 以国君之爱民，如赤子常设法以养之，令民安国丰，谓之富国安民之法也。 人之形益禀父母精血，是元气所化也。 中黄真人日：骨肉以精血为根，灵识以元气为本。 神之与气，性命之本也。 神为气子，气为神母，谓之形中子母也。 常令子母不相离，气乃湛然住於丹台之内，自然成变化也。 赞日：天门常开，地户须闭。 永存绵绵，勿令暂废。 吸至于根，呼彻于蒂。 子谓之神，母谓之气。 如鸡袍．卯，似鱼在水。 结就圣胎，自然蝉蜕。 神仙抱一之道，皆是炼神之道也，本无自然之道。 遇道之人，常能一抱一守中，乃得神气不散，逍遥自在，为真人矣。 赞日：道为性本，性是心源。 心性同体，应化无边。 百姓日用，亦日自然。 若能了悟，亡心象忘言。 虚心实腹，抱一而还。 功成九转，乃得成仙。 又日：行炼神之道，当为神仙。 为形沉而神超，乃得逍遥。 行炼气之法，当为胎仙，为炼形之人，神气交感，氤氲相符，结胎育婴，如蝉蜕也。 行炼形之衍，乃返老为少，留形住世之卫也。 谨备迷其文，以见无名子祖迷分为三卷之本旨。 别本无名子字渊明。 悟真篇序 嗟夫，人身难得，光阴易迁。 罔测短修，安逃业报。 不自及早省悟，惟只甘分待终。 若临期一念有差，立堕三涂恶趣。 则动经尘劫，无有出期。 当此之时，虽悔何及。 故老释以性命学，开方便门，教人修种，以逃生死。 释氏以空寂为宗，若顿悟圆通，则直超彼岸。 如有习漏未尽，则尚徇於有生。 老氏以炼养为真，若得其枢要，则立跻圣位。 如其未明本性，则犹唠於幻形。 其次《周易》有穷理尽性至命之辞，《鲁语》有毋意必固我之说，此又仲尼极臻乎性命之奥也。 然其言之常略而不至於详者何也？ 盖欲序正人伦、施仁义礼乐有为之教，故於无为之道，未尝显言。 但以命术寓诸《易》象，以性法混诸微言故耳。 至於《庄子》推穷物累逍遥之性，《孟子》善养浩然之气，皆切几之矣。 迨夫！ 汉魏伯阳引《易》道阴阳交娠之体，作《参同契》以明大丹之作用唐忠国师於语录首叔老庄言，以显至道之本末。
chunks.translated_text:
May this be bequeathed to fellow aspirants, that they may readily delve into its essence, attaining luminous and direct insight—so that the true reality of *Wuzhen* may forever serve as the orthodox Dharma-seal, unconfused by the doctrines of heterodox schools and crooked sects.

Written in the mid-autumn of the *gui-si* year of the Qiandao reign of the Great Song, by Xiangchuan’s Wumingzi, Xi Baoguang, with reverence.

Kongxuanzi says: Wumingzi divided this work into three scrolls—upper, middle, and lower—entitled *The Three Vehicles of the Great Dao*, aligning with the true meaning of the *Yinfu Jing*.

This is based on the *Yinfu Jing* commentary by Master Jinhua. Jinhua’s exegesis states: “The strategy of strengthening the army to achieve victory” is none other than the process of refining the golden elixir to transmute the form. It is the accumulation of yang *hun* to dissolve yin *po*, deploying yang soldiers to battle yin bandits. Through the mutual conquest of the Five Phases and the mutual agitation of the Eight Trigrams, one returns to the root and restores life, whereupon the elixir blazes forth. Every cycle of the returned elixir depends upon the divine water of the Flowery Pond. Thus, born between heaven and earth, humans remain ignorant of heaven and earth’s principles, allowing yin and evil to plunder them. Their radiance and vitality swiftly pass, their spirit and essence dissipate, and so they decline and wither. The sages therefore devised symbolic methods to lure the true yang qi, congealing it into the divine elixir. This extends and preserves the form, uniting spirit with the Dao—like a nation beset by marauding bandits, which must deploy a strong army to subdue them. Only after securing its treasures and restoring the nation’s prosperity does one practice the immortal’s Way of embracing the One.

In praise:
The Flowery Pond’s divine water,
Jade mercury and golden lead.
Heaven and earth supply the resources,
Sun and moon the firing and refining.
*Zhun* and *Meng* ignite the fire,
Advancing and retreating with precision.
Drawing and adding, bathing,
Nine revolutions in a single year.
Kan and Li penetrate the head,
Thirty years of meritorious practice.
Hold fast without slackening,
Transmute the form and ascend as an immortal.

The method of enriching the nation and pacifying the people is the method of refining qi. The *Inner Classic of Laozi* states: The structure of the body mirrors the image of a nation. The sage takes the body as the nation, the heart as the ruler, and essence and qi as the people. When the people are at peace, the nation thrives; when the people scatter, the nation is enfeebled. If one cherishes essence and nurtures qi, one attains longevity. Just as a ruler cherishes the people like infants, constantly devising ways to nourish them so that the people are at peace and the nation prospers—this is the method of enriching the nation and pacifying the people. The human form is endowed with the father’s essence and mother’s blood, transformed from primordial qi. Master Zhonghuang says: Bones and flesh take essence and blood as their root, while spirit and consciousness take primordial qi as their foundation. Spirit and qi are the root of nature and life. Spirit is the child of qi, and qi is the mother of spirit—this is the mother and child within the form. When mother and child are never parted, qi abides serenely within the cinnabar terrace, naturally effecting transformations.

In praise:
The Gate of Heaven ever open,
The Door of Earth must be sealed.
Perpetually maintain continuity,
Never allowing even a moment’s lapse.
Inhaling to the root,
Exhaling to the stem.
The child is called spirit,
The mother is called qi.
Like a chick in the egg,
Like a fish in water.
Once the sacred embryo is formed,
Naturally one sloughs off like a cicada.

The Way of embracing the One is the method of refining spirit, for there is no natural Dao apart from this. Those who encounter the Dao must constantly embrace and guard the center, ensuring that spirit and qi do not scatter. Then they wander freely and at ease, becoming true persons.

In praise:
The Dao is the root of nature,
Nature is the source of the heart.
Heart and nature are of one body,
Responding and transforming without limit.
The common people in their daily use
Also call this natural.
If one can awaken to this,
Forms vanish and words are forgotten.
Empty the heart and fill the abdomen,
Embrace the One and return.
After nine revolutions of merit,
One attains immortality.

It is also said: Practicing the method of refining spirit leads to becoming a spirit immortal, where the form sinks while the spirit soars, attaining freedom. Practicing the method of refining qi leads to becoming a fetal immortal, where one refines the form, spirit and qi intermingle, mist and haze harmonize, and the embryo is nurtured to give birth to the infant—like a cicada’s molting. Practicing the method of refining the form reverses aging to regain youth, preserving the form to abide in the world.

With care, I have arranged these texts to reveal Wumingzi’s original intent in dividing the work into three scrolls.

Another edition gives Wumingzi the courtesy name Yuanming.

*Preface to the Wuzhen Pian*

Alas! The human body is hard to obtain, yet time swiftly passes. Unaware of life’s brevity, how can one escape karmic retribution? If one does not awaken in time, content to await the end, a single misguided thought at the final moment will plunge one into the three evil destinies. Then, for kalpas as numerous as dust motes, there will be no escape. At such a time, though one may regret, what use is it? Thus, the Daoist and Buddhist traditions, through the study of nature and life, open the gate of expedient means, teaching people to cultivate the seed of liberation and escape birth and death. Buddhism takes emptiness and quiescence as its宗, and if one suddenly awakens to perfect comprehension, one directly transcends to the other shore. But if habitual tendencies remain unexhausted, one still clings to existence. Daoism takes refinement and nurturance as its truth, and if one grasps its pivotal essence, one immediately ascends to sagehood. Yet if one has not awakened to the original nature, one remains entangled in the illusory form. Moreover, the *Book of Changes* contains teachings on exhausting principle, fulfilling nature, and reaching life’s culmination; the *Analects of Lu* speaks of “no willfulness, no insistence, no obstinacy, no self-absorption”—these are Confucius’s ultimate insights into the mysteries of nature and life. Yet why are their words often brief and lacking in detail? It is because they wished to order human relationships and promote the teachings of benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and music—active endeavors—so they did not explicitly expound the Way of non-action. Instead, they embedded the techniques of life in the images of the *Changes* and concealed the methods of nature within subtle words. As for *Zhuangzi*, who probed the fetters of things to reveal the nature of carefree wandering, and *Mencius*, who excelled in nurturing the flood-like qi—both came close to the crux. Then, in the Han dynasty, Wei Boyang drew upon the *Changes*’ principles of yin-yang intercourse to compose the *Cantong Qi*, elucidating the workings of the great elixir. In the Tang, the Venerable Zhong of Guoshi prefaced his recorded sayings with the words of Laozi and Zhuangzi, revealing the origin and end of the supreme Dao.

chunks.original_text: 如此，岂非教虽分三，道乃归一。 奈何后世黄缁之流各自专门，互相非是，致使三家宗要迷没邪歧，不能混一而同归矣。 且今人以道门尚於修命，而不知修命之法理出两 瑞，有易遇而难成者，有难遇而易成者。 如炼五芽之气，服七耀之光，注想按摩，纳清吐浊，念经持呎，噀水叱符，叩齿集神，休妻绝粒，存神闭息运眉间之思，补脑还精习房中之术，以致服炼金石草木之类，皆易遇难成者。 已上诸法，於修身之道率皆灭裂，故施功虽多而求效莫验。 若勤心苦志，日夕修持，上可辟病，免其非横，一日一不行，则前功渐弃。 此乃迁延岁月，必难成功，欲望州得永得，还婴返老，变化飞升，不麻拿。 深可痛伤。 盖近世修行之徒，妄有执着，不悟妙法之真，却怨神仙馒语。 殊不知成道者皆因炼金丹而得，恐泄天机，遂托数事为名。 其中问惟闭息一法，如能忘机息虑，即与二乘坐禅相同。 若勤而行之，可以入定出神。 奈何精神属阴，宅舍难固，不免常用迁徙之法，既未得金汞还返之道，又岂能回阳换骨，白日而升天哉。 夫炼金液还丹者，则难遇易成，须要洞晓阴阳，深达造化，方能追二气於黄道，会三性於元宫，钻簇五行，和合四象，龙吟虎啸，夫唱妇随，玉鼎汤煎，金炉火炽，始得玄珠成象，太乙归真，都来片饷工夫，永保无穷逸乐。 至若防危虑险，慎於运用抽添，养正持盈，要在守雌抱一。 自然返阳生之气，剥阴杀之形，节气既周，脱胎神化，名题仙籍，位号真人，此乃大丈夫功成名遂之时也。 今之学者，有取铅汞为二气，指藏府为五行，分心肾为坎离，以肝肺为龙虎，用神气为子母，执津液为铅汞，不识浮沉，宁分主客。 何异认他财为己物，呼别姓为亲儿。 又岂知金木相克之幽微，阴阳互用之奥妙。 是皆日月失道，铅汞异炉，欲结还丹，不亦难乎。 仆幼亲善道，涉践三教经书，以至刑法、书算、医卜、战阵、天文、地理、吉凶死生之术，靡不留心详究。 惟金丹一法，阅尽群经及诸家歌诗论契，皆云日魂月魄、庚虎甲龙、水银丹砂、白金黑锡、坎男离女，能成金液还丹，终不言真铅真汞是何物也。 又不说火候法度、温养指归，加以后世迷徒恣其臆说，将先圣典教妄行笺注，乖讹万状，不惟素乱仙经，抑亦惑误后学。 仆以至人未遇，口诀难逢，遂至寝食不安，精神倾顿。 虽询求褊于海岳，请益尽於贤愚，皆莫能通晓真宗，开照心腑。 后至熙宁己酉岁，因随龙图陆公入成都，以夙志不回，初诚愈恪遂感真人授金丹、药物、火候之诀，其言甚简，其要不繁，可谓指流知源，语一悟百雾开日莹，尘尽鉴明，校之仙经，若合符。 契因谓世之学仙者十有八九，而达其真要者未闻一二。 仆既遇真诠，安敢隐默，罄所得成律诗九九八十一首，号曰《悟真篇》，内七言四韵一十六首，以表二八之数。 绝句六十四首，按《周易》诸卦。 五言一首，以象太一之奇。 续添《西江月》一十二首，以周岁律。 其如鼎器尊卑、药物斤两、火候进退、主客后先、存亡有无、吉凶悔吝，悉备其中矣。 及乎篇集既成之后，又觉其中惟谈养命固形之术，而於本源真觉之性有所未究，遂玩佛书及《传灯录》至於祖师有击竹而悟者，乃形於歌颂诗曲杂言三十二首，今附之卷末，庶几达本明性之道，尽於此矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, though the teachings diverge into three, the Dao converges as one. Yet how lamentable that later generations of the yellow-robed and black-clad each cling to their own sect, mutually disparaging, causing the essential doctrines of the three schools to stray onto misleading paths, unable to merge and return to unity.

Moreover, people today assume the Daoist gate values only the cultivation of life, unaware that the methods and principles of life-cultivation arise from two auspicious sources: some are easily encountered yet difficult to accomplish, while others are difficult to encounter yet easy to accomplish. Practices such as refining the qi of the Five Sprouts, ingesting the light of the Seven Luminaries, visualizing and massaging, inhaling the pure and exhaling the turbid, reciting scriptures and chanting spells, spraying water and shouting talismans, clicking teeth to gather spirits, abandoning wives and fasting, concentrating thoughts between the brows, replenishing the brain and returning essence, or practicing bedchamber arts—along with consuming and refining minerals, herbs, and plants—all belong to the easily encountered yet difficult to accomplish. The above methods, in the path of self-cultivation, are generally fragmented and flawed; though much effort is expended, no verifiable effects are attained. Even if one diligently applies the mind and suffers hardship, practicing day and night, the best outcome is merely warding off illness and avoiding untimely misfortune. A single day of neglect, and prior progress gradually dissipates. This drags on for years, making success nearly impossible, and one cannot hope to attain longevity, reverse aging, transform the body, or ascend in broad daylight. Deeply grievous indeed!

The fault lies with modern practitioners who stubbornly cling to delusions, failing to awaken to the truth of the wondrous method, and instead blame the immortals for deceit. Little do they know that those who attain the Dao all do so through refining the golden elixir, yet fearing the leakage of celestial secrets, they veil the truth under various pretexts. Among these practices, only breath-holding—if one can forget scheming and quiet the mind—resembles the seated meditation of the Two Vehicles. If diligently practiced, it may lead to entering samadhi and projecting spirit. Yet since spirit belongs to yin and its dwelling is hard to stabilize, one must constantly employ shifting methods. Without mastering the way of returning mercury and lead, how can one reverse yang, transform the bones, and ascend to heaven in broad daylight?

Refining the golden liquid and returning the elixir, however, is difficult to encounter yet easy to accomplish. It requires thorough comprehension of yin-yang and deep penetration of creation’s workings. Only then can one pursue the two qi along the Yellow Path, unite the three natures in the Primordial Palace, gather the Five Phases, harmonize the Four Images, where dragon chants and tiger roars, husband sings and wife follows, the jade crucible simmers, and the golden furnace blazes. Only then does the Mysterious Pearl take form, the Supreme One return to truth—all achieved in a brief moment, securing boundless ease and joy forever.

Yet one must guard against danger and contemplate risks, be cautious in applying the methods of withdrawal and addition, nurture correctness and maintain fullness, and hold fast to the feminine and embrace the One. Naturally, the qi of returning yang is generated, the form of slaying yin is stripped away. When the cyclical nodes are complete, one sheds the mortal coil through spiritual transformation, the name is inscribed in the immortal register, and the title of Perfected One is conferred—this is the moment when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name is established.

Nowadays, scholars take lead and mercury as the two qi, designate the viscera as the Five Phases, split heart and kidneys into Kan and Li, regard liver and lungs as dragon and tiger, use spirit and qi as mother and child, and grasp fluids as lead and mercury. They fail to distinguish floating from sinking, much less discern host from guest. How is this different from mistaking another’s wealth for one’s own or calling a child of another surname one’s own? They remain ignorant of the subtleties of metal and wood’s mutual restraint or the mysteries of yin-yang’s reciprocal use. Thus, sun and moon lose their way, lead and mercury occupy separate crucibles—how can one hope to congeal the returning elixir?

From youth, I was devoted to the Dao, traversing the scriptures of the Three Teachings, as well as studies in penal law, calligraphy, mathematics, medicine, divination, military strategy, astronomy, geography, and the arts of fortune, misfortune, life, and death—nothing escaped my careful inquiry. Yet of the golden elixir method alone, though I perused all the classics and the songs, poems, treatises, and concordances of various schools, all spoke of the sun’s essence and moon’s spirit, Metal Tiger and Wood Dragon, mercury and cinnabar, white gold and black tin, Kan male and Li female, capable of forming the golden liquid and returning elixir—but none revealed what true lead and true mercury truly are. Nor did they explain the methods of fire timing, the standards of nurturing, or the ultimate aim. Worse still, later generations of deluded disciples, indulging their whims, recklessly annotated the sacred teachings of the ancient sages, introducing myriad errors that not only disorder the immortal scriptures but also mislead later learners.

As I had not yet encountered a perfected being and the oral instructions were hard to come by, I became restless, unable to eat or sleep, my spirit exhausted. Though I sought counsel from mountains and seas, inquired of the worthy and the foolish alike, none could clarify the true essence or illuminate the depths of my heart. Later, in the year *jiyou* of the Xining era (1069), while accompanying Minister Lu of the Dragon Diagram to Chengdu, my long-held resolve unwavering and my initial sincerity ever more reverent, I was moved to receive from a Perfected One the oral instructions on the golden elixir, its ingredients, and the fire timing. The words were concise, the essentials uncluttered—truly a case of pointing to the stream to know the source, speaking one to awaken a hundred. Like mist dispersing to reveal the sun’s brilliance or dust settling to mirror clarity, when compared with the immortal scriptures, they matched perfectly.

I reflected that of the many who study immortality, eight or nine out of ten do so, yet scarcely one or two grasp its true essentials. Having encountered the true transmission, how could I dare remain silent? I poured forth all I had received into ninety-nine regulated poems, titled *Awakening to Reality*. Among them, sixteen heptasyllabic quatrains represent the number of two eights. Sixty-four jueju verses correspond to the hexagrams of the *Zhou Changes*. One pentasyllabic poem symbolizes the oddity of the Great One. Twelve additional *West River Moon* lyrics align with the twelve months of the year. Within these are fully contained the hierarchy of crucibles, the weight of ingredients, the advance and retreat of fire timing, the precedence of host and guest, the presence and absence of existence, and the auspices and regrets of fortune.

After completing the collection, I realized it spoke only of the arts of nurturing life and preserving form, leaving the original source of true awakening unexplored. Thus, I turned to Buddhist scriptures and the *Transmission of the Lamp*, where I found that even the patriarchs attained enlightenment through such means as striking bamboo. I expressed these insights in thirty-two songs, odes, poems, and miscellaneous verses, now appended to the end of the scroll. May this suffice to illuminate the path of returning to the root and clarifying the nature, bringing it to completion.

chunks.original_text: 所期同志览之，则见末而悟本，舍妄以从真。 时皇宋熙宁乙卯岁旦，天台张伯端　平叔序。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之一 象川无名子翁葆光注武夷陈达灵传集庆空玄子戴起宗疏 七吉四韵一十六首，以表一斤二八之数 不求大道出迷途，纵负贤才岂丈夫。 百岁光阴石火烁，一生身世水泡浮。 只贪利禄求荣显，不觉形容暗瘁枯。 试问堆金等山岳，无常买得不来无。 注曰：人问世所重之极至者日富、日贵，二者皆人之所欲也，故天下之人，莫不央其性命之情，尽其平生之志，争先力求而以得之为快也。 观其所以然者，无过浸淫於利禄声色而已矣。 殊不知利禄声色，实为伐性命之戈矛，囚一身之桂桔。 夫世之人不明道德性命之妙，惟饕利禄，日恣责瞋，汨没爱河，漂流欲海，是非、人我交战，胸中喜怒哀乐互残躯体，是致尸魔，促其气寿。 寒暑削其容光，不觉在生一世，瞥然水上之呕。 光景百年，瞬若石中之火。 纵使金高北斗，玉等南山，迨至无常，而欲买身，使不为蝼蚁之窟穴可乎。 哀哉，痛哉！ ．命未告终，真灵已投於别壳矣。 虚静天师曰：今生不觉，别后换壳，投入别壳，展转不觉。 吁！ ．与其不觉投於异类，曷容栖迟於大道耶。 道遂功成，身超碧落，乘云气，御飞龙，而游乎无极，死生不变乎己，而位号真人矣。 至此乃大丈夫得意之秋，至荣至显之日也。 若乃区区俗务，碌碌尘心，而堕於世网者，纵负班、马之雄才，兼有苏、张之荣显，抑不过为土上之游魂，行尸之阴鬼耳，乌云为真大丈夫哉。 是以仙翁首咏是章，盖於时达高明之士言之，可因一言而自悟，速求大道出离迷涂，为无为事，乃真大丈夫，降此俱无足取。 参学弟子宗源日观仙翁之诗、无名子之注，而不省悟者，真愚冥之甚也，见闻之士可不下手速修耶。 别本注曰：难莫难於遇人，易莫易於成道。 现宰官长者之身，结同志得道之友，炼一黍於一霎之中，立地成道。 然纡朱怀金，门深似海，有道之士，望望然去之，此遇人之难成道之易也。 易莫易於遇人，难莫难於成道，百钱挂杖，四海一身，风植灵根，亲传至道。 然龙虎之文易解，刀圭之锁难开，得药忘言，炼铅无计，遇此人之易，成道之难也。 安得亲扣玄关，二者俱全哉。 仙翁瞻游成都，遇青城丈人，得传金液还丹之道，警叹成道之难，故作是诗，以结丹友。 其章云：试问堆金等山岳，无常买得不来无。 辞意近切如此。 虽有拱璧以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 仙翁远矣，高山流水，落落知音。 子野陆墅曰：道不负人，人乃负道。 人生虽有百年期，寿夭穷通莫预知。 昨日街头方走马，今朝棺内已眠尸。 妻财抛下非君有，罪业将行难自欺。 大药不求争得遇，知之不炼是愚痴。 注云：人寿夭穷通、富贵贫贱，未有不默意於未然之先，然非常人可测度而预知之者。 故人寿虽日百年，迨其七十固已稀矣。 今以有限易摧之身，终日汨汨而逐无涯不测之事，不亦难乎。 一息不来，则茶然疲投而不知所归，可不谓之大哀耶。 是以昨方走马，今日眠尸，出息不保入息者也。 当斯之时，虽则荣耀居极品俸禄，至万钟家丰无价之珍，室美倾城之态，悉皆抛下，非己有也。 所可与之偕行而不可欺者，昔所造之罪业而已。

May those of like aspiration who peruse these words perceive the branch and awaken to the root, forsaking delusion to follow truth.

Written on the first day of the year *yimao* in the reign of Emperor Xining of the Great Song, by Zhang Boduan, styled Pingshu, of Tiantai.

*Commentary and Annotations on the "Awakening to Reality" of the Perfected One of Purple Yang, Scroll One*

Xiangchuan Wumingzi Weng Baoguang annotated
Wu Yi Chen Daling transmitted
Qingkongzi Dai Qizong collated

Seven-character quatrains, sixteen in all, to express the weight of one catty and the number two-eight:

Not seeking the Great Dao to escape delusion,
Even with worthy talent, how can one be a true man?
A hundred years of light pass like a spark from stone,
A lifetime’s existence floats like a bubble on water.
Only craving profit and rank, seeking glory and fame,
Unknowing, the form and countenance wither and dry.
Try asking: though gold be piled like mountains,
Can impermanence buy back what is not yet gone?

**Annotation:**
When asked what the world values most, the answer is wealth and nobility—both are what people desire. Thus, all under heaven exhaust their nature and life’s essence, expending their lifelong aspirations, striving with all their might to obtain them, finding joy in their attainment.

Yet observe the reason for this: it is nothing more than indulgence in profit, rank, fame, and sensual pleasures. Little do they know that profit, rank, fame, and sensual pleasures are in truth the spears and halberds that sever life and nature, the fetters that bind the body.

People of the world, not understanding the wonders of the Dao, virtue, nature, and life, only glut themselves on profit and rank, daily indulging in greed and anger, drowning in the river of love, adrift in the sea of desire. Right and wrong, self and others wage war within, while joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure within the breast mutually ravage the body, summoning the corpse-demons that shorten the breath and lifespan.

Cold and heat erode the radiance of the countenance, unknowing that in this lifetime, one’s existence is but a fleeting bubble on water. A hundred years of light and shadow pass in an instant like a spark from stone. Though gold be heaped as high as the Northern Dipper and jade amassed like the Southern Mountains, when impermanence arrives, can one buy back the body and prevent it from becoming a nest for ants and worms?

Alas! How grievous! Before life’s end is announced, the true spirit has already entered another shell.

The Master of Serene Emptiness said: "Unawakened in this life, after death one changes shells, entering another form, revolving endlessly without awareness."

Ah! Rather than unawakened entry into another species, why not abide in the Great Dao? When the Dao is accomplished and the work complete, the body ascends beyond the azure heavens, riding the clouds and qi, driving flying dragons, and roaming the boundless. Death and life no longer alter the self, and one is titled a Perfected One. This is the season of fulfillment for a true man, the day of utmost glory and fame.

Yet those entangled in mundane affairs, their hearts mired in worldly dust, falling into the snares of the world—though they possess the heroic talent of Ban and Ma, and the glory and fame of Su and Zhang—are but wandering souls upon the earth, shadowy ghosts of walking corpses. How can they be called true men?

Thus, the Immortal Elder first composed this verse, speaking to those of lofty and enlightened understanding, that they might awaken through a single word, swiftly seek the Great Dao to escape delusion, and engage in the work of non-doing. Only then is one a true man; all else is unworthy of regard.

**Disciple of the Study Zongyuan’s Reflection:**
Those who read the Immortal Elder’s poems and Wumingzi’s annotations without awakening are truly the most benighted. O those who have seen and heard, can you not hasten to practice?

**Alternative Annotation:**
Nothing is harder than encountering the right person; nothing is easier than attaining the Dao. Manifesting as an official or elder, forming bonds with like-minded friends on the path to the Dao, refining a single grain of millet in a fleeting moment, one may attain the Dao in an instant.

Yet draped in crimson and holding gold, with gates as deep as the sea, those of the Dao turn away in dismay—this is the difficulty of encountering the right person and the ease of attaining the Dao.

Nothing is easier than encountering the right person; nothing is harder than attaining the Dao. With a hundred coins hanging from a staff, one roams the four seas alone, planting the spiritual root, receiving the transmission of the supreme Dao.

Yet the patterns of dragon and tiger are easy to comprehend, while the locks of the elixir spoon are hard to open. Having obtained the medicine, one forgets words; refining lead, one has no method. This is the ease of encountering the right person and the difficulty of attaining the Dao.

How can one personally knock at the mysterious pass and achieve both?

The Immortal Elder wandered to Chengdu, where he met the Elder of Qingcheng and received the transmission of the Golden Fluid Returning Elixir. Moved by the difficulty of attaining the Dao, he composed this poem to gather fellow alchemists. The verse reads: *"Try asking: though gold be piled like mountains, / Can impermanence buy back what is not yet gone?"* The meaning is urgent and pressing.

Though one offer a double handful of jade before a team of four horses, it is not as good as sitting and advancing in this Dao.

The Immortal Elder is far beyond us—like high mountains and flowing waters, rare are those who know his music.

Ziye of Luzhu said: "The Dao does not betray man; man betrays the Dao. Though a human life may span a hundred years, longevity or early death, poverty or prosperity cannot be foreknown. Yesterday, one rode a horse through the streets; today, one lies as a corpse in a coffin. Wealth and wives are left behind, no longer yours; the karma of sins follows, impossible to deceive. If one does not seek the Great Medicine, how can one encounter it? To know it and not refine it is foolishness."

**Annotation:**
No one can foresee or predetermine longevity or early death, prosperity or poverty, wealth or lowliness. Yet all secretly harbor desires for what has not yet come to pass, though these are beyond the measure of ordinary people.

Thus, though a human lifespan may be a hundred years, reaching seventy is already rare. Now, with a fragile body easily destroyed, one spends each day in ceaseless pursuit of boundless and unpredictable affairs—is this not difficult?

When a single breath does not return, one suddenly collapses, not knowing where to go—can this not be called great sorrow? Thus, one who was riding a horse yesterday lies as a corpse today: the outgoing breath does not guarantee the incoming one.

At such a time, though one’s glory and rank reach the highest offices, with salaries of ten thousand bushels, a household rich in priceless treasures, a chamber filled with beauties who could topple a city—all are cast aside, no longer one’s own. The only thing that accompanies one, impossible to deceive, is the karma of sins committed in the past.

chunks.original_text: 所以万般将不去，惟有业随身也。 夫人欲免轮回而不堕於世网者，莫若金丹大药，为升天之灵梯，超几之捷径也。 其道至简至易，虽愚昧小人得而行之，亦立跻圣位。 奈何上圣秘重，不许轻泄，传之者皆口口相授，不记文字，是以难遇也。 自匪勤求苦志，诚动高穹，未或闻於一二也。 昔谢自然以兹道之难遇，欲求真师於蓬莱，竭其家产以备舟楫，不顾洪涛巨浪之厄，直往而不少惮，遂感神人而语之曰：蓬莱隔弱水三万里，一芥不为之浮，子将安往。 赤城山有司马子微在焉，子往师之。 谢回舟寻访赤城，果遇子微授道，修之不辍，不数载白日升天。 噫！ 人之精诚一发於中，感格於神人者，将无往而不遇矣。 人苟能操心秉志如此，奚虑金丹不得耶。 道不负人，人自负之耳。 《参同契》曰：大道无适莫兮，惟传於贤者。 倘不推诚而力慕，争得遇之耶。 惟夫金丹秘要诚难遇矣，得遇之者，皆风有仙骨，祖宗阴德累积深厚也。 然亦须有财力，丹友三人，方能成就。 此理惟达者知，诚难一一具言也。 阴真君《六五精微论》曰：欲学此道，须假资财。 如无资财，金丹即不成也。 又须三人，方可修炼。 所以冲熙王君遇仙人刘海蟾，得金丹衍，无财下工，遂入洛谒富韩公，赖其力成道而去。 苟通之而又有力，不早修炼者，不亦愚痴之甚乎。 仙翁赠刘君诗曰：闻君知药已多年，何不收心炼汞铅。 莫教烛被风吹灭，六道轮回莫怨天。 亦此意也。 别本注曰：麟凤不出世，神仙不常见。 有能空梦泡幻影之身，可脱生死老病之苦，为人间希有之事。 道上逢师，师边得旨，下手速修犹太迟耳。 仙翁非是诗，其末章云：大道不求争得遇，知之不炼是愚痴。 其叮咛恳切如此语。 侪。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, of all the myriad things, none will accompany one in the end—only the karma one carries remains.

For those who wish to escape the cycle of rebirth and avoid entanglement in the world’s snares, nothing surpasses the Great Elixir of Golden Cinnabar as the sacred ladder to ascension and the swiftest path to transcendence. Its Way is utterly simple and effortless; even the dullest and most ignorant may practice it and swiftly ascend to sagehood. Yet the highest sages guard it with utmost secrecy, forbidding its careless disclosure. Those who transmit it do so only through direct oral instruction, never committing it to writing—hence its rarity. Unless one seeks it with tireless devotion and sincerity that moves the highest heavens, one may scarcely hear even a whisper of it.

In ancient times, Xie Ziran, despairing of the Way’s elusiveness, sought a true master on Penglai. He exhausted his family’s wealth to prepare a boat, heedless of the perils of towering waves and raging tides, pressing onward without fear. Moved by his resolve, a divine being spoke to him: “Penglai lies beyond thirty thousand *li* of weak waters, where not even a mustard seed may float—where do you think you are going? On Mount Chicheng dwells Sima Ziwei; go and take him as your teacher.” Xie turned his boat and sought out Mount Chicheng, where he indeed found Ziwei and received the Way. Through unceasing cultivation, within a few years, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight.

Ah! When a person’s sincerity bursts forth from within and resonates with the divine, there is nowhere it will not be met. If one could but hold fast to such resolve, what worry is there that the Golden Elixir would not be attained? The Way does not fail people—people fail themselves.

As the *Cantong Qi* says: “The Great Way is not partial; it is transmitted only to the worthy.” If one does not pursue it with utmost sincerity and ardent longing, how can one hope to encounter it?

Truly, the secret essentials of the Golden Elixir are difficult to come by. Those who do encounter them are born with the bones of immortals, their ancestors’ accumulated hidden virtue deep and profound. Yet even then, one must possess the means: three fellow cultivators are required to achieve success. This principle is known only to the enlightened; it is too subtle to be fully expounded.

As Master Yin Zhenjun states in the *Six-Five Subtleties*: “To study this Way, one must have resources. Without resources, the Golden Elixir cannot be completed. Moreover, three people are needed for its refinement.” Thus, when Lord Chongxi met the immortal Liu Haichan and received the transmission of the Golden Elixir, lacking the means to begin, he journeyed to Luoyang to seek the wealthy Han Gong. Through Han’s assistance, he completed the Way and departed.

If one has both the understanding and the means yet delays cultivation, is this not the height of folly?

An immortal elder once addressed Master Liu in verse:
*“I hear you’ve known the medicine for many years—*
*Why not still your heart and refine mercury and lead?*
*Lest the candle be snuffed out by the wind,*
*Do not blame heaven for the six paths of rebirth.”*

Such is the meaning.

Another commentary notes: “Unicorns and phoenixes do not appear in the world; divine immortals are rarely seen. To empty the body of its dreamlike, illusory form, to escape the suffering of birth, aging, sickness, and death—this is a rarity among mortals. If one meets a master on the Way and receives their guidance, to begin practice swiftly is still too late. The immortal elder’s verse is no mere poetry; its closing lines declare:
*‘The Great Way is not sought in vain—*
*To know it yet not refine it is sheer folly.’*
Such earnest admonition is spoken thus.”

Han Changli’s poem reads:
In Nanchong County of Guozhou,
Cold as Xie Ziran.
The children knew nothing,
Only that there were immortals.
Light of life, they learned his art,
There at Gold Spring Mountain.
One morning, seated in empty space,
Mists arose between them—
As if the strains of pipes and reeds
Came from the dark heavens.

Drifting like smoke in the clouds.

The prefect marveled and sighed.

The common folk vied to be first.

Surely true and fit to be passed down.

On the night he received the Register, celestial music resounded in the empty sky above the peaks. The mountain’s inscribed stone recorded the event.

*"Yin and yang of grasses and trees stand paired in balance—
Lack but one, and fragrance fades."*

chunks.original_text: 初开绿叶阳先倡，次发红花阴后随。 常道即兹为日用，真源返此有谁知。 报言学道诸君子，不识阴阳莫乱为。 注曰：草木未生之初，含孕至朴。 及其甲拆，禀一气以萌芽。 故抽一干以象一气，次分两叶以象阴阳。 又於两叶中间复抽一药，以应三才。 过此已往，渐渐支离，花叶芬菲。 春以之生而开绿叶，夏以之长而发红花，此阳气使之然也。 秋以之肃而结实，冬以之杀而粪本，此阴气使之然也。 阴阳两齐，化生不已，若还缺一，则万物不生。 故真一子曰：孤阴不自产，寡阳不自成。 是以天地氤氲，万物化醇。 男女媾精，万物化生。 常道即兹，以为日用。 真源反覆，有阴阳颠倒互用之机，人能炼之，可以超生死。 学者苟不明此而反我者，乃蒙蔽耳。 阳裹阴精质不刚一作，莫把孤阴为有阳，独修一物转赢廷。 劳形按引皆非道，服气餐霞总是狂。 举世馒求铅汞伏，何时得见虎龙降。 劝君穷取生身处，返本还元是药王。 注曰：阳裹阴精，己之真精也。 精能生气，气能生神，荣卫一身，莫大於此，油桔灯灭，髓竭人亡。 此言精气实一身之根本也，奈何此物属阴，其质不刚，其性好飞，日逐前后便溺、涕唾汗泪，易失难擒，不受制炼，故圣人谓之太阳流光，其性猛烈，若不得混元真一，阳丹以制之，兼以阴中阳火以育之，则无由凝结以成变化。 若只修此一物，转见廷赢。 按引劳形，皆非正道。 养霞服气，总是狂图。 设使吞日月之精华，光生五藏，运双关於夹脊，脑补精还，以至尸解投胎，出神入定，千门万法，不过修阳裹阴精一物而已。 孤阴无阳，如牝鸡自卯，欲抱成鸡，岂可得乎。 锺离公曰：涕唾精津气血液，七般物事总皆阴。 若将此物为仙质，怎得飞神贯玉京。 以此言之，一身之中，非惟真精一物属阴，五脏六腑俱阴非阳。 分心肾为坎离，以肝肺为龙虎，得乎？ 用神气为子母，执津液为铅汞，得乎？ 若执此等治身而求纯阳之证，犹如去玲加冰，除热用汤，飞龟飞蛇，愈见乖张。 《参同契》曰：使二女同居，颜色甚殊，苏秦通言，张仪结媒，发辨利舌，奋为美辞，推心调合，谐为夫妇，弊发腐齿，终不相知。 此喻以女妻女，以阴炼阴，安能有产化之道哉。 真龙真虎者，一八是也。 真铅真汞者，龙虎二弦之气也。 此道至简不繁，至近匪遥，但学者执僻坚，以傍门非类之药为铅汞，及以大道真诀为非，深可悲伤。 故锺离公曰：求仙不识真铅汞，护读丹经千万篇。 不识个中含蓄意，谤他真语作虚言。 故仙翁直指铅汞所产川源之处，身从何生，命从何立。 返此之本，还此之源，颠倒修之，则真龙真虎自降，真铅真汞自伏。 非药之王，其孰能与於此哉。 近世多矣，十六岁童男童女，使之交合，泄而成胎，谓之胎元丹，谓之紫河车，以此为金丹大药，是犹接竹点月，不亦远之愈远乎。 后天地生有形有质者，皆非至药。 盖形而下者，非先天之道也。 又上阳子曰：《契》云：是非历藏法，内视有所思，阴道厌九一，浊乱弄元胞，诸衍甚众多，千条有万余。 彭真人曰：世人不达大道之宗元，而趋傍门之曲径，此属多般皆为左道，乖讹天理，悖乱至真，不达黄帝之文，全失老君之旨，本期永寿，反尔伤身。 仆曰：只为世人执己而修，则千条万径无非傍门者矣。
chunks.translated_text:
At first, the green leaves emerge, with yang taking the lead;
Next, the red blossoms bloom, as yin follows behind.
The constant Dao lies herein for daily use—
Who knows the true source, when turned back to this?

I say to all you gentlemen who study the Dao:
Without understanding yin and yang, do not act recklessly.

**Annotation:**
Before grasses and trees come into being, they contain the purest essence. When their husks split open, they receive the one qi to sprout. Thus, a single stem rises to symbolize the one qi, then divides into two leaves to symbolize yin and yang. Between these two leaves, a bud emerges once more, corresponding to the Three Powers. Beyond this, they gradually branch out, their flowers and leaves flourishing. In spring, they grow and unfurl green leaves; in summer, they mature and bloom red flowers—this is the work of yang qi. In autumn, they wither and bear fruit; in winter, they decay and nourish their roots—this is the work of yin qi. When yin and yang stand paired in balance, transformation and generation never cease. If one is lacking, the myriad things cannot come to be. Thus, Master Zhenyi said: *"A solitary yin cannot give birth on its own; a lone yang cannot achieve completion."* Therefore, when heaven and earth intermingle in harmony, the myriad things are transformed into purity. When male and female unite in essence, the myriad things are born through transformation. The constant Dao lies herein for daily use. The true source, when reversed, holds the mechanism of yin and yang’s inversion and mutual employment. Those who can refine this may transcend life and death. Yet scholars who fail to comprehend this and turn against it are merely deluded.

If yin essence is wrapped within yang, its substance is not firm—
Do not mistake a solitary yin for possessing yang.
Cultivating but a single element only weakens the body further.
Exhausting the form through stretching and guiding is not the Dao;
Ingesting qi and consuming mist is sheer madness.

The world seeks in vain to subdue lead and mercury—
When will they ever witness the descent of tiger and dragon?
I urge you to thoroughly explore the place of your birth,
For returning to the root and restoring the origin is the King of Medicines.

**Annotation:**
The yin essence wrapped within yang is one’s true essence. Essence generates qi, and qi generates spirit. Nothing is more vital to the nourishment and defense of the body than these. When the oil is exhausted, the lamp goes out; when the marrow is depleted, the person perishes. This speaks of essence and qi as the very root of the body. Yet alas, this substance belongs to yin—its nature is not firm, and its tendency is to flee. Day by day, it is lost through urine, sweat, tears, and saliva, easily dissipated and difficult to capture, refusing to be refined and controlled. Thus, the sages called it *"the radiant light of the Great Yang,"* for its nature is fierce and violent. Without the True One of the Primordial Origin and the yang elixir to restrain it, combined with the yang fire within yin to nurture it, there is no way for it to congeal and transform. If one cultivates only this single element, the body will only grow weaker. Stretching and guiding the form, ingesting mist and consuming qi—all are false paths. Even if one were to swallow the essence of the sun and moon, illuminating the five viscera, or circulate the twin passes at the spine, replenishing the brain and returning essence, or achieve corpse liberation, rebirth, spirit departure, or deep meditation—through a thousand methods and ten thousand techniques, one would still be cultivating only the yin essence wrapped within yang. A solitary yin without yang is like a hen laying an egg, hoping to hatch a chick—how could it ever succeed?

Master Zhongli said:
*"Tears, saliva, essence, fluids, qi, blood, and marrow—
These seven substances are all yin.
If one takes these as the material for immortality,
How could the spirit ever soar to the Jade Capital?"*

From this, it is clear that within the body, not only is true essence a yin substance—even the five viscera and six bowels are yin, not yang. Can one truly divide the heart and kidneys into Kan and Li, or the liver and lungs into dragon and tiger? Can one use spirit and qi as mother and child, or cling to fluids as lead and mercury? If one relies on such methods to cultivate the body in pursuit of the state of pure yang, it is like removing ice by adding frost, or quenching fire with boiling water—like making a turtle or snake fly, only to see it grow more erratic.

*The Kinship of the Three* states:
*"Make two women live together—their complexions differ greatly.
Su Qin speaks eloquently, Zhang Yi arranges the match,
Their tongues sharp as swords, their words sweet as honey.
They feign sincerity to harmonize, pretending to be husband and wife,
Yet in the end, their hair rots and their teeth decay—
They never truly know one another."*

This metaphor speaks of marrying a woman to a woman, refining yin with yin—how could there be any path to generation and transformation? The true dragon and true tiger are the one and the eight. True lead and true mercury are the qi of the dragon and tiger’s two arcs. This Dao is utterly simple, not complex; utterly near, not distant. Yet scholars cling stubbornly to their biases, mistaking heterodox and unrelated medicines for lead and mercury, and dismissing the true formulas of the Great Dao as false. How deeply lamentable!

Thus, Master Zhongli said:
*"Those who seek immortality without knowing true lead and mercury
May pore over a thousand or ten thousand volumes of alchemical classics,
Yet if they fail to grasp the hidden meaning within,
They will slander the true teachings as empty words."*

Therefore, the Immortal Elder directly points to the source of lead and mercury, to the place from which the body is born and life is established. By returning to this root and restoring this origin, and by inverting the process of cultivation, the true dragon and true tiger will naturally descend, and true lead and true mercury will naturally be subdued. If not the King of Medicines, who else could achieve this?

In recent times, many have taken sixteen-year-old boys and girls, made them copulate, and collected the semen to form an embryo, calling it *"Embryonic Origin Elixir"* or *"Purple River Chariot,"* regarding it as the great medicine of the golden elixir. This is like trying to catch the moon by grasping at bamboo—does it not only grow more distant? All things born after heaven and earth, possessing form and substance, are not the supreme medicine. For that which is below form is not the Dao of the prior heaven.

Master Shangyang said:
*The Kinship* states:
*"This is not the method of circulating through the viscera;
Inward contemplation leads to distraction.
The yin path disdains the nine and the one,
Defiling and disturbing the primordial womb.
The branches are many, the methods countless—
A thousand paths, ten thousand techniques."*

Master Peng said:
*"The world does not comprehend the fundamental origin of the Great Dao
And instead pursues the crooked paths of heterodox methods.
These myriad practices are all left-handed ways,
Deviating from heavenly principle, violating the supreme truth.
They fail to grasp the writings of the Yellow Emperor
And completely miss the intent of the Old Master.
What was meant to bring eternal life
Only harms the body instead."*

I say: It is only because the world clings to self-cultivation that its thousand paths and ten thousand techniques are nothing but heterodox ways.

chunks.original_text: 仙翁垂悯直言，穷取生身处，岂不直露天机。 此正合锺离公云：生我之门、死我之户。 大哉，上贤说道，下稍无人承当何哉？ 绿为世人因业识中来，却又因业识中去。 一阳奔走於形，虽男子身中皆阴，若执一己而修，岂能还其元而返其本，又将何而回阳换骨哉。 是以大修行人，求先天真铅，叉从一初受气生身之处求之，方可得彼先天真一气，以还其元而返其本也，此为男子修仙之道。 女人修行，则以乳房为生气所，其法充简。 是以男子修仙日炼气，女人修仙曰炼形。 坎女修炼，先积气於乳房，然后安炉立鼎，行太阴炼形之法，其道易成者，良有旨。 宣和中，洞宾游吴兴，见一妓张珍奴，色华美，性澹素，虽落风尘，每夕沐浴更衣灶香告天，求脱去甚切。 洞宾作一士访之，珍奴见之，风神秀异，殊敬尽欢而去。 明日又至，如是往往月余，终不及乱。 张珍奴曰：荷君春顾甚久，独不留一宿，罄枕席之欢娱，岂妾猥漏，不足奉君子耶？ 士曰：不然。 人贵心相知，何叉如此哉。
chunks.translated_text:
The Immortal Elder, in compassion, speaks plainly,
Tracing life to its very source—how could this not reveal the celestial mechanism?
This aligns precisely with what Lord Zhongli declared:
*"The gate that gives me life, the door that takes it away."*
How profound! The sagely teachings of the highest worth—
Yet among the lower ranks, none can bear their weight.

For worldly folk come from the realm of karmic consciousness,
And to the realm of karmic consciousness they return.
As the solitary yang flees through the form,
Even within the male body, all is yin.
If one clings to self-cultivation,
How can one restore the primordial and return to the root?
And by what means could one reverse yang and renew the bones?

Thus, the great practitioner
Seeks the precelestial true lead,
Tracing it back to the very origin where qi was first received and life began.
Only then can one obtain that precelestial true unified qi,
Restoring the primordial and returning to the root—
This is the Way for men to cultivate immortality.

For women, the path of practice centers on the breasts as the seat of generative qi,
And the method is simple and unadorned.
Thus, men cultivate immortality by refining qi,
While women cultivate immortality by refining form.

In the practice of the Kan woman,
One first accumulates qi in the breasts,
Then establishes the furnace and tripod,
And proceeds with the Great Yin method of refining form.
This Way is easily accomplished—truly, there is deep meaning here.

During the Xuanhe era, Lü Dongbin traveled to Wuxing,
Where he encountered a courtesan named Zhang Zhennu,
Whose beauty was radiant and whose nature was pure and unadorned.
Though fallen among the wind and dust,
Each night she bathed, changed her clothes, lit incense at the hearth, and prayed to Heaven,
Earnestly seeking liberation.

Dongbin, disguised as a scholar, visited her.
Zhennu, seeing his refined and extraordinary bearing,
Treated him with utmost respect and hospitality before he departed.
The next day, he returned, and this continued for over a month,
Yet he never once crossed the bounds of propriety.

Zhang Zhennu said:
*"You have honored me with your visits for so long,
Yet never stayed a single night to enjoy the pleasures of the pillow and mat.
Could it be that I am too coarse and unworthy to serve you, sir?"*

The scholar replied:
*"Not so. What matters most is the meeting of minds—
Why must it come to this?"*

chunks.original_text: 且如汝每夜告天，实何所求。 珍曰：失身於此，又将何为。 但自念奴入是门中，妄施粉黛，以假为真，歌枢艳曲，以悲为乐。 本是一团臭脓皮袋，借为饰以惑人，每每悔叹，世之愚夫不自尊贵。 过我门者，观我如一枝花，情牵意恋，留恋不拾，非但求财，多致身顶。 妾虽假容交惧，觉办愈重，惟旦夕告天，早析了脱。 士曰：汝志如此，何不学道。 珍奴曰：陷于此地，何从得师。 士曰：吾为汝师可乎。 珍即拜叩。 士曰：再来乃可。 遂去。 珍日夜望不至，深自悔恨，自书曰：逢师许多时，不说些兄个。 安得仍前相对坐，懊恨韶光空自过。 直到如今问头我。 笔未竟，士忽来见，所书读其韵曰：别无巧妙与，你方见一个。 子后午前定息坐，夹脊双关昆仑过。 急时得气力思量我。 珍大喜，士乃以太阴炼形丹法与之。 珍自是神气裕然，若大开悟。 不知密有，所传尤多，珍亦不以告人。 临别留步蟾官云：坎离坤兑分子午，须认取自家宗祖。 地雷震动山头雨，要洗濯黄芽出土。 捉得金精牢闭固，辨甲庚要生龙虎。 待他问汝甚传人，但说先生姓吕。 珍方悟是吕先生。 即佯狂，丐于市，投荒地密修真诀，愈三年，尸解而去。 修行事不问男女，若勇猛心坚成道爻矣。 疏日； 太阳流珠，《参同契》本旨正以喻灵汞之难伏。 今无名子取以喻人身之汞，解此亦通。 太上曰：万物负阴而抱阳，是皆因阴阳而成也。 人与万物未尝无阳，今以人身皆为阴者何也，以其后天地生，有质生质。 既有质，则为阴阳五行所拘而为阴矣，所以不能变化。 《参同契》云：物无阴阳，违天背元。 彭真人云：孤阴寡阳，不能自生。 成外药之妙，非无阴也。 今以为纯阳者何也，以其气得之先天地生，无质生质，能化有形为无形。 故能变化后天之气，亦为先天之气而为纯阳，故日阳也。 或问曰：阳裹阴精质不刚，不可用也。 今又曰：兼以阴中阳火以育之，何也？ 曰：此大小炉鼎中之真火也。 人身纯阴，只有一点元海真火，若得阳丹以制之，则不复飞走。 又以阴中阳火以育之，则还丹可结。 是知阴精不可以独修，铃用以兼修，则呼吸涵育，接大小炉鼎之火归於身，自然还丹凝结，以成变化。 在大小炉鼎，则日阴中阳火。 在人身，则日阴裹阳精。 紫河车在仙方补益病躯，非可比变化形神者。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之一 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷二

And what, pray, do you seek each night in your prayers to Heaven?"
Zhennu replied: "Having lost myself to this life, what else could I do? Yet I reflect: since entering this gate, I have wantonly applied powder and rouge, passing false for true; sung lewd and seductive songs, turning sorrow into mirth. This body is but a sack of foul pus, dressed to deceive. How I regret it—foolish men, failing to honor their own worth, pass my door and see me as a mere flower, their hearts ensnared, their wills undone. They seek not only wealth but often ruin themselves. Though I feign joy in such exchanges, my burden only grows heavier. Thus, I pray day and night for early release."

The scholar said: "With such resolve, why not study the Dao?"
Zhennu answered: "Trapped in this place, where would I find a teacher?"
The scholar replied: "Might I be your teacher?"
Zhennu immediately bowed in reverence.
The scholar said: "Come again, and it may be so." Then he departed.

Zhennu waited day and night, but he did not return. Filled with remorse, she wrote:
*"For so long I met my teacher,
Yet never asked a single question.
How could we sit face to face again,
Lamenting time wasted in vain?
Only now do I turn to seek the source."*

Before she finished writing, the scholar suddenly appeared. Reading her verse, he composed a matching rhyme:
*"No clever tricks to impart,
You’ll soon see one true part.
Sit in stillness from midnight to noon,
Qi rises past the double passes, over Kunlun’s moon.
When urgency strikes, recall my art."*

Overjoyed, Zhennu received from him the method of *Taiyin Lianxing* (Refining Form through the Great Yin). From that moment, her spirit and qi flourished as if a great awakening had dawned. Though she received many secret teachings, she revealed none to others.

At their parting, he left her a verse in the *Chan Palace* style:
*"Kan and Li, Qian and Dui divide the Zi and Wu,
You must recognize your own ancestral root.
Earth’s thunder shakes, rain falls on the mountain’s crest,
To wash and nurture the yellow sprout from the soil’s breast.
Seize the golden essence, bind it firm and tight,
Distinguish Jia and Geng to birth dragon and tiger’s might.
When asked what lineage you transmit,
Say only: ‘My teacher bears the surname Lü.’"*

Only then did Zhennu realize he was Master Lü. She feigned madness, begged in the marketplace, and retreated to the wilderness to secretly cultivate the true method. After three years, she departed through *shijie* (liberation by corpse).

The path of cultivation knows no distinction of male or female; with courage and unwavering resolve, the Dao may be attained.

**Commentary:**
The *Taiyang Liuzhu* (Flowing Pearl of the Great Yang) in the *Cantong Qi* (Token for the Agreement of the Three) originally illustrates the difficulty of subduing *linggong* (spiritual mercury). Here, the anonymous author uses it to symbolize the mercury within the human body—a valid interpretation.

The *Taishang* (Most High) said: "All things bear yin and embrace yang, for they are formed through the interplay of yin and yang." Neither humans nor other beings lack yang, yet why is the human body deemed entirely yin? Because, born after Heaven and Earth, it possesses form and substance. Once form exists, it is constrained by yin, yang, and the Five Phases, becoming yin and thus incapable of transformation.

The *Cantong Qi* states: "Things without yin and yang defy Heaven and forsake the Origin." Master Peng said: "Solitary yin or solitary yang cannot generate life." The wonder of external elixirs is not the absence of yin. Why, then, is it called *chunyang* (pure yang)? Because its qi precedes Heaven and Earth, unburdened by form or substance, it can transform the tangible into the intangible. Thus, it transmutes postnatal qi into prenatal qi, becoming pure yang—hence, yang.

One might ask: "If yang is wrapped in yin’s essence, its quality is not firm—how can it be used? Yet you also say it must be nurtured with *yang fire within yin*—why?" This refers to the true fire within the great and small crucibles. The human body, being pure yin, possesses only a single spark of true fire in the *yuanhai* (primordial sea). If yang elixir is used to restrain it, it will no longer flee. Nurturing it further with *yang fire within yin* allows the *huandan* (returned elixir) to coalesce.

Thus, yin essence cannot be cultivated alone; it must be refined in tandem. Through breath and nurturance, the fires of the great and small crucibles are drawn into the body, naturally condensing the returned elixir to enable transformation. In the great and small crucibles, this is called *yang fire within yin*; within the human body, it is *yang essence wrapped in yin*.

The *Ziheche* (Purple River Carriage) in immortal formulas replenishes the ailing body, but it cannot compare to the transformation of form and spirit. *Ziyang Zhenren Wuzhen Pian Zhushu*, Scroll One

chunks.original_text: 象川无名子翁葆光注武夷陈达灵传集庆空玄子戴起宗疏 不识真铅正祖宗，万般作用枉施功。 休妻馒遣阴阳隔，绝粒徒教肠胃空。 草木金银皆滓质，云霞日月属朦胧。 更饶吐纳并存想，总与金丹事不同。 注曰：真铅之要，以二八之气为宗，此外皆非至道，枉施功耳。 夷门破迷歌曰：孤寡不是道，阴阳失宗旨。 王真人曰：学人刚要辞妻妾，不念无为无不为。 高象先曰：或阳兮孤妻，或阴兮独宿。 此皆言孤阴寡阳、独修一物之意。 或者不知又执此说，以行房中御女之衍，毁谤仙道，咎将谁归。 殊不知喻阳夫阴妻之义，非人问夫妻也。 《破迷歌》曰：休粮不是道，死后作饿鬼。 以上诸物皆后天地生，查滓之类，易遇难成，乌可与金丹大药同旦而语哉。 疏曰：休粮绝粒、吐纳存想等法，皆傍门俗士因不休妻之句误。 以探阴之衍为金丹者多矣，胡不全究太白真人《破迷歌》乎：行气不是道，津液非神水。 存想不是道，画饼岂为饵。 探阴不是道，精竭命随逝。 断盐不是道，饮食无滋味。 辟谷．不是道，饥馁伤脾胃。 休妻不是道，阴阳失宗位。 如何却是道，太一舍真气o,气交而不交，升降效天地。 二物相配合，起自於元始。 媳女与婴儿，匹配成既济。 本是真阴阳，夫妻同一义。 所以不须休，孤阳岂成事。 出世为金仙，金丹非容易。 志士不说真，大洞隐深义。 五行不顺行，虎向水中生。 五行类倒卫，龙从火裹出。 斯言真妙言，便是太一力。 仙翁律诗所以盖本此也。 夷门《破迷歌》：太一含真气，龙自火中生，虎自水中起，阴阳知颠倒，本自於元始。 五行不顺行，还同於天地。 及休妻之义，皆不及《太一歌》明白。 世人既不知五行频倒，又安能知真阴阳之不须休乎。 学仙之士，於仙书名目不能尽知，又安能详玩全文混融一於理乎。 是以金丹大道，世远书亡，性昏道晦，诅因休妻馒遣阴阳隔之说，讹为世问夫妻，流入淫衍。 惜哉！ ．丹成气满，自然绝粒，非如服黑豆、胡麻子等药，以度凶年。 或者饵药辟谷； 以卫流世，安能成纯阳之仙。 问有专饵草木，纵得长生，亦非纯阳之质。 右警劝世人，明大道，破傍门。 此系空玄子分类。 学仙须是学天仙，惟有金丹最的瑞。 二物会时情性合，五行全处龙虎蟠。 本因戊己为媒聘，遂使夫妻镇合欢。 只候功成朝帝阙，九霞光裹驾翔鸾。 注曰：仙有数等，阴神至灵而无形者，鬼仙也。 处世无诸疾恼而永寿者，人仙也。 飞空走雾、饥渴不挠、寒暑无侵、遨游海岛、长生不死者，地仙也。 形神俱妙、与道合真、步日月无影、入金石无碍、水火不焚溺、变化无穷、或老或少、隐显莫测、若存若亡、消则成气、息则成形、着龟莫能测、鬼神莫能知者，天仙也。 阴真君曰：若能绝欲，兼修胎息，移神入壳，入定投尸，托阴生化而不坏者，可为下品仙也。 若授六甲符录，正一盟威。 上清大洞经录等法，及剑卫、尸解等衍得道者，立为南官列仙，隐诸洞府，为中品仙也。 若是修金丹大药得道者，全身冲天，为无极上品之天仙也。 故仙翁勉修真之士，须立志慷慨，特达不韦，无为彼中下之仙，直为无上九品极上天仙可也。 夫五金、八石、朱砂、水银、黑铅、白锡、黄丹、雄黄、雌黄、枇霜、粉霜、曾青、胆矾、秋石、草木灰霜、水查滓煮伏之类，以至自己津精气血液等，此皆后天。
chunks.translated_text:
The Xiangchuan Wumingzi Weng Baoguang annotated *Wu Yi Chen Daling’s Collected Transmissions of Ji Qingkongxuanzi Dai Qizong*:

Not knowing the true Lead’s true ancestry,
All efforts are vainly expended.
Dismissing one’s wife severs yin and yang,
Fasting leaves the stomach and bowels empty.
Herbs, trees, gold, and silver are but dregs;
Clouds, mist, sun, and moon remain obscure.
Even with breath-work and visualization,
None compare to the work of the Golden Elixir.

Annotation: The essence of true Lead lies in the qi of the two eights as its origin; all else is not the supreme Dao, and efforts spent are wasted. The *Yimen Pomi Ge* states: "Solitude and widowhood are not the Way; yin and yang lose their fundamental principle." Master Wang Zhen said: "Disciples eager to forsake wives and concubines forget that non-action achieves all." Gao Xiangxian said: "Either yang alone with a widowed wife, or yin alone in solitary rest." These all speak of cultivating yin in isolation or yang in solitude, refining but a single element. Yet some, misunderstanding, cling to this notion and practice bedchamber arts of controlling women, slandering the immortal Dao—where lies the fault? They fail to grasp that the analogy of yang as husband and yin as wife refers not to mundane spouses.

The *Pomi Ge* says: "Fasting is not the Way; after death, one becomes a hungry ghost." All the aforementioned—postnatal substances born of heaven and earth, coarse dregs—are easily encountered yet difficult to perfect. How can they compare to the Golden Elixir’s great medicine?

Annotation: Practices like fasting, breath-work, and visualization are misguided paths followed by commoners and lay practitioners who misinterpret the phrase "forsaking one’s wife." Many mistake the arts of exploring yin for the Golden Elixir. Why not thoroughly study the *Pomi Ge* of the Great White Immortal?
*"Breath-work is not the Way;*
*Saliva is not divine water.*
*Visualization is not the Way;*
*Painting cakes cannot serve as food.*
*Exploring yin is not the Way;*
*Essence exhausted, life follows in death.*
*Abstaining from salt is not the Way;*
*Food loses its savor.*
*Grain avoidance is not the Way;*
*Hunger and weakness harm spleen and stomach.*
*Forsaking one’s wife is not the Way;*
*Yin and yang lose their proper place.*
*What then is truly the Way?*
*The Supreme Unity harbors true qi,*
*Qi intermingling yet not intermingling,*
*Ascending and descending in emulation of heaven and earth.*
*Two substances unite in harmony,*
*Arising from the primordial beginning.*
*Girl and boy, matched in pairing,*
*Complete the perfect balance.*
*These are true yin and yang,*
*Husband and wife sharing one principle.*
*Thus, no need to forsake;*
*How can solitary yang accomplish anything?*
*To emerge as a Golden Immortal,*
*The Golden Elixir is not easily attained.*
*Scholars do not speak of truth,*
*The Great Cavern conceals profound meaning.*
*The Five Phases do not move in sequence;*
*The tiger is born within water.*
*The Five Phases reverse their course;*
*The dragon emerges from fire.*
*These words are truly sublime,*
*Manifesting the power of the Supreme Unity."*

The immortal elder’s regulated verse fundamentally derives from this. The *Yimen Pomi Ge* states:
*"The Supreme Unity contains true qi,*
*The dragon is born within fire,*
*The tiger arises from water,*
*Yin and yang know inversion,*
*Originating from the primordial beginning.*
*The Five Phases do not move in sequence,*
*Yet harmonize with heaven and earth."*
Even the meaning of forsaking one’s wife is not as clearly expressed as in the *Taiyi Ge*. Since people do not understand the inversion of the Five Phases, how can they comprehend that true yin and yang require no forsaking? Those who study immortality, unable to fully grasp the titles of immortal texts, how can they thoroughly ponder and integrate their principles? Thus, the great Way of the Golden Elixir has faded with time, texts lost, nature dimmed, and the Dao obscured. The misinterpretation of "forsaking one’s wife to sever yin and yang" has been distorted into mundane spouses, leading to licentious practices. Alas!

When the Elixir is complete and qi is full, one naturally abstains from grain—not like consuming black beans or sesame seeds to survive famine. Some consume medicines to avoid grain, seeking to endure worldly hardship; how can this achieve the state of a pure yang immortal? Others rely solely on herbs and plants; though they may attain longevity, they do not embody pure yang.

[Right] Admonishing the world, clarifying the great Dao, and refuting heterodox paths. This is Kongxuanzi’s classification.

To study immortality, one must study Heavenly Immortals;
Only the Golden Elixir is most authentic and auspicious.
When the two substances meet, nature and temperament unite;
Where the Five Phases are complete, dragon and tiger coil.
Originally through wu and ji as matchmakers,
Husband and wife are eternally joyful.
Awaiting only the completion of merit to ascend the imperial court,
Amidst ninefold radiance, riding a soaring simurgh.

Annotation: Immortals have several ranks. Those who are spiritually numinous yet formless are Ghost Immortals. Those who live in the world free from illness and vexation, enjoying eternal longevity, are Human Immortals. Those who fly through the air, walk through mist, endure neither hunger nor thirst, resist cold and heat, roam the seas and islands, and live forever without dying are Earthly Immortals. Those whose form and spirit are both wondrous, merging with the Dao, casting no shadow when stepping into sunlight, passing through metal and stone unimpeded, unharmed by water or fire, transforming endlessly, appearing old or young, hidden or manifest, existing or vanishing, condensing into qi or resting into form—whose depths the tortoise and diviner cannot fathom, and whose mysteries ghosts and spirits cannot know—are Heavenly Immortals.

Master Yin Zhenjun said: "Those who can abstain from desire, cultivate embryonic breathing, move the spirit into the husk, enter samadhi, and cast off the corpse, relying on yin transformation without decay, may become lower-grade immortals. Those who receive the talismans of the Six Jia, the Orthodox Unity, the Alliance of Might, the Upper Clarity, the Great Cavern Scriptures, or practice sword arts and corpse liberation, attaining the Dao, are established as Southern Palace Immortals, concealed in grotto-heavens, and become middle-grade immortals. Those who refine the Golden Elixir’s great medicine and attain the Dao, ascending bodily into the heavens, become the highest-grade Heavenly Immortals of the Limitless Upper Realm." Thus, the immortal elder encourages cultivators of truth to set their aspirations boldly, be resolute and unwavering, not settling for middle or lower immortals, but striving directly for the supreme nine-grade Heavenly Immortal.

As for the five metals, eight minerals, cinnabar, mercury, black lead, white tin, red lead, realgar, orpiment, arsenic, sublimed arsenic, verdigris, chalcanthite, autumn stone, herbal frost, water dregs, and refined substances—even one’s own saliva, essence, qi, blood, and fluids—all these are postnatal.

chunks.original_text: 是天地未分之前，混元真一之气，谓之无中生有。 圣人以法追摄於一个时辰内，结成一粒，大如黍米，号日金丹，又日真铅，又日阳丹，又日真一精，又日真一水，又日真水，又日水虎，又日太一含真气。 人得一粒饵之，立跻圣地，此乃天上之甲科，天仙之大道也，举世无知者。 真一之气，生於天地之○先，混於虚无之中，恍惚杳冥，视之不见，听之不闻，搏之不得，如之何凝结而成黍米哉。 圣人以实而形虚，以有而形无。 实而有者，真阴真阳也，同类无情之物也。 虚而无者，二八初弦之气也，有气而无质者也。 两者相形，一物生焉。 所谓一物者，真一之气，凝而为一黍之珠者也。 经曰：元始悬一宝珠，大如黍米，在空玄之中。 此其证也。 圣人恐泄天地之机，以真阴真阳取喻青龙白虎也，以两弦之气取喻真铅真汞也。 今仙翁於诗曲中，复以青龙之一物名日赤龙，曰震龙，日天魂、乾象、乾炉、玉鼎、玉液、扶桑、海龙、上弦、束阳、长男、赤汞、朱砂、朱砂鼎、离日、赤凤，已上无过比类青龙之一名也。 又以白虎之一物名日黑虎，日兑虎，日地魄、坤位、坤鼎、金鼎、金炉、华岳、岩虎、下弦、西川、少女、黑铅、偃月炉、坎月、黑龟，已上无过比类白虎一名也。 又以龙之弦气名日真汞，日诧女，日木液、青娥、砂裹汞、朱裹汞，日精，日情，日黄芽、流珠、青衣、女子、金乌、离女、牝龙、真火、二八媳女、玉液、玉芝之类，其实一也。 又以虎弦气名日真铅，日金公，日金精、水中金、水中银，日性，日白雪、素练、郎君、玉兔、坎男、真水、九三郎君、刀圭之类，其实一也。 此言二物会时情性合者，二物即龙虎也。 青龙在束，束方属木，木能生火，龙之弦气为火，日情，属南方，谓之朱雀也。 白虎在西，西方属金，金能生水，虎之弦气为水，日性，属北方，谓之玄武也。 夫龙木、虎金、情水、性火，谓之四象。 四象会合於中官而成丹者，土也。 此真五行也。 龙虎二物相交，则情性合矣。 龙虎合而成丹，则五行全矣。 故日二物会时情性合，五行全处虎龙蟠也。 木龙在束，金虎在西，二物问隔，孰能使之配合而为夫妻耶，配合在黄婆而已。 左手擒龙，右手捉虎，使之合并也。 戊己属土，故谓之黄婆。 金木问隔，黄婆能使之合并。 黄婆能使之配合，岂知非媒聘使之欢合而为夫妻乎。 两者异，真一之气藏。 两者同，真一之气变。 真一之气变，真人自出现，此外药之法象。 饵金丹后，复有十月之功，炼形成气。 又有九载抱一，化气成神。 方能形神俱妙，与道合真，膺录授图，上宾于天。 丹熟人问，道成天上。 九霞光裹，两腋风生，驾凤验鸾，翱翔碧落。 自非夙植灵根，广积阴惊，其孰能与於此哉。 陆子野曰：天仙非金丹不能成其道。 金丹是何物？ 曰：分明元是我家物，寄在坤官坤是人。 所言二物者何物也？ 我与彼也。 彼我会，则情性和而五行备。 龙虎，情性而已。 且道这会如何？ 会，所谓有用，用中无用。 无功，功裹施功。 竹密不妨流水过，山高岂碍白云飞。 戊己，乃中也。 中者，得其正位。 戊己者，意土也。 彼我之意相会，则夫妻之情惧悦而得矣。 所以戊己为生物之乡，生物系乎意也。
chunks.translated_text:
Before Heaven and Earth divided, there existed the primordial True Unity’s qi—this is called "something born from nothing." The sage, through method, gathers and condenses it within a single hour, forming a grain as large as a millet seed, called the Golden Elixir, also known as True Lead, Yang Elixir, True Unity’s Essence, True Unity’s Water, True Water, Water Tiger, or the Supreme Unity’s Containing True Qi. Should one ingest a single grain, one immediately ascends to the sacred realm—this is the celestial examination’s highest rank, the great Dao of Heavenly Immortals, unknown to the world.

The True Unity’s qi arises before Heaven and Earth, blending within the void’s emptiness, faint and indistinct, invisible to sight, inaudible to hearing, untouchable by grasp. How then is it condensed into a millet seed? The sage shapes the real through the empty, manifests the existent through the nonexistent. The real and existent are True Yin and True Yang—emotionless things of the same kind. The empty and nonexistent are the qi of the first crescent of the second and eighth months—possessing qi yet lacking form. When these two take shape, one thing is born. That one thing is the True Unity’s qi, congealed into a millet-seed pearl.

As the scripture says: *"In the beginning, a precious pearl hung, large as a millet seed, within the empty mystery."* This is its proof. Fearing the leakage of Heaven and Earth’s mechanism, the sage uses True Yin and True Yang to illustrate the Azure Dragon and White Tiger, and the qi of the two crescents to illustrate True Lead and True Mercury.

Now, in the immortal elder’s poetic verses, the Azure Dragon’s single entity is further named the Crimson Dragon, Thunder Dragon, Celestial Soul, Qian Image, Qian Crucible, Jade Tripod, Jade Fluid, Fusang, Sea Dragon, Upper Crescent, Eastern Yang, Eldest Son, Cinnabar Mercury, Cinnabar, Cinnabar Tripod, Li Sun, and Crimson Phoenix—all these are but metaphors for the Azure Dragon’s single name. The White Tiger’s single entity is further named the Black Tiger, Dui Tiger, Earthly Soul, Kun Position, Kun Tripod, Metal Tripod, Metal Crucible, Hua Peak, Cliff Tiger, Lower Crescent, Western River, Youngest Daughter, Black Lead, Crescent Moon Crucible, Kan Moon, and Black Tortoise—all these are but metaphors for the White Tiger’s single name.

The Azure Dragon’s crescent qi is called True Mercury, Maiden of Wonder, Wood Fluid, Green Maiden, Mercury within Cinnabar, Mercury within Vermilion, Essence, Emotion, Yellow Sprout, Flowing Pearl, Green Robe, Maiden, Golden Crow, Li Maiden, Female Dragon, True Fire, Maiden of the Second and Eighth Months, Jade Fluid, and Jade Mushroom—yet in truth, it is one. The White Tiger’s crescent qi is called True Lead, Metal Duke, Metal Essence, Gold within Water, Silver within Water, Nature, White Snow, White Silk, Young Gentleman, Jade Hare, Kan Son, True Water, Ninth Third Gentleman, and Knife’s Edge—yet in truth, it is one.

This speaks of the union of the two things when emotion and nature harmonize—the two things being Dragon and Tiger. The Azure Dragon resides in the East; the East pertains to Wood, which generates Fire. The Dragon’s crescent qi is Fire, called Emotion, belonging to the South, known as the Vermilion Bird. The White Tiger resides in the West; the West pertains to Metal, which generates Water. The Tiger’s crescent qi is Water, called Nature, belonging to the North, known as the Dark Warrior.

Dragon-Wood, Tiger-Metal, Emotion-Water, Nature-Fire—these are the Four Symbols. When the Four Symbols converge at the Central Palace to form the Elixir, it is Earth. These are the true Five Phases. When Dragon and Tiger unite, emotion and nature harmonize. When Dragon and Tiger merge to form the Elixir, the Five Phases are complete. Thus it is said: *"When the two things meet, emotion and nature harmonize; where the Five Phases are complete, Dragon and Tiger coil."*

The Wood Dragon in the East and the Metal Tiger in the West are separated—who can make them a pair, husband and wife? Their union depends on the Yellow Dame alone. With the left hand seizing the Dragon and the right hand grasping the Tiger, she makes them merge. Wu and Ji pertain to Earth, hence she is called the Yellow Dame. Though Metal and Wood are separated, the Yellow Dame enables their union. If she can make them pair, is she not the matchmaker who brings joyful union as husband and wife?

When the two are distinct, the True Unity’s qi is concealed. When the two are one, the True Unity’s qi transforms. When the True Unity’s qi transforms, the True Person naturally appears—this is the outer medicine’s symbolic method. After ingesting the Golden Elixir, there follows ten months of refining form into qi. Then, nine years of embracing the One, transforming qi into spirit. Only then can form and spirit both attain perfection, merging with the Dao in truth, receiving records and charts, and ascending as a guest to Heaven.

When the Elixir ripens in the human realm, the Dao is accomplished in the celestial. Enveloped in ninefold rosy clouds, winds arise beneath both armpits, and one rides phoenix and simurgh, soaring through the azure vault. Without prior planting of spiritual roots or amassing of hidden merits, who could attain this?

Lu Ziye said: *"Without the Golden Elixir, the Heavenly Immortal’s Dao cannot be fulfilled."* What is the Golden Elixir? It is clearly one’s own family’s treasure, lodged within the Kun Palace—Kun is the human. What are the two things? Myself and the other. When the other and I meet, emotion and nature harmonize, and the Five Phases are complete. Dragon and Tiger are but emotion and nature. How then does this meeting occur? The meeting is the so-called *"useful within the useless, effort within effortlessness."* *"Dense bamboo does not hinder flowing water; high mountains do not obstruct drifting clouds."*

Wu and Ji are the Center. The Center is the proper position. Wu and Ji are the Earth of Intent. When the intent of the other and myself meet, the joy of husband and wife is attained. Thus Wu and Ji are the homeland of living things, for life depends on intent.

chunks.original_text: 真土无位，真意无形，神哉神哉。 疏曰：《传道集》云：仙非一也，纯阴而无阳者，鬼也。 纯阳而无阴者，仙也。 阴阳相杂者，人也。 惟人者，可以鬼，可以仙。 仙有五等：鬼仙者，阴中超脱，神像不明，鬼关无姓，三山无名，虽不轮回，又难返蓬瀛，终无所归，止於投胎夺舍。 盖以神识内守，一心不散，意中以出阴神，乃清灵之鬼，非纯阳之仙。 以其一志，阴灵不散，故日鬼仙。 崇释之徒，用功至此，乃曰得道，诚可笑也。 人仙者，不能全於大道，止於一法一衍，功能安乐延年。 地仙者，法天地升降之理，取日月生成之数，身中用年月，日中用时刻，识龙虎配坎离，五行颠倒，气传子母，液行夫妇，三田返覆，烧成丹药，永镇下田，炼形住世，长生不死，以作陆地神仙。 神仙者，以地仙厌居尘世，用功不已，炼形成象，五气朝元，三阳聚顶，功满忘形，胎仙自化，阴尽阳纯，身外有身，脱质升仙，超几入圣，谢绝尘世，以返三山。 天仙者，厌居三岛，而传道人问，功行满足十界。 之，质，一阳天为无形而为丹道上有功，人问有行，受天书以返洞天，升於八又升於三清灵元自然之有中生有者，以有形之物变化而成也。 其始有形矣无中生有，取而服之，无质而质，质生则能化有形为无形，化后天气为先天气盖无质者，真一之气也，虎之中，纯一无伪，人能知其机而盗则可以诱真一之气服之一粒，非无为无作立跻圣域者？ 此也。 枯坐独修几火几药而能成者也。 本一物也，物之中，各含阴阳而成四象为一而土在其中，为真五行。 合为一未合，，返其本源，此金丹也。 则各藏真一之气寓於物。 物既同，则交真一之气，《商岩口授经》二物者工夫到日鲜莹洁白下工夫，则目现心悟安能化有形形神俱妙。 寓於真龙真使之凝结生分为二物，二四象合五行二物始为丹。 傅若坚心静定灵光如月即虚室生白也。 须见日轮红光涌出再持守则白光灭矣。 此二物得了，即丹基欲结。 此法真中妙更真，都绿我独异於人。 自知颠倒由离坎，谁识浮沉定主宾。 金鼎欲留朱裹汞，玉池先下水中银。 神功运火非终旦，现出深潭日一轮。 注曰：此道至圣至神，至贵至尊，至简至易，玄中之玄，妙中之妙？ 举世罕闻。 仙翁出乎其类，技乎其萃，独得深旨。 故冲熙翁曰：金丹大道，举世道人无所许可，惟平叔一人而已。 泰山也，河海也，丘埋行潦何敢冀焉。 离 ，属火为阳而居南，所反为女者，外阳而内阴也，谓之真汞。 坎 ，为阴而居北，所以反为男者，外阴而内阳也，谓之真铅。 故仙翁曰：日居离位反为女，坎配蟾官却是男。 不会个中颠倒意，休将管见事高谈。 此言坎之男、离之女，犹父之精、母之血也。 日之乌、月之兔也，砂之汞、铅之银也，天之玄、地之黄也，此数者皆指示龙虎初弦二气也。 主宾者，阳尊高居左日主，阴位低下居右日宾。 夫离为火，火炎上，火乃木之性，俱浮，属阳，故为主也。 坎为水，水润下，水为金之性，俱沉，属阴，故为宾也。 此常道也。 今也离反为女，坎反为男，是主反为宾也。 宾反为主，岂非颠倒乎，故日自知颠倒由离坎，谁识浮况定主宾。 定主宾者，盖道中取二弦之气，颠倒之主宾，不取常道主宾，故日定主宾也。
