The True Earth has no position; the True Intent has no form—how wondrous, how wondrous!

The *Commentary* states: As the *Anthology of the Transmitted Dao* says, immortality is not singular. Those purely yin without yang are ghosts. Those purely yang without yin are immortals. Those with both yin and yang intermingled are humans. Only humans may become ghosts or immortals. Immortals are of five ranks:

**Ghost Immortals** transcend within yin, their spirit-images unclear, nameless at the Ghost Pass, unrecorded in the Three Mountains. Though they escape the wheel of rebirth, they struggle to return to Penglai and Yingzhou, finding no ultimate refuge, only the cycle of possessing bodies and seizing vessels. For their spirit-awareness turns inward, their single mind undispersed, and from their intent emerges a yin spirit—a luminous ghost, not a purely yang immortal. By their unwavering will, their yin spirit remains undissipated, hence they are called Ghost Immortals. The followers of Śramaṇa who cultivate to this point claim to have attained the Dao—how laughable!

**Human Immortals** cannot fully embody the Great Dao, mastering only a single method or branch. Their practice grants peace, joy, and extended years.

**Earth Immortals** emulate the ascending and descending principles of Heaven and Earth, harnessing the generative numbers of the Sun and Moon. Within the body, they employ years and months; within the day, they employ hours and moments. They recognize the Dragon and Tiger as the pairing of Kan and Li, invert the Five Phases, transmit qi between mother and child, circulate essence between husband and wife, reverse the Three Fields, and refine the elixir. This elixir, eternally lodged in the Lower Field, forges the body to dwell in the world, achieving undying life as a terrestrial immortal.

**Divine Immortals**, weary of dwelling in the dusty world, persist in their practice, refining form into image. The Five Qi ascend to the origin; the Three Yang gather at the crown. When merit is fulfilled and form forgotten, the Embryonic Immortal naturally transforms. Yin is exhausted, yang made pure; a body exists beyond the body. Shedding their form, they ascend as immortals, transcending the subtle to enter sagehood, bidding farewell to the mortal realm to return to the Three Mountains.

**Celestial Immortals**, disdaining the Three Isles, transmit the Dao to humanity. When their merit and conduct fulfill the Ten Realms, their form—a yang within Heaven—becomes formless, achieving the highest attainment in the alchemy of the Elixir. With merit in the world and virtue among people, they receive the Heavenly Scriptures and return to the Grotto-Heavens, ascending to the Eight and then to the Three Clarities. The numinous origin’s "being within non-being" arises from transforming the formed into the formless. At first, there is form; then, "non-being generates being." Taking and ingesting it, the formless becomes form. Once form arises, it can transform the formed into the formless, converting postcelestial qi into precelestial qi. For the formless is the True Unity’s qi, pure and unadulterated within the Tiger. One who knows its mechanism and steals it may entice the True Unity’s qi to ingest a single grain—is this not the effortless attainment of sagehood? Yet how many can achieve this through mere seated meditation, tending the fire and refining the medicine?

In essence, it is one thing. Within this thing, yin and yang intermingle to form the Four Images, which unite as one—Earth at their center, constituting the True Five Phases. When united, they return to their root; when ununited, each harbors the True Unity’s qi within. Since the things are the same, the True Unity’s qi intermingles. As the *Oral Instructions of Shangyan* states: "The two things—when the work is perfected, they appear fresh, lustrous, and white. With effort, the eyes perceive and the heart awakens; how can the formed be transformed and form and spirit both attain subtlety?"

The True Dragon and True Tiger’s qi congeals and generates, dividing into two things. The Four Images and Five Phases unite—only then do the two things become the Elixir. If the heart is steadfast and the mind serene, the numinous radiance shines like the moon—this is the empty chamber generating brightness. One must witness the solar orb’s crimson light surging forth; with continued refinement, the white light vanishes. When these two things are obtained, the foundation of the Elixir is laid.

This method is true within the true, wondrous beyond compare. Only I alone differ from others in knowing this. Who else recognizes the inversion of Li and Kan, the settling of floating and sinking to determine host and guest?

The Golden Crucible seeks to retain cinnabar-wrapped mercury;
The Jade Pool first receives silver within water.
The divine work of tending the fire is not a full day’s labor—
From the deep pool, a single solar orb emerges.

The *Annotation* states: This Dao is most sacred, most wondrous, most noble, most exalted, most simple, most easy—mysterious within the mysterious, wondrous within the wondrous. Rarely is it heard in the world. The Immortal Elder stands above his kind, excelling beyond his peers, uniquely grasping its profound purport. Thus, Master Chongxi said: "Of the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir, none among the world’s Daoists are worthy—only Pingshu alone." He is Mount Tai, the rivers and seas; how dare the hills and puddles aspire to compare?

Li, associated with fire, is yang and resides in the south. Yet it is reversed to become female, outwardly yang but inwardly yin—this is True Mercury. Kan, associated with water, is yin and resides in the north. Yet it is reversed to become male, outwardly yin but inwardly yang—this is True Lead. Thus, the Immortal Elder said:
*"The sun dwells in Li’s position yet becomes female;
Kan pairs with the Toad Palace yet is male.
If you fail to grasp this inversion,
Do not presume to discuss such lofty matters with shallow insight."*

This speaks of Kan’s male and Li’s female as a father’s essence and mother’s blood, the sun’s crow and moon’s hare, cinnabar’s mercury and lead’s silver, Heaven’s mystery and Earth’s yellow. All these point to the Dragon and Tiger’s initial and crescent qi.

Host and guest: yang is noble, high, and resides on the left—this is the host. Yin is lowly and resides on the right—this is the guest. Li is fire, which flames upward; fire’s nature is wood, both floating and yang—hence it is the host. Kan is water, which moistens downward; water’s nature is metal, both sinking and yin—hence it is the guest. This is the ordinary Dao.

Yet now, Li is reversed to become female, and Kan is reversed to become male—thus the host becomes the guest, and the guest becomes the host. Is this not inversion? Hence it is said: *"Only I know the inversion arises from Li and Kan; who recognizes the settling of floating and sinking to determine host and guest?"* Determining host and guest means that within the Dao, one takes the crescent qi and inverts host and guest, not adhering to the ordinary Dao’s host and guest. Thus, it is called "determining host and guest."

chunks.original_text: 人人自有长生药，自是愚痴枉把抛。 甘露降时天地合，黄芽生处坎离交。 井蛙应谓无龙窟，篱鹦争知有凤巢。 金鼎者，金为阴物，鼎中有火之气，是阴中有阳之象，白虎是也。 玉池者，玉为阳物，池中有水之气，是阳中有阴之象，青龙是也。 砂中汞者，龙之弦气也。 水中银者，虎之弦气也。 修丹之士，若欲以虎留恋龙之气，又先驱龙就虎，然后二物氤氲，两情交合，施功煅炼，自然凝结真一之精也。 火即二弦之气也。 旦者，一昼之首，子为六阳之元，故日日一也。 圣人运动丹火，有神妙之功，不半时中，立得真一之精，一粒如黍，现於北海之中，赫然光透帘帏，若深潭现出一轮之红日也。 非终旦者，明一时辰中金丹之成也，此药之法象也。 疏曰：坎男离女、日乌月兔、天玄地黄，金阴之鼎有火焉，玉阳之池有水焉。 主反为宾，宾反为主，皆是阴中取阳，阳中取阴也。 颠倒五行逆修，以至於太极。 太极者，先天未判之气也。 金丹之结阳也，火非世问之几火也，二弦之气皆火也。 二弦者，其初也有气而无质，其源也至清而无浊，在年为二八月阴阳之平，在月为上下弦金水之半。 上阳子陈政虚曰：妙之一字，夫谁肯信。 异於人者，世人迷於爱欲之中，我却於爱欲之中，而有分别。 何谓分别，圣人以离坎颠倒而用之，谓之火上水下，以乾坤颠倒而用之，谓之地在天上。 以夫妇颠倒而用之，谓男下女上。 浮沉者，火炎木浮而在上为主，水降金沉而在下为宾。 此乃人之道，此为世问法也，此为顺五行也。 今焉火木虽浮，使之就下而反为宾。 金水须沉，使之逆上而反为主。 是之谓仙道也，是出世问法也，是为水火既济也，是为颠倒五行也。 金鼎玉池，道光所注不出颠倒之机，而反失於欲留先下之义。 子野以金鼎喻彼此，却合紫阳翁之意，何哉？ 绿自己之精气血液者，朱裹汞也，不可令其走逸，故云欲留彼此之华也。 灵池丹井丹泉者，水中银也，即先天一点真气，故云先下又欲留者，但令其住而不令其去，要取人而不失於己。 先下者，彼到而我待之，铅至而汞迎之，坎动则离受之。 金丹之道，先要得此欲留先下四字之旨。 运火非旦者，叉得其温和而运之。 故《参同契》云：发火初温微，亦如爻动时。 纯阳翁云：中宵漏永温温，铅鼎光透帘帏。 盖万物生化之初，其受阴阳之气只霎时中。 况此上仙之道，其炼先天之气，又为迅速。 故佛云：如露亦如电者，谓其至精至微而甚功疾，为不可久矣。 久则有损，而亏神功。 若得此先天真铅，归于悬胎室内，岂非深潭之现红日也。 人人自有长生药，自是愚痴枉把抛。 甘露降时天地合，黄芽生处坎离交。 井蛙应谓无龙窟，篱钨争知有凤巢。 丹熟自然金满屋，何须寻草学烧茅。 注曰：甘露、黄芽，皆金丹异名也。 天地、坎离，皆龙虎之象也。 天地之气氤氲，甘露自降。 坎离之气交并，黄芽自生。 龙虎二弦之道交接，真一之气自结。 此般至宝，家家自有，以其太近，故轻而弃之，殊不知此乃升天之灵梯也。 近世学者多执傍门非类，孤阴寡阳，有中生有，易遇难成等法，而自误其身，不知斯道简而易成者，有如井底之蛙，篱问之雀，安知有龙窟凤巢也。 黍粒之珠既悬，天地之金可掬。
chunks.translated_text:
Every person possesses the elixir of immortality,
Yet fools, in their ignorance, cast it recklessly aside.
When sweet dew descends, heaven and earth unite;
Where the yellow sprout arises, Kan and Li converge.

The well-frog claims no dragon’s cave exists,
The hedge-sparrow disputes the phoenix’s nest.
The golden crucible: gold is a yin substance,
Yet within the crucible lies the qi of fire—
An image of yang within yin, the White Tiger.
The jade pool: jade is a yang substance,
Yet within the pool lies the qi of water—
An image of yin within yang, the Green Dragon.
Mercury within cinnabar is the crescent qi of the Dragon;
Silver within water is the crescent qi of the Tiger.

For those who refine the elixir,
If one wishes to entice the Tiger’s qi to linger with the Dragon,
First drive the Dragon to the Tiger,
Then let the two substances intermingle,
Their essences conjoined in mutual embrace.
Apply the firing process, and naturally,
The true essence of the One coalesces.
Fire is the crescent qi of the two.
"Dawn" marks the beginning of the day,
And *zi* is the origin of the six yang—
Thus, "daily one."

The sage moves the elixir fire with divine skill,
And in less than half an hour,
Attains the true essence of the One—
A grain like millet appearing in the Northern Sea,
Radiant light piercing through curtains,
Like the red sun emerging from a deep pool.
"Not the entire dawn" signifies the elixir’s completion within a single hour—
Such is the symbolic method of this medicine.

The commentary states:
Kan as male, Li as female;
The sun’s crow, the moon’s hare;
Heaven’s mystery, earth’s yellow.
The golden crucible of yin contains fire,
The jade pool of yang contains water.
Host becomes guest, guest becomes host—
All is the extraction of yang from yin,
The extraction of yin from yang.
Inverting the Five Phases to cultivate in reverse,
One reaches the Supreme Ultimate.
The Supreme Ultimate is the primordial, undifferentiated qi.

The coagulation of the golden elixir is yang,
Yet its fire is not the common flame of the world—
The crescent qi of the two is fire.
The two crescents: at their inception, they are qi without form;
At their source, they are utterly pure, without turbidity.
In the year, they are the balance of yin and yang in the second and eighth months;
In the month, they are the waxing and waning of metal and water at the half-moons.

Master Shangyang, Chen Zhengxu, said:
*"The word ‘wondrous’—who would believe it?"*
Different from others:
While the world is lost in the snares of desire,
I discern within desire itself.
What is this discernment?
The sage employs Li and Kan in inversion—
This is called "fire above, water below."
He employs Qian and Kun in inversion—
This is called "earth above, heaven below."
He employs husband and wife in inversion—
This is called "male below, female above."

Floating and sinking:
Fire flames upward, wood floats above—host;
Water descends, metal sinks below—guest.
This is the human Dao, the worldly method,
The alignment with the Five Phases.
Yet now, though fire and wood float,
They are made to descend and become guest.
Though metal and water should sink,
They are made to ascend and become host.
This is the immortal’s Dao, the otherworldly method,
The completion of water and fire,
The inversion of the Five Phases.

The golden crucible and jade pool,
The radiance of the Dao shines upon the mechanism of inversion—
To lose the meaning of "desiring to retain, first descending" is to err.
Ziye likened the golden crucible to mutuality,
Thereby aligning with Master Ziyang’s intent—how so?
For one’s own essence, qi, blood, and fluids—
This is the cinnabar-clad mercury,
Which must not be allowed to escape.
Thus, it is said: *"Desire to retain the essence of both."*

The numinous pool, elixir well, and cinnabar spring—
This is the silver within water,
The primordial, true qi of the One.
Thus, *"first descending, then desiring to retain"* means
Allowing it to stay without letting it depart,
Seeking to take from the other without losing one’s own.
"First descending" means awaiting the other’s arrival,
Mercury welcoming lead,
Li receiving when Kan moves.

The Dao of the golden elixir first requires grasping
The purport of these four words: *"desiring to retain, first descending."*
The firing process is not confined to dawn—
One must apply gentle warmth.
Thus, the *Cantong Qi* states:
*"The initial firing is gentle and mild,
Like the stirring of a hexagram."*
Master Pure Yang said:
*"In the deep of night, the clepsydra’s waters flow warm,
The lead crucible’s light pierces through curtains."*

For all things, at the inception of generation,
They receive the qi of yin and yang in but a fleeting moment.
How much more so for this Dao of supreme immortality—
The refinement of primordial qi is swift indeed.
Thus, the Buddha said:
*"Like dew, like lightning"*—
Speaking of its utmost subtlety and rapid efficacy,
For it cannot endure long.
Prolonged effort brings harm,
Diminishing the divine work.

If one obtains this primordial true lead
And returns it to the suspended womb chamber,
Is this not like the red sun appearing in a deep pool?

Every person possesses the elixir of immortality,
Yet fools, in their ignorance, cast it recklessly aside.
When sweet dew descends, heaven and earth unite;
Where the yellow sprout arises, Kan and Li converge.
The well-frog claims no dragon’s cave exists,
The hedge-sparrow disputes the phoenix’s nest.
When the elixir ripens, gold naturally fills the house—
Why seek herbs to burn as straw?

The annotation states:
Sweet dew and yellow sprout are alternate names for the golden elixir.
Heaven and earth, Kan and Li, are symbols of Dragon and Tiger.
When the qi of heaven and earth intermingle, sweet dew descends of itself.
When the qi of Kan and Li converge, the yellow sprout arises of itself.
When the Dao of Dragon and Tiger’s two crescents unite,
The true qi of the One coalesces of itself.
This supreme treasure exists in every household,
Yet because it is too near, it is slighted and discarded—
Little do they know it is the divine ladder to ascension.

Modern scholars cling to heterodox paths:
Lone yin, solitary yang,
Something born from something,
Methods easy to encounter yet hard to complete—
They delude themselves,
Unaware that this Dao is simple and easily achieved.
Like the frog at the bottom of the well,
The sparrow amid the hedge,
How could they know of the dragon’s cave or phoenix’s nest?
Once the millet-grain pearl is suspended,
The gold of heaven and earth may be scooped up.

Hence it is said: *"Only I know the inversion arises from Li and Kan; who recognizes the settling of floating and sinking to determine host and guest?"* Determining host and guest means that within the Dao, one takes the crescent qi and inverts host and guest, not adhering to the ordinary Dao’s host and guest. Thus, it is called "determining host and guest."

chunks.original_text: 昔邵刚中精於黄白之卫，世号为小淮南王，后遇仙翁韩子陶法师於水上，北面事之，出汞金百镒献陶以为质，陶笑而不顾，邵敌血书盟，陶遂授道焉。 既竟，陶取汞一掬入口漱之，吐於水盆中，水　为之涌沸，沸定，成紫金一探，此示其内丹大药有如此之神妙，岂待穷年卒岁，弄草烧茅之辈可得而见之乎。 经文不日地藏发泄，金玉露形，又其证也。 疏曰：吕纯阳以土瓦石为金，南唐耿仙姑捏雪成银，陈泥丸含汞立乾。 《传道集》云：口中可以乾汞，皆熟之验。 右外药。 虎跃龙腾风浪厅，中央正位产玄珠。 果生枝上终期熟，子在胞中岂有殊。 南北宗源翻卦象，晨昏火候合天枢。 须知大隐居尘市，何必深山守静孤。 注曰：此诗言内药之法象也。 夫真一之精，造化在外日金丹，又日真土。 吞入己腹中即名真铅，又名阳丹。 此言虎，即金丹也。 龙者，我之真气也。 我之真气，自气海而上，其涌如浪，其动如风也。 中央正位者，即丹田中金胎神室也，乃丹结聚之处。 玄珠者，运火之际，真精自然运转，沿尾问直透夹脊，上冲泥丸室，颗颗降下口中，状若雀卯，甘香无比，号曰玄珠。 咽下丹田名日婴兄，又日金液还丹也。 夫黍珠之丹，是先天地之气，即真一之精结成，为母、为君、为铅，故《金钥匙》谓之黑铅也，又谓之水虎也。 己之真气，后天地生，为子、为臣、为汞，故《金钥匙》谓之红铅也，又谓之火龙也。 金丹自外来，吞入腹中，则己之真气，自下元气海而上涌，如风浪翕然而奏。 丹若臣之於君，子之於母，其相与之意可知也。 龙虎相交在神室，土釜之中受火符，运育结成圣胎，若果之叉熟，儿之铃生。 十月功圆，脱胎神化无方也。 南北者，子午时也。 宗源者，起首之初也。 晨昏者，昼夜之首也。 子为六阳之首，故为晨用屯卦直事，进火之侯也。 午为六阴之元，故为昏用蒙卦直事，进水之侯也。 一日两卦直事，至三十日终，为既济未济，二卦终而复始，循环不已，故日翻卦象也。 《参同契》云：朔旦屯直事，至暮蒙当受，昼夜各一卦，用之须依次。 既未至晦爽，终则复更始是也。 一日两卦主事，并牝牡四卦，一月计六十四卦，计三百八十四爻，应一年并闰余之数。 乾之t初九起於坤之初六，乾之策三十有六爻，计二百一十六。 坤之初六起於乾之初九，坤之策二十有四，爻计一百四十有四。 总而计之三百六十，应周天之数。 日月行度、交合、升降，不出於卦爻之内。 月行速一月一周天，日行迟一年一周天。 枢天者，斗建之极也，一昼夜一＇周天，一月一移也。 如正月建寅，二月建卯是也。 且如正月建寅，如太阳未过官分，以寅加亥，至酉建子，正月斗建临子正酉时也。 如太阳已过官分，以寅加戌，至寅建午，正月斗建临午正寅时也。 上士至人，明阴阳上下J知日月盈亏，行子午火符，日有昼夜？ 数月应时加喊，然后时合天度，一一依斗建而运之，故日合天枢也，6天枢即斗极也。 《夷门歌》曰：十二门中天，一作月建移。 刻漏依时逐，旋布此其旨也。 至道之妙，妙在於斯。 坎离升降，生产灵药，结成黄芽。 别本云：且如正月建寅，立春戌时指艮，雨水戌时指寅。 故曰：月月常加戌，时时见破军。
chunks.translated_text:
In former times, Shao Gangzhong was deeply versed in the arts of the Yellow and White, and the world styled him the "Lesser King of Huainan." Later, he encountered the immortal elder Master Han Zitao by the waterside, and, facing north, became his disciple. He presented a hundred *yi* of cinnabar and gold to Tao as a pledge, but Tao merely laughed and paid no heed. Shao then cut his arm and swore a blood oath, whereupon Tao at last transmitted the Dao to him.

When the transmission was complete, Tao took a handful of mercury, rinsed his mouth with it, and spat it into a basin of water. The water surged and boiled, and when the bubbling subsided, it had transformed into a lump of purple gold. This demonstrated the wondrous efficacy of the Great Elixir of Internal Alchemy—how could those who toil year after year, tinkering with herbs and burning thatch, ever hope to witness such a thing? The scriptures do not speak in vain of "Earth’s Treasury laid bare, gold and jade revealed in their true form"—this is further proof.

The commentary states: Lü Chunyang turned tiles and stones into gold; the Lady Immortal Geng of Southern Tang molded snow into silver; Chen Niuwan dried mercury in his mouth in an instant. The *Transmission of the Dao Collection* says: "Mercury may be dried in the mouth"—all these are signs of mastery.

**External Medicine**

Tiger leaps, dragon soars—wind and waves surge in the hall,
At the central true position, the Mysterious Pearl is born.
Though the fruit ripens on the branch in its due season,
How is the child in the womb any different?

North and South trace their source to the trigrams’ turning,
Dawn and dusk’s fire-timing aligns with the Celestial Pivot.
Know that the great hermit dwells amid the dusty world—
Why seek seclusion in the deep mountains, guarding solitude alone?

The annotation says: This poem speaks of the symbolic method of the Internal Medicine. The essence of the True One, the work of creation, is called the Golden Elixir when external, and True Earth. When swallowed into one’s belly, it is named True Lead, or Yang Elixir.

Here, the tiger refers to the Golden Elixir. The dragon is one’s true *qi*. One’s true *qi* rises from the Sea of Qi, surging like waves, stirring like wind. The "central true position" is the Golden Womb’s divine chamber within the Cinnabar Field, where the elixir coalesces. The Mysterious Pearl is the true essence that, during the firing process, naturally circulates, ascending from the *weilu* through the spine to the Mud Pill Palace, then descending into the mouth in droplets like sparrow’s eggs, incomparably sweet and fragrant. Swallowed into the Cinnabar Field, it is called the Infant Boy, or the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir.

The millet-grain pearl of the elixir is the *qi* prior to Heaven and Earth, the essence of the True One coalesced. It is the Mother, the Sovereign, the Lead—hence the *Golden Key* calls it Black Lead, or the Water Tiger. One’s true *qi*, born after Heaven and Earth, is the Child, the Minister, the Mercury—hence the *Golden Key* calls it Red Lead, or the Fire Dragon.

The Golden Elixir comes from without; when swallowed into the belly, one’s true *qi* surges upward from the lower Sea of Qi like wind and waves. The elixir, like a minister to the sovereign or a child to its mother, naturally responds. Dragon and tiger unite in the divine chamber, the earthen crucible receives the fire tally, and the Sacred Embryo is nurtured and formed—like fruit ripening on the branch, like a child born in the womb. After ten months of work, the embryo is perfected, and the spirit transforms without limit.

"North and South" refer to the hours of *zi* and *wu*. "Source" refers to the beginning. "Dawn and dusk" are the starts of day and night. *Zi* is the first of the six yang hours, hence dawn employs the *Zhun* hexagram to govern the firing time. *Wu* is the origin of the six yin hours, hence dusk employs the *Meng* hexagram to govern the watering time. Each day, two hexagrams govern the work, and after thirty days, the cycle ends with *Jiji* and *Weiji*, then begins anew, revolving without cease—hence it is called "turning the trigrams’ image."

The *Cantong Qi* says: "At dawn, *Zhun* governs the work; by dusk, *Meng* takes its turn. Day and night, each hexagram is used in sequence. From the first to the last day of the month, the cycle ends and begins again." Each day, two hexagrams govern the work, along with the four hexagrams of *Qian* and *Kun*, totaling sixty-four hexagrams and 384 lines in a month—corresponding to the days of a year, including intercalary months.

*Qian*’s first nine begins with *Kun*’s initial six. *Qian*’s thirty-six lines total 216. *Kun*’s initial six begins with *Qian*’s first nine, and *Kun*’s twenty-four lines total 144. Together, they sum to 360, matching the number of the celestial circuit. The movements of the sun and moon—their conjunctions, ascents, and descents—all unfold within the hexagrams and lines.

The moon moves swiftly, completing one circuit in a month; the sun moves slowly, completing one in a year. The "Celestial Pivot" is the pole of the Northern Dipper. In a day and night, it completes one circuit, shifting once a month. For example, the first month is aligned with *yin*, the second with *mao*. In the first month, when the sun has not yet passed the palace division, *yin* is placed over *hai*, and *zi* is established at *you*—thus, in the first month, the Dipper’s handle points to *zi* at the *you* hour. If the sun has passed the palace division, *yin* is placed over *xu*, and *wu* is established at *yin*—thus, in the first month, the Dipper’s handle points to *wu* at the *yin* hour.

The superior adept, the perfected one, understands the rise and fall of yin and yang, the waxing and waning of the sun and moon. They practice the *zi-wu* fire tally, day and night, counting the months and aligning with the seasons. Only then do their timings accord with the celestial degrees, following the Dipper’s movement in every detail—hence it is called "aligning with the Celestial Pivot." The Celestial Pivot is the Dipper’s pole.

The *Yimen Song* says: "Within the twelve gates of Heaven, one acts as the monthly establishment shifts. The water clock follows the time, rotating in sequence—this is its meaning." The subtlety of the supreme Dao lies herein. The ascent and descent of *Kan* and *Li* give birth to the numinous medicine, coalescing the Yellow Sprout.

Another version states: For example, in the first month aligned with *yin*, at the *xu* hour of the *Lichun* solar term, the handle points to *gen*; at the *xu* hour of the *Yushui* solar term, it points to *yin*. Thus it is said: "Each month, constantly add *xu*; at every hour, observe the Breaking Army."

chunks.original_text: 金丹大药，家家自有，不拘市朝。 奈何见龙不识龙，见虎不识虎。 逆而修之，几何人哉。 片饷之问，结一宝，珠大如黍米。 古诗曰：将来掌上霞光灿，吞入腹中官殿新。 又曰：大道隐朝市，山中知不知。 疏曰：金丹因先天之气结成，因人身后天之气而成变化。 风浪之涌，言一身之气与金丹际会也。 玄珠之产，言一身之气与金丹交结也。 日之子午，因日所历。 斗之子午，因初所指，其子午者，地之正方也。 穷而用之，与日斗同运，此乃真师口传。 日之所会则神聚，世谓之月将。 斗之所指则气动，世谓之月建。 时合天度，用日之子午，依斗建运用。 斗之子午，日有昼夜数分，子昼午夜，月应时加喊分，子生午亏。 南北者，以子午言。 晨昏者，亦以子午言。 自子至巳为晨，自午至亥为昏。 此仙道之晨昏，非世问日出没之晨昏也。 天呈又法交节气，以月建加亥交中气加戌，以推各时所指。 彭真人既为《参同契分章通真义》毕，因读五行颠倒不顺行四句，以为泄天地互用之机，分阴阳返复之道，遂迷黑铅水虎，论红铅火龙诀名日《还丹内象金箫匙》，其言虎之体、龙之用，皆论大丹造化。 今无名子借以分言内外二丹，但取其题，不取其文，虽非真一子迷作本旨，然其理亦通。 右内药。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之二 原文为『谷J，依文意改为『谷〕。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之三 象川无名子翁葆光注武夷陈达云传集庆空玄子戴起宗疏 黄芽白雪不难寻，达者须凭德行探。 四象五行全藉土，三元八卦岂离壬。 炼成灵质人难识，消尽阴魔鬼莫侵。 欲向人间留秘诀，未逢一个是知音。 注曰：龙之弦气日黄芽，虎之弦气日白雪，大药根源实基於此。 其道至简，其事非难。 若非丰功伟行，莫能遭遇真师指授玄要也。 盖谓大道肇自虚无生一气，一气生阴阳，日龙日虎。 龙木生火，虎金生水。 木火金水合成四象，四象合而成丹。 丹之成本於土，土无正位，分位四季。 四时不得四季之土，四序不行不能生成万物也。 是以四象五行全藉土也。 壬者，水也，即真一之气，号日真一水也。 生於天地之先，变而为阳龙、阴虎也。 龙虎合而成丹，丹土也，龙木也，虎金也，谓之三性三元，不离真一之水变也。 八卦者，真一之气，一变为天，日乾为父。 二变为地，日坤为母。 乾以阳气索坤之阴气，一索生长男，日震。 再索生中男，日坎。 三索生少男，日艮。 此乾气交於坤气，而生三男阳也。 及乎坤以阴气索阳之乾气，一索生长女，日巽。 再索生中女，日离。 三索生少女，日兑。 此坤之气交於乾气而生阴也。 亦不离真一之水变也，故日三元八卦岂离壬也。 非惟三元八卦不离真一之精，自开辟以来，几有形与名之类，莫不由此而成变化。 真一子曰：真一之精乃天地之母，阴阳之根，水火之本，日月之宗，三才之源，五行之祖。 万物类之以生成，千灵承之以舒惨。 至於高天厚地，洞府名山，玄象灵官，神仙圣众，风雨晦明，春夏秋冬，未兆之前，莫不由此，铅气产出而成变化者也。 修丹之士，得真一之水，万事毕矣。 真一之黍，吞归五内，运火十月，炼尽韦阴，化为纯阳真一之仙，阴魔尸鬼逃遁无门。 仙黄欲留秘旨於人问，未闻有知音者，大有径庭，不近人情故也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Great Elixir of Golden Cinnabar is possessed by every household, unbound by marketplace or court. Yet how many recognize the Dragon when they see it, or the Tiger when they behold it? Those who cultivate it in reverse—how few they are! In but a fleeting moment, a single treasure coalesces, a pearl as large as a grain of millet.

An ancient poem says:
*Placed upon the palm, its rosy glow dazzles;
Swallowed into the belly, the palace halls renew.*

Another verse declares:
*The Great Dao hides within the court and market—
Do those in the mountains know or not?*

A commentary explains: The Golden Cinnabar forms from the *qi* of Primordial Heaven, yet through the *qi* of the postnatal body, it undergoes transformation. The surging of wind and waves describes the meeting of the body’s *qi* with the Golden Elixir. The birth of the Mysterious Pearl speaks of the intertwining of the body’s *qi* with the Golden Elixir.

The *zi* and *wu* of the sun follow its daily course; the *zi* and *wu* of the Dipper stem from its initial pointing. These *zi* and *wu* mark the cardinal directions of Earth. When fully mastered and applied, they move in harmony with the sun and Dipper—this is the true oral transmission of the master.

Where the sun converges, spirit gathers—commonly called the "monthly general." Where the Dipper points, *qi* stirs—commonly called the "monthly establishment." Aligning with celestial degrees, one employs the sun’s *zi* and *wu*, following the Dipper’s movement in its operation.

The Dipper’s *zi* and *wu* divide day and night by degrees: *zi* governs day, *wu* governs night. The moon responds to the timely addition of *xu* degrees: *zi* generates, *wu* wanes. "South and north" refer to *zi* and *wu*; "dawn and dusk" likewise refer to *zi* and *wu*. From *zi* to *si* is dawn; from *wu* to *hai* is dusk. This is the immortals’ dawn and dusk, not the worldly dawn and dusk of sunrise and sunset.

Another method of celestial presentation: at the solar terms, the monthly establishment is added to *hai*, and at the midpoints, it is added to *xu*, to determine the Dipper’s pointing for each time.

After Master Peng completed *The True Meaning of the "Cantong Qi" Divided into Chapters*, he read the four lines on the inversion of the Five Phases and their non-sequential movement, perceiving them as revealing the mechanism of Heaven and Earth’s mutual operation and the Dao of yin-yang’s cyclical return. Thus, he became enamored with the Black Lead and Water Tiger, expounding upon the Red Lead and Fire Dragon in a text titled *The Golden Flute Key to the Inner Image of Returned Cinnabar*, wherein he discussed the Tiger’s essence and the Dragon’s function—all concerning the creation and transformation of the Great Elixir. Now, the Nameless One borrows this to distinguish between the inner and outer elixirs, adopting only its title, not its text. Though this diverges from the original intent of the True One, its principles remain coherent.

---

**Inner Medicine**

In the *Commentary and Annotations on Master Ziyang’s "Awakening to Reality"*, Volume Two (the character *gu* [谷] is amended here according to the text’s meaning), Volume Three:

The Yellow Sprout and White Snow are not hard to find—
The adept must seek them through virtue and conduct.
The Four Images and Five Phases rely entirely on Earth;
The Three Origins and Eight Trigrams—how could they leave *ren*?

Refined into a numinous essence, few recognize it;
Dissolving all yin demons, no ghost may invade.
Wishing to leave this secret formula among men—
Yet not one soul has proven a true confidant.

A note explains: The Dragon’s latent *qi* is called the Yellow Sprout; the Tiger’s latent *qi* is called the White Snow. The root of the Great Medicine truly lies herein. The Dao is utterly simple; the practice is not difficult. Yet without great merit and noble deeds, one cannot encounter a true master to transmit its mysteries.

The Great Dao originates from the Void, giving birth to the One *Qi*; the One *Qi* generates yin and yang, called Dragon and Tiger. The Dragon (Wood) engenders Fire; the Tiger (Metal) engenders Water. Wood, Fire, Metal, and Water combine to form the Four Images; the Four Images unite to form the Elixir. The Elixir’s formation depends on Earth, which has no fixed position but is distributed across the four seasons. Without Earth in the four seasons, the four phases cannot proceed, and the myriad things cannot be born and completed. Thus, the Four Images and Five Phases rely entirely on Earth.

*Ren* is Water, the *qi* of the True One, also called the True One Water. It arises before Heaven and Earth, transforming into the yang Dragon and yin Tiger. The Dragon and Tiger unite to form the Elixir—Earth. The Dragon is Wood; the Tiger is Metal. These are the Three Natures, the Three Origins, inseparable from the transformations of the True One Water.

The Eight Trigrams arise from the *qi* of the True One: first, it transforms into Heaven, called *Qian*, the Father. Second, it transforms into Earth, called *Kun*, the Mother. *Qian*, with its yang *qi*, seeks *Kun*’s yin *qi*: at the first seeking, it generates the Eldest Son, *Zhen*; at the second seeking, the Middle Son, *Kan*; at the third seeking, the Youngest Son, *Gen*—these are the three yang sons born of *Qian*’s *qi* uniting with *Kun*’s *qi*. Then, *Kun*, with its yin *qi*, seeks *Qian*’s yang *qi*: at the first seeking, it generates the Eldest Daughter, *Xun*; at the second seeking, the Middle Daughter, *Li*; at the third seeking, the Youngest Daughter, *Dui*—these are the three yin daughters born of *Kun*’s *qi* uniting with *Qian*’s *qi*. Neither do they depart from the transformations of the True One Water. Thus, it is said: *The Three Origins and Eight Trigrams—how could they leave ren?*

Not only do the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams not depart from the essence of the True One, but since the beginning of creation, all things with form and name have arisen and transformed through it. The True One says: The essence of the True One is the Mother of Heaven and Earth, the Root of Yin and Yang, the Origin of Water and Fire, the Ancestor of Sun and Moon, the Source of the Three Powers, and the Progenitor of the Five Phases. The myriad things rely on it for birth and completion; the thousand spirits depend on it for flourishing or withering. Even the vastness of Heaven and Earth, the grottoes and sacred mountains, the celestial bodies and numinous officials, the immortals and sages, wind and rain, darkness and light, spring and summer, autumn and winter—before any sign appears, all arise from it. The *qi* of Lead emerges and undergoes transformation.

The cultivator of the Elixir who obtains the True One Water has accomplished everything. Swallowing the True One’s grain into the five viscera and refining it with fire for ten months, all residual yin is purged, transmuting into a pure yang immortal of the True One. Yin demons and corpse-ghosts flee with no escape. The immortal wishes to leave this secret among men, yet no one has proven a true confidant—so vast is the gulf, so distant from human sentiment.

chunks.original_text: 盖善根种而灵骨锺，灵骨锺而仙可冀。 灵骨之锺、善根之种也，不於一生二生，而於无量万亿生中种诸善根，才出头来，飘飘然便有出尘气象。 噫！ 走骨行尸，一瓶一钵，便欲登仙，神仙中人不易得也，胡不扪己之心，与平几之心有以异乎，无以异乎。 我之仙事亦无涯也，铃也广大变通为己任，独高一世，鹤立鸡常，人笑我为迂疏，我知我非几俗。 赤精亦松乃吾友，蓬莱方丈乃吾家。 自然遭遇异人亲传至道，结合心友，一黍丹成。 仙翁欲向人问留此不传之秘旨，莫怪子期期不遇，怎生得个这般人。 疏曰：土者，言其会极之地。 壬者，言其生物之初。 真一之水，未成形之气也。 真一之黍，已成形之气也。 四象各怀真土，一四成五，二三成五，四象皆土也。 壬，水也，天一之所生壬在子先，为一阳之首。 壬在子先者，即亥末子初也。 生气之元，五行之先，故皆始於壬也。 真一子曰：真一之精，止成变化者也。 其文出《金钥匙》。 莫不因此铅汞产出，即真一之水壬也。 好把真铅着意寻，莫教容易度光阴。 但将地魄擒朱汞，自有天魂制水金。 可谓道高龙虎伏，堪言德重鬼神钦。 已知永寿齐天地，烦恼无由更上心。 注曰：真铅，即金丹也。 地魄，在外药则白虎是也，内药即金丹也。 天魂，在外药则青龙是也，内药即己身也。 朱汞者，在外龙之弦气也，在内已之真气也。 水金者，在外虎之弦气也，在内金丹也。 又谓之朱裹汞，水中银。 已上喻内外二事也。 仙翁勉修真之士，速修金丹以超生死，无虚度日也。 但将白虎擒龙，自有青龙制虎，二气捆缢以产金丹，既得金丹，复将此金丹吞入腹中，擒自己真气，其自己真气恋金丹而结圣胎也。 内之真龙既降，则世外之龙虎自伏。 内炼神魂鬼魄既圣，则世外之鬼神自钦。 非道隆德邵，其龙孰能与於此哉。 体化纯阳，寿齐天地，逍遥物外，自在人问，万念俱空，何烦恼之有。 陆子野曰：地魄乃铅，天魂乃汞，以铅制汞，在彼我耳。 休炼三黄及四神，若寻众草便非真。 阴阳得类方交感，二八相当自合亲。 潭底日红阴怪灭，山头月白药苗新。 时人要识真铅汞，不是凡砂及水银。 注曰：三黄四神，金石草木，皆后天地生，查滓之物，安能化有形而入於无形哉。 外内不可以成胎，缀花不可以结子。 真一之气，生於天地之先，杳杳冥冥，不可测度，因二八同类相当之物，合而成亲，捆缢交感之中，激而有象同类者，无情之情、不色之色，正谓乌肝八两、兔髓半斤是也。 此二八相当之同类，合而成亲，则真一之气归於交感穴中，凝成黍粒，斯道妙矣。 潭阴也，日阳也，潭底日红者，阴中之阳也。 阴中之阳为纯阳，而无阴气，故曰阴怪灭也。 乃是虎之弦气，谓之红铅。 山阳也，月阴也，山头月白者，阳中之阴也。 乃龙之弦气，初弦气故日药苗新，谓之黑铅。 铅作汞。 古歌曰：红铅黑汞大丹头，将红入黑是真修。 此之谓也。 圣人以此二物，於一时之中，造化成一粒阳丹。 在北海之中，赫然如日，光透帘幛，即时探吞入腹，点己阴汞，则一身阴邪之气悉皆消灭，亦如晓日初自束海而升，赫然照耀，阴怪悉消灭矣。 阴汞自下丹田，峰顶乍禀阳丹之气，渐渐凝结，萌芽新嫩，故药苗新也。

For those whose virtuous roots are sown and whose numinous bones are forged, the attainment of immortality may be hoped for. The forging of numinous bones and the sowing of virtuous roots do not occur in one or two lifetimes, but over countless billions of lives, wherein all manner of good roots are planted. Only then, upon emerging, does one float free with the bearing of one who has transcended the dust. Alas! Those who are but walking bones and moving corpses, clutching a single alms bowl and begging bowl, yet aspire to ascend as immortals—such men are not easily found among the ranks of the transcendent. Why not examine one’s own heart and compare it to the heart of the common man: is there a difference, or is there none?

My own immortal work knows no bounds; I take vast transformation and adaptability as my duty, standing alone above the world, like a crane among chickens. Though others laugh at me as impractical and eccentric, I know I am no mere mortal. The crimson essence of the pine is my friend; Penglai and Fangzhang are my home. Naturally, I have encountered extraordinary individuals who have transmitted the supreme Dao, forming bonds with kindred spirits. With a single grain of elixir, the work is complete.

The immortal elder wishes to leave this untransmitted secret among men, yet one cannot blame him for rarely encountering a true confidant—how could such a person be found? The commentary states: "Earth" refers to the place where all things converge. "Ren" signifies the inception of all life. The True One Water is the *qi* before form takes shape; the True One’s grain is the *qi* after form has arisen. The Four Symbols each harbor true earth; one and four make five, two and three make five—thus the Four Symbols are all earth. *Ren* is water, born of Heaven’s One. *Ren* stands at the forefront of *zi*, the first of the yang. *Ren* at the forefront of *zi* refers to the transition from *hai* to *zi*. It is the origin of generative *qi*, the first of the Five Phases, and thus all things begin with *ren*.

Master True One says: The essence of the True One alone brings about transformation. This passage comes from *The Golden Key*. All lead and mercury arise from it—this is the True One Water, *ren*. Diligently seek the true lead; do not let time slip by in vain. Simply capture the earthly *po* to subdue the cinnabar mercury, and the celestial *hun* will naturally restrain the watery metal. This may be called: the Dao is lofty, and dragons and tigers submit; the virtue is weighty, and ghosts and spirits revere. Once you know your life will be as enduring as Heaven and Earth, no vexations will ever trouble your heart again.

The annotation states: True lead is the golden elixir. The earthly *po*, in external medicine, is the White Tiger; in internal medicine, it is the golden elixir. The celestial *hun*, in external medicine, is the Green Dragon; in internal medicine, it is one’s own body. Cinnabar mercury, in external alchemy, is the coiled *qi* of the dragon; internally, it is one’s own true *qi*. Watery metal, in external alchemy, is the coiled *qi* of the tiger; internally, it is the golden elixir. It is also called mercury enveloped in cinnabar, or silver within water. The above illustrates both internal and external processes.

The immortal elder urges those who cultivate the truth to swiftly refine the golden elixir and transcend life and death, lest they waste their days in vain. Simply capture the White Tiger to subdue the dragon, and the Green Dragon will naturally restrain the tiger. When these two *qi* intertwine and bind, the golden elixir is born. Once obtained, swallow this golden elixir into the abdomen to capture one’s own true *qi*. As the true *qi* clings to the golden elixir, the sacred embryo forms. When the inner true dragon descends, the external dragons and tigers of the world naturally submit. When the inner refinement of spirit, soul, ghosts, and *po* attains sanctity, the ghosts and spirits of the world naturally revere. If the Dao is not profound and virtue not abundant, how could dragons achieve this? With the body transformed into pure yang, life endures as long as Heaven and Earth. Roaming beyond the mundane, at ease among men, all thoughts dissolve—what vexations could remain?

Lu Ziye says: The earthly *po* is lead; the celestial *hun* is mercury. To restrain mercury with lead is a matter of self and other. Do not refine the Three Yellows or Four Spirits; if you seek among grasses, it will not be the truth. Only when yin and yang are of the same kind do they interact; when two and eight correspond, they naturally unite. When the sun at the bottom of the pool glows red, yin monsters vanish; when the moon atop the mountain shines white, the medicinal sprout is fresh. If men wish to know true lead and mercury, they must understand these are not ordinary cinnabar or quicksilver.

The annotation states: The Three Yellows and Four Spirits—minerals, metals, and plants—are all born of the postnatal world, impure substances. How could they transform the formed into the formless? Without internal and external alignment, the embryo cannot form; flowers cannot bear fruit. The *qi* of the True One arises before Heaven and Earth, profound and unfathomable, beyond measure. Only when two and eight, being of the same kind and correspondence, unite and bind, does interaction occur. Within this binding and interaction, a semblance arises—an emotion without emotion, a color without color—just as eight ounces of crow’s liver and half a catty of hare’s marrow. When these two corresponding elements of two and eight unite, the *qi* of the True One returns to the cavity of interaction, congealing into a grain of millet. Herein lies the marvel of the Dao.

The pool is yin; the sun is yang. The red sun at the bottom of the pool is yang within yin. Yang within yin is pure yang, devoid of yin *qi*—thus the yin monsters vanish. This is the coiled *qi* of the tiger, called red lead. The mountain is yang; the moon is yin. The white moon atop the mountain is yin within yang. This is the coiled *qi* of the dragon, the initial coiled *qi*—hence the medicinal sprout is fresh—called black lead. Lead becomes mercury. An ancient song says: Red lead and black mercury are the great heads of the elixir; to merge red into black is true cultivation. This is what it means.

The sage uses these two substances to, in a single moment, transform and create a grain of yang elixir. In the midst of the Northern Sea, it blazes like the sun, its light piercing through curtains. Immediately, it is plucked and swallowed into the abdomen, where it refines one’s yin mercury. All the yin and perverse *qi* of the body are thereby extinguished—just as when the dawn sun first rises from the Eastern Sea, blazing brilliantly, all yin monsters vanish. The yin mercury, descending from the lower cinnabar field to the peak of the summit, gradually congeals, newly sprouting and tender, thus the medicinal sprout is fresh.

chunks.original_text: 亦如月之朔旦，与日相交，乍禀太阳之气，日没时则吐微光西方，於庚上状若蛾眉，月光新嫩，如药苗新也。 此咏内外二药之法象也。 《西华经》曰：阳中之阴名日媳女，阴中之阳名日金公。 此乃壶中夫妇，紫府阶梯，悟之者神仙现在目前，迷之者尘沙杳隔万里。 夫外药之真铅真汞，即龙虎初弦之气也。 内之真铅真汞，即金丹与己之真气也。 时人要识真铅汞，只此是真，此外皆非真道。 此二真物，能化有形而入於无形，为真人仙子。 乃．若几砂几汞，岂可比伦哉。 疏曰：丹经传於世者，多用砂中抽汞名为真汞，或用朱砂名为金体。 转炼为丹，费财既多，费岁月亦久，成功则少。 纵使有成，服之丧生者多矣，皆未识真铅真汞者也。 不识玄中颠倒颠，争知火裹好栽莲。 牵将白虎归家养，产下明珠似月圆。 馒守药炉看火候，但安神息任天然。 草阴剥尽丹成熟，跳出樊笼寿万年。 注曰：以人事推之，男儿固不可有孕，火裹固不可栽莲。 然神仙玄妙之道，有颠倒颠之卫，辄使男儿有孕，亦犹火裹栽莲也。 何则日离为男反为女，月坎为女反为男，此颠倒颠之义也。 二物颠倒，则能生丹。 以丹点已阴汞而结圣胎，养就婴兄，即是男儿有孕，亦犹火裹栽莲，岂非颠倒颠乎。 故仙翁读《参同契》曰：五行逆兮，丹体常灵常存。 言水逆而土，土逆而木，木逆而金，金逆而火，火逆而水，此颠倒颠之深旨也。 颠倒颠之义明白也。 青龙白虎，元是真一之精变为二物，分位东西，实同出而异名也。 真一之精属汞，汞为龙，在东，故真一之精居东也。 白虎本是真一精之子，寄体生在西，其家在东束也。 故仙翁曰：金公本是东家子，送在西邻寄体生。 认得唤来归合养，配将姹女作亲情是也。 金公者，铅也。 姹女者，汞也。 以铅点己之汞而结为圣胎，所以牵将白虎归家养，配以青龙结为夫妇，产个明珠似月圆也。 ○似月圆者，修丹之士，先取上 西畔半轮之月，得阳金八两。 次取下 东畔半轮之月，得弦水半斤。 以此两个半轮之月，合气而生丹，故得金丹一粒似月圆也。 亦如道光禅师谓，灵丹一粒，其重一斤。 此乃两个八两合成一斤而言之，与仙翁月圆之意亦同。 此比喻外药法象也。 及得此丹吞入己腹中，则金丹却为白虎，又牵此白虎归己腹中，配以己汞，然后运阴符阳火，循历六十四卦，煅炼成金液还丹，一粒亦重一斤，似月圆也。 此比喻内药法象也。 内丹所以似月圆者，盖运火之卦，一卦有六爻，六十四卦计三百八十四爻，象一斤三百八十四铢也。 外丹所以似月圆者，一斤乃上下二弦，半轮二八之数，故似月圆也。 《参同契》云：上弦兑亦八，下弦艮亦八，两弦合其精，乾坤体乃成。 二八应一斤，易道正不倾。 故真一子曰：上下两弦，一，斤之数分三百八十四铢，以用运火符爻所是也。 仙翁指示月圆之意，要使学者洞明造化之指，分内外二八之数，不可一槩而论之也。 火非人间火也，元始之祖气也，阴阳之气而无质者也。 亦无药可守，谩言而已。 青霞子曰：鼎鼎非金鼎，炉炉非玉炉。 火从离下发，水向坎中符。 三性既会合，二物自相拘。 固济胎不泄，变化在须臾。 高象先曰：天地捆缊，男女姤精。 四象五行随辐辏，昼夜屯蒙法自然，焉用孜孜看火候。
chunks.translated_text:
Just as the moon at the first dawn of the new moon meets the sun and suddenly receives the *qi* of the Great Yang, when the sun sets, it emits a faint glow in the west, appearing like a crescent on the *geng* position, its light fresh and tender—like the medicinal sprout newly born.

This describes the symbolic forms of the inner and outer elixirs. The *Western Florescence Scripture* states: "The yin within yang is called the Maiden; the yang within yin is called the Metal Duke." These are the husband and wife within the crucible, the stairway to the Purple Palace. Those who awaken to this see immortals before their eyes; those who remain deluded are separated by endless sands.

The true lead and true mercury of the outer elixir are the initial *qi* of the Dragon and Tiger. The true lead and true mercury within are the Golden Elixir and one’s own true *qi*. If one seeks to recognize true lead and mercury, only these are genuine—all else is not the true Way. These two true substances can transform the tangible into the intangible, becoming perfected beings and immortals. How could mere cinnabar and mercury compare?

A commentary states: Most elixir scriptures transmitted in the world extract mercury from cinnabar and call it true mercury, or use cinnabar as the golden body. Refining them into an elixir wastes both wealth and years, with little success. Even if achieved, many who consume it lose their lives—all because they fail to recognize true lead and true mercury.

*"Not knowing the inversion within the mysterious,*
*How can one plant lotuses in fire?*
*Lead the White Tiger home to nurture,*
*And bear a luminous pearl like the full moon.*
*Guard the furnace and watch the fire’s timing,*
*But let spirit and breath follow nature.*
*When yin’s husk is stripped away, the elixir ripens,*
*Leaping from the cage to live ten thousand years."*

A note explains: By human standards, a man cannot conceive, nor can lotuses grow in fire. Yet the Dao of immortals is wondrous and inverted—it enables a man to conceive, just as lotuses grow in fire. Why? The sun (*li*) is male yet becomes female; the moon (*kan*) is female yet becomes male—this is the meaning of inversion. When these two are inverted, they generate the elixir. Using the elixir to refine one’s yin mercury and form the sacred embryo, nurturing the immortal infant, is like a man conceiving—just as planting lotuses in fire. Is this not inversion?

Thus, the immortal elder, expounding the *Triple Concordance*, said: *"The Five Phases move in reverse—*
*The elixir’s body remains ever-spiritual, ever-abiding."*
Water reverses into earth, earth into wood, wood into metal, metal into fire, fire into water—this is the profound meaning of inversion. The principle of inversion is now clear.

The Green Dragon and White Tiger are originally the essence of the True One, transformed into two substances, positioned east and west—truly the same in origin but different in name. The essence of the True One pertains to mercury; mercury is the Dragon, in the east, so the essence of the True One resides in the east. The White Tiger is the child of the True One’s essence, born in the west but with its home in the east. Thus, the immortal elder said: *"The Metal Duke is originally the son of the eastern house,*
*Sent to the western neighbor to be born.*
*Recognize and call him home to nurture,*
*Pair him with the Maiden to wed."*

The Metal Duke is lead; the Maiden is mercury. Using lead to refine one’s own mercury and form the sacred embryo is like leading the White Tiger home to nurture, pairing it with the Green Dragon as husband and wife, producing a luminous pearl like the full moon.

The "full moon" refers to the adept first gathering the half-moon from the upper west, obtaining eight ounces of yang metal. Next, they gather the half-moon from the lower east, obtaining half a catty of crescent water. Combining the *qi* of these two half-moons generates the elixir—thus, the single grain of Golden Elixir resembles the full moon. This aligns with Master Daoguang’s Chan saying: *"A single grain of numinous elixir weighs one catty,"* for two eight-ounce measures combine into one catty, echoing the immortal elder’s full-moon imagery. This metaphor describes the symbolic form of the outer elixir.

When this elixir is swallowed into the abdomen, the Golden Elixir becomes the White Tiger. Leading this White Tiger into one’s own body and pairing it with one’s mercury, then circulating the yin tally and yang fire through the sixty-four hexagrams, one refines it into the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir—a single grain also weighing one catty, like the full moon. This metaphor describes the symbolic form of the inner elixir.

The inner elixir resembles the full moon because the fire-circulating hexagrams each have six lines, and sixty-four hexagrams total 384 lines, corresponding to one catty and 384 *zhu*. The outer elixir resembles the full moon because one catty comprises the upper and lower crescents, the two eights of the half-moons. As the *Triple Concordance* states: *"The upper crescent *dui* is eight,*
*The lower crescent *gen* is eight.*
*When the two crescents merge their essence,*
*The body of *qian* and *kun* is complete.*
*Two eights make one catty—*
*The Dao of Change stands firm and true."*

Thus, Master True One said: The upper and lower crescents, one catty, divide into 384 *zhu*, used to circulate the fire tally and hexagram lines. The immortal elder’s full-moon imagery aims to make scholars thoroughly understand the workings of creation, distinguishing the inner and outer eights—one cannot generalize them.

Fire is not the fire of the human world but the primordial ancestral *qi*, the *qi* of yin and yang without form. There is no medicine to guard—such talk is mere idle chatter. Master Azure Radiance said:

*"The crucible is not a metal crucible,*
*The furnace is not a jade furnace.*
*Fire arises from below *li*,*
*Water accords with *kan*.*
*When the three natures unite,*
*The two substances naturally bind.*
*The embryo is sealed and not leaked—*
*Transformation occurs in an instant."*

Gao Xiangxian said:

*"Heaven and earth intermingle,*
*Male and female join in essence.*
*The four images and five phases follow like spokes to a hub,*
*Day and night, *zhun* and *meng*, follow nature—*
*Why laboriously watch the fire’s timing?"*

All the yin and perverse *qi* of the body are thereby extinguished—just as when the dawn sun first rises from the Eastern Sea, blazing brilliantly, all yin monsters vanish. The yin mercury, descending from the lower cinnabar field to the peak of the summit, gradually congeals, newly sprouting and tender, thus the medicinal sprout is fresh.

chunks.original_text: 此言世间之鼎炉，乃自然鼎炉中之火也。 但安神定息，任其自然，调文治武，则符刻漏不得分毫差忒，不半时辰，立得丹饵。 然后复依此进退，阴符阳火，运用抽添，防危虑险，十月功圆，剥尽群阴，体化纯阳，跳出尘笼寿万年也。 此方为金液还丹也，尚未能入妙，更抱一九载，使气归神，方为九转金液大还丹也。 於斯时也，形神俱妙，与道合真矣。 疏曰：汞者，太阳流珠也。 得金华而结金丹，本因太阳流珠而生。 太阳流珠又因东方青龙而生，故为东方之子，金公是也。 金公，金丹也。 本是东家之子，太阳流珠寄体於西方金华而生，张随注《参同契》云：一月三十日，三百六十时，象小炉鼎。 一年十二月，卦气节度、火侯进退，象大炉鼎。 推荡成六百篇，非世间之火也。 神仙嗟凡人不识真火，故设卦爻而象之。 夫卦者，火之筌蹄也。 见火之用，卦爻可忘。 无名子之注本此也。 要知产药川源处，只在西南是本乡。 铅见癸生急须采，金逢望远不堪尝。 送归土釜牢封固，次入疏珠厮配当。 药重一斤须二八，调停火候托阴阳。 注曰：《西华经》曰：药生西方，收归戊己。 探及其时，下功有日。 夫西南坤地，虎生处也。 坤方又是月所生之处，故日本月。 是金水之精，上下两弦合气成丹。 是以金丹药村土产川源之处，实出於坤地也。 铅遇癸生，时将丑也。 金逢望远，月将亏也。
chunks.translated_text:
This speaks of the crucible and furnace of the human world—it is the fire within the natural crucible and furnace. Simply settle the spirit and regulate the breath, allowing it to follow nature. Harmonize the civil and martial, and the tally will align with the clepsydra without the slightest deviation. In less than half an hour, the elixir is immediately obtained. Thereafter, proceed with this method of advance and retreat, yin tally and yang fire, applying the techniques of withdrawal and addition, guarding against danger and anticipating peril. After ten months, the work is complete, all yin is stripped away, and the body transforms into pure yang, leaping from the cage of the mundane to attain ten thousand years of longevity. This method yields the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir, yet it has not yet entered the sublime. Only after embracing the One for nine years, allowing qi to return to spirit, does it become the Ninefold Transmutation of the Great Returned Golden Liquir. At this time, form and spirit are both wondrous, and one merges with the Dao in truth.

The *Shu* states: Mercury is the flowing pearl of the Great Yang. Obtaining the golden radiance, it congeals into the golden elixir, originally born from the flowing pearl of the Great Yang. The flowing pearl of the Great Yang is in turn born from the Azure Dragon of the East, thus it is the child of the East—this is Metal Lord. Metal Lord is the golden elixir. Originally the child of the Eastern household, the flowing pearl of the Great Yang lodges its body in the golden radiance of the West to be born. Zhang Suizhu’s commentary on the *Cantong Qi* says: "A month has thirty days, three hundred sixty hours, resembling the small crucible and furnace. A year has twelve months, with the hexagram qi’s seasonal measures and the fire’s advance and retreat, resembling the great crucible and furnace." Expounding upon this yields six hundred chapters—this is not the fire of the human world. The immortals sigh that mortals do not recognize the true fire, so they devise hexagrams and lines to symbolize it. The hexagrams are but the fish-trap and rabbit-snare of fire. Once the fire’s function is seen, the hexagrams and lines may be forgotten. The commentary of Master Wuming follows this principle.

One must know where the medicine’s river-source arises—only in the southwest is its homeland. When lead meets the birth of *gui*, hasten to gather it; when metal encounters the distant full moon, it is no longer fit to taste. Send it back to the earthen cauldron, seal it firmly, then enter the flowing pearls to pair and match. The medicine weighs one *jin* and requires two eights; harmonize the fire’s timing by entrusting it to yin and yang.

The *Zhu* states: The *Xihua Jing* says: "The medicine is born in the West and gathered into *wu* and *ji*." When the time is ripe, the day to apply effort arrives. The southwest is the land of *kun*, where the tiger is born. The *kun* direction is also where the moon is born, hence it is called the root of the moon. This is the essence of metal and water; when the upper and lower crescents unite in qi, the elixir is formed. Thus, the source of the golden elixir’s medicinal herbs and river-origin truly emerges from the land of *kun*. When lead encounters the birth of *gui*, the time approaches *chou*. When metal meets the distant full moon, the moon is about to wane.

chunks.original_text: 月之圆存乎口诀，时之子妙在心传。 周天息数微微数，玉漏声寒滴滴符。 此真人口口相传之密旨也。 陆思诚作《悟真篇后序》云：以此诗传者，多谬以铅为若字，以金为如字，甚失仙翁旨意。 铅与金即金丹也。 陆公发其 瑞救鲁鱼之失，秘其源惧竹帛之传。 吾侪亲授师旨，当自知之。 如或不然，空玄之中，去地五丈。 黍米之珠，未易得也。 奈何纷纷傍门，以圭丹为铅金，在天癸时探取，真同兄戏。 又有坤纳癸之说，如叶文叔者，可付之一笑。 盖金丹以癸日子时下工，不得逾时过刻，是以急探也。 望日既远，月亏气喊，故不堪尝也。 盖癸日遁得壬子时、天壬地癸会于北方，故朱震《易传》曰：晦日朔旦，坎月离日会于壬癸。 坎月戊也，离日己也。 又曰：三日暮震，象月出庚。 八日兑，象月现丁。 十五乾，象月盈甲壬。 十六日日一巽，象月退辛。 二十三日艮，象月消丙。 三十日坤，象月灭乙藏癸。 晦日朔旦，月中坎水流戊，日中离火就己。 此乃天机要旨，当以口诀，难以书传，未遇真师，徒尔妄意强猜穿凿而已。 饵丹归丹田土釜之中，固济胎不泄，运火飞流珠之汞以配之，则胎结圣矣。 乌肝八两、兔髓半斤，合成一斤，故日药重一斤须二八也。 火实无火，不过假托阴阳二气，调停而运用耳。 疏曰：人因癸生之时，或探天癸，或遁时癸，安知《悟真》之秘旨。 时将丑者，言时已过也。 月将亏者，言日已过也。 日时既过，铅已息者将消，金已盈者将亏。 探之无有，尝之无效，《易》日…水流湿，火就燥。 流就者，水火之性也。 戊己者，水火中之土也。 水流火就，皆怀戊己以生成。 壬癸者，日月藏用之地也。 戊己者，日月显明之方也。 壬癸拱子，戊己拱午。 子午朔望，日月魂魄，金丹之妙用也。 详见一月小周天数中。 阳为火也，阴亦为火也。 火实无火，乃天地日月之精气，假托而运用之。 万卷仙经语总同，金丹只此是根宗。 依他坤位生成体，种在乾家交感宫。 莫怪天机都泄漏，只绿学者自愚蒙。 若人了得诗中意，立见三清太上翁。 注曰：万卷仙经，至当归一，莫不以龙虎二八初弦之气为丹之质，但依坤母生成之理逆而修之，得丹之后，种在乾父交感之官，以运符火。 修丹至要，不出铅火二字，铅火为大丹之本。 仙翁於此泄尽天机，学者皓首迷蒙，何不近取诸身，以明至道，结成一黍，立宾于天。 疏曰：崔公《入药镜》云：产在坤，种在乾是也。 产在坤，先天气外药也。 种在乾，后天气内药也。 坤母生成之理，坤位西南，月出於庚，金水生成，两弦妙用，此产在坤也。 乾父交感之官，中官北海，犹乾之在西北，饵丹於中，铅汞交感，以成变化，此种在乾也。 铅者，白虎也。 火者，青龙也。 白虎之弦气铅，亦为水青龙之弦气火，非凡火。 铅者，月之精，生於水，成於金，有质而有气，天地妙化之根也。 火者，日之精，生於木，克於金，有气而无质，天地发生之本也。 故日修丹之要、大丹之本，不出铅火也。 陆子野曰：地为坤位，我是乾宗。 藉彼坤中生物之气，自种灵根於家国之下，以成圣胎尔。 万卷千经理不过此也。 三五一都三个字，古今明者实然稀。 束三南二同成五，北一西方四共之。
chunks.translated_text:
The moon’s fullness lies in oral transmission,
The mystery of the *zi* hour rests in heart-to-heart teaching.
The *zhou*-heaven’s breath counts in subtle numbers,
The jade clepsydra’s cold drips match each measure.
This is the true esoteric secret passed mouth to mouth.

Lu Sicheng, in his *Postscript to the Wuzhen Pian*, states: Those who transmit these verses often misread *qian* (lead) as *ruo* (as if) and *jin* (metal) as *ru* (like), greatly distorting the Immortal Elder’s intent. Lead and metal are none other than the golden elixir. Master Lu exposed the error of mistaking characters for their homophones, guarding the source lest it be spread carelessly in texts. We who have received the master’s direct teaching should understand this. If not, in the vast emptiness, five *zhang* above the earth, the pearl the size of a millet grain is not easily obtained.

Alas, how many stray paths confuse cinnabar with lead and metal, seeking them at the *tian gui* hour—truly child’s play. There is also the theory of *kun* receiving *gui*, as in Ye Wenshu’s case, which deserves only a laugh. For the golden elixir, work begins at the *gui* day’s *zi* hour; one must not exceed the moment by even a breath. As the full moon recedes, the moon wanes and its *qi* weakens, making it unfit for gathering.

On the *gui* day, when the hidden *ren-zi* hour arrives, celestial *ren* and terrestrial *gui* meet in the north. Thus, Zhu Zhen’s *Yi Commentary* states: "At the dark moon’s dawn, the *kan* moon and *li* sun meet at *ren* and *gui*. The *kan* moon is *wu*; the *li* sun is *ji*." It also says: "On the third day, *zhen* rises at dusk, symbolizing the moon emerging at *geng*. On the eighth day, *dui* appears, symbolizing the moon revealing *ding*. On the fifteenth, *qian* is full, symbolizing the moon’s plenitude at *jia* and *ren*. On the sixteenth, the sun shifts to *xun*, symbolizing the moon’s retreat at *xin*. On the twenty-third, *gen* wanes, symbolizing the moon’s decline at *bing*. On the thirtieth, *kun* conceals it, symbolizing the moon’s disappearance, hiding *yi* and storing *gui*."

At the dark moon’s dawn, the moon’s *kan* water flows to *wu*, and the sun’s *li* fire converges on *ji*. This is the celestial mechanism’s essential secret—meant for oral transmission, difficult to convey in writing. Without a true master, one can only vainly guess and force interpretations.

Ingest the elixir into the *dan tian*’s earthen crucible, sealing the embryo to prevent leakage. Circulate the fiery-flowing pearl of mercury to pair with it, and the sacred embryo will congeal. Eight ounces of crow’s liver and half a *jin* of hare’s marrow combine into one *jin*—hence the saying, "The medicine weighs one *jin* and requires two eights." The fire is not truly fire; it merely borrows the *yin* and *yang* *qi*, adjusting and applying them.

**Commentary:**
People, at the time of *gui*’s birth, either seek *tian gui* or trace the *gui* hour, unaware of the *Wuzhen Pian*’s secret. "The time approaches *chou*" means the moment has passed; "the moon is about to wane" means the day has passed. Once day and hour have passed, the lead that was stirring will dissipate, and the metal that was full will wane. Seeking yields nothing; tasting brings no effect. The *Yi* says: "...water flows to the damp, fire moves to the dry." Flowing and converging are the natures of water and fire. *Wu* and *ji* are the earth within water and fire. Water flows and fire converges, both embracing *wu* and *ji* to generate and complete. *Ren* and *gui* are where the sun and moon conceal their functions; *wu* and *ji* are where they display their brilliance. *Ren* and *gui* encircle *zi*; *wu* and *ji* encircle *wu*. *Zi* and *wu*, new and full moons, the sun and moon’s ethereal and corporeal souls—these are the golden elixir’s wondrous workings. Details appear in the *xiao zhou tian* numbers of a single month.

*Yang* is fire, and *yin* is also fire. The fire is not truly fire; it is the essence-*qi* of heaven and earth, sun and moon, borrowed and applied. Though ten thousand volumes of immortal scriptures exist, the golden elixir’s root lies solely here. Following the *kun* position’s generative principle, plant it in the *qian* household’s chamber of union.

Do not blame the celestial mechanism for being fully revealed—only that scholars remain ignorant. If one grasps the poem’s meaning, one will immediately meet the Three Pure Ones and the Supreme Elder.

**Commentary:**
All ten thousand volumes of immortal scriptures ultimately converge: none but the *qi* of the dragon and tiger’s two eights’ initial crescent serve as the elixir’s substance. Following the *kun* mother’s generative principle in reverse cultivation, after obtaining the elixir, plant it in the *qian* father’s chamber of union to circulate the fire’s tally. The essentials of elixir refinement do not exceed the two words *lead* and *fire*—lead and fire are the great elixir’s foundation. The Immortal Elder revealed the celestial mechanism entirely, yet scholars, though white-haired, remain confused. Why not seek it within oneself to illuminate the supreme Way, congeal a single millet grain, and immediately ascend to heaven?

**Commentary:**
As Cui Gong’s *Ruyao Jing* says: "Born in *kun*, planted in *qian*." Born in *kun* is the external medicine of primordial *qi*; planted in *qian* is the internal medicine of later heaven’s *qi*. The *kun* mother’s generative principle: the *kun* position is the southwest, where the moon emerges at *geng*, where metal and water are generated, and the two crescents’ wondrous workings—this is "born in *kun*." The *qian* father’s chamber of union: the central palace’s northern sea, like *qian*’s position in the northwest. Ingesting the elixir within, lead and mercury unite and transform—this is "planted in *qian*."

Lead is the White Tiger. Fire is the Green Dragon. The White Tiger’s crescent-*qi* lead is also water; the Green Dragon’s crescent-*qi* fire is no ordinary fire. Lead is the moon’s essence, born of water, completed in metal, possessing substance and *qi*—the root of heaven and earth’s wondrous transformations. Fire is the sun’s essence, born of wood, overcoming metal, possessing *qi* but no substance—the origin of heaven and earth’s generation. Thus, the essentials of elixir refinement and the great elixir’s foundation do not exceed lead and fire.

Lu Ziye said: The earth is the *kun* position; I am the *qian* lineage. Borrowing the *qi* of creation from within *kun*, I plant the numinous root beneath my household to form the sacred embryo. The principles of ten thousand volumes and a thousand scriptures do not surpass this.

Three, five, and one—three words in all,
Rare indeed are those who understand them through the ages.
East’s three and south’s two together make five,
North’s one and west’s four complete them.

Thus, the source of the golden elixir’s medicinal herbs and river-origin truly emerges from the land of *kun*. When lead encounters the birth of *gui*, the time approaches *chou*. chunks.original_text: 戊己自归生数五，三家相见结婴儿。 是知太一含真气，十月胎圆入圣基。 注曰：三五一，不离龙虎也。 龙属木，木数三，居东。 木能生火，故龙之弦气属火。 火数二，居南。 二物同源，故三与二合成一五也。 虎属金，金数四，居西。 金能生水，放虎之弦气属水，水数＇，居北。 二物同官，故四与一合成二五也。 二物之五交於戊己之中官，中宫属土，土生数五，是为三五也。 三五合而成丹，丹者，一也，故日三五一也。 此三个字，自古迄今，能合三五一而成丹，能了达婴兄者，实稀有也。 一即金丹也。 婴儿者，即丹也。 丹是一，一是真一之气，天地之母气也。 己之真气，天地之子气也。 以母气咽归五内，以伏子气，犹猫伏鼠而不走也。 子母之气相恋，於胞胎之中结成婴儿之一，故日太一含真气，言含真一之气，如人怀胎十月满足，然后降生圣胎，亦如之十月功圆，自然神圣，故日十月胎圆入圣基。 后人以肾为婴兄，安有如此之功。 疏曰：一二三四五生数，生则有兆而未成形，非世问有质之五行，天地虚无之气，此为先天。 六七八九十届成数，成则有形，非先天无质之五行，此为后天。 天一地四为五，合中五成十。 天三地二为五，合中五成十。 两五相偶，亦合为天数二十有五。 金丹因先天五行成丹，故只取五行生数。 肾为婴儿，心为妮女，出於内外二景。 存想神鬼之法皆阴也，是以无功焉。 右分内药。 五－实四韵一首以象太一之奇 女子着青衣，郎君披素练。 见之不可用，用之不可见。 恍惚裹相逢，杳冥中有变。 一作夫妇若相逢恩情自相恋。 一霎火焰飞，真人自出现。 注曰：女子者，龙之弦气也，阳中之阴，故日女子，又名木姬。 生於青龙，故着青衣也。 郎君者，虎之弦气也，阴中之阳，故日郎君，又名金郎。 生於白虎，故披素练也。 有质可见者，后天地生滓质之物类也，以其有质，故可见而不可用也。 无形可睹者，龙虎二八初弦之气也，以其有气而无质，故不可见而可用也，实探铅之枢机也。 恍恍惚惚、杳杳冥冥者，混元真一之气也，生於天地之先不可测度。 恍惚中有物者，龙之弦气也。 杳冥中有精者，虎之弦气也。 二孩之气在於恍惚之中、杳冥之内，捆缢相逢，磅砖相恋。 故得真一之气灵非有，变而为一黍之珠，此无中生有之妙也。 真人者，金丹也。 圣人将一年火侯擭於一个时辰中，又於一个时辰中分为六侯，先於两候中运火煅炼，立得真一之气，结成一粒之珠，现在北海之中，大如黍米。 岂非一霎时火，真人自出现乎。 此道至妙至玄，苟非遭遇真师，口授真诀，其孰能与於此哉。 仙仑咏此一章，所以五言四韵一首，表五行四象而成一粒之黍珠也。 丹虽是真一之气所变，苟不因龙虎二弦之气相交，则亦不能成丹矣。 盖龙虎并二弦者四象，四象交会於中官而成丹。 丹土也，乃真五行也。 老君曰：五行即是药，四象不可阙是也。 故五行四象合而成丹，所以仙翁日五言四韵一首，以象太一之奇者，此也。 阳子曰：此诗八句，括尽一部丹经之妙用。 首句是乾家事为木汞，属我。 二句是兑家事为铅，属他。 三句则生人物矣，四句可以炼丹，五句为入室下功，六句乃防危杜险，七句即丹成九转，八句为行满三千。

"Wu and Ji naturally return to the generative number five; the three families meet to form the sacred infant. Thus we know the Great One contains the true *qi*—after ten months, the embryo is complete, entering the foundation of sageliness."

**Annotation states:** The "three, five, and one" do not depart from dragon and tiger. The dragon pertains to wood, wood’s number is three, residing in the east. Wood can generate fire, thus the dragon’s crescent *qi* pertains to fire. Fire’s number is two, residing in the south. The two things share a single source, so three and two combine to form one five. The tiger pertains to metal, metal’s number is four, residing in the west. Metal can generate water, thus the tiger’s crescent *qi* pertains to water, water’s number is one, residing in the north. The two things share a single palace, so four and one combine to form a second five. The two fives of these two things converge within the central palace of Wu and Ji. The central palace pertains to earth, earth’s generative number is five—this is the three fives. When the three fives unite, they form the elixir; the elixir is one, hence it is called "three, five, one." These three words—from ancient times to the present, those who can unite the three, five, and one to form the elixir and comprehend the sacred infant are truly rare. The "one" is the golden elixir. The "infant" is the elixir itself. The elixir is one; one is the true *qi* of the Great One, the mother-*qi* of heaven and earth. One’s own true *qi* is the child-*qi* of heaven and earth. Drawing the mother-*qi* inward to subdue the child-*qi* is like a cat crouching over a mouse to prevent its escape. When mother and child *qi* long for each other, within the womb they coalesce into the sacred infant—hence, "the Great One contains the true *qi*." This speaks of containing the true *qi* of the Great One, like a person carrying a child for ten months until full term, then giving birth to the sacred embryo. Likewise, after ten months of practice, the work is complete, and one naturally becomes spiritually sagely—hence, "after ten months, the embryo is complete, entering the foundation of sageliness." Later generations take the kidneys as the sacred infant, but how could they achieve such efficacy?

**Commentary states:** One, two, three, four, five are generative numbers—generative, they have signs but no form, not the five phases of the mundane world with substance, but the *qi* of heaven and earth’s emptiness and nothingness, this is the prior heaven. Six, seven, eight, nine, ten are completion numbers—completion, they have form, not the prior heaven’s formless five phases, this is the posterior heaven. Heaven’s one and earth’s four make five, combined with the central five to complete ten. Heaven’s three and earth’s two make five, combined with the central five to complete ten. The two fives pair, also combining into the heavenly number twenty-five. The golden elixir is formed from the prior heaven’s five phases, thus it only takes the generative numbers of the five phases. The kidneys as the sacred infant and the heart as the young maiden arise from the inner and outer two visions. The methods of visualizing spirits and ghosts are all yin—thus they yield no efficacy.

**Internal Medicine Division.**
Five words, four rhymes, one verse to symbolize the singularity of the Great One:

A maiden wears blue robes,
A young lord dons white silk.
Seen, they cannot be used;
Used, they cannot be seen.
Within the dim and vague, they meet,
In the distant and obscure, transformation occurs.
*(One version reads: When husband and wife meet, their affection naturally deepens.)*
In an instant, flames fly—
The true person emerges of itself.

**Annotation states:** The "maiden" is the dragon’s crescent *qi*, yang within yin—hence called a maiden, also named "Wood Maiden." Born of the Azure Dragon, she wears blue robes. The "young lord" is the tiger’s crescent *qi*, yin within yang—hence called a young lord, also named "Metal Lad." Born of the White Tiger, he dons white silk. Those with substance that can be seen are the impure, material things of the posterior heaven—because they have substance, they can be seen but cannot be used. Those without form that cannot be beheld are the initial crescent *qi* of the dragon and tiger—because they have *qi* but no substance, they cannot be seen but can be used, truly the pivot of lead extraction. The dim and vague, distant and obscure are the primordial true *qi* of the undifferentiated origin, born before heaven and earth, beyond measure. Within the dim and vague lies a thing—the dragon’s crescent *qi*. Within the distant and obscure lies an essence—the tiger’s crescent *qi*. The *qi* of these two children resides within the dim and vague, the distant and obscure, where they meet in embrace, longing in profound affection. Thus the true *qi* of the Great One, spiritually numinous yet insubstantial, transforms into a grain of millet’s pearl—this is the wonder of nothing giving birth to being. The "true person" is the golden elixir. The sage condenses a year’s fire phases into a single hour, and within that hour divides them into six phases. First, within two phases, the fire is circulated to refine and forge, immediately obtaining the true *qi* of the Great One, coalescing into a single grain of pearl, appearing within the Northern Sea, large as a grain of millet. Is this not an instant of fire when the true person emerges of itself? This Way is most wondrous and mysterious—without encountering a true teacher to transmit the oral instructions, who could attain this? The immortal master chanted this chapter, thus five words and four rhymes in one verse, to represent the five phases and four images forming a single grain of millet pearl. Though the elixir is transformed from the true *qi* of the Great One, without the dragon and tiger’s two crescent *qi* uniting, it could not become the elixir. The dragon and tiger together with their two crescents are the four images; the four images converge within the central palace to form the elixir. The elixir is earth—it is the true five phases. Laozi said: "The five phases are the medicine; the four images cannot be lacking." Thus the five phases and four images unite to form the elixir—hence the immortal master said, "five words, four rhymes, one verse to symbolize the singularity of the Great One." Yangzi said: "These eight lines encompass the wondrous workings of an entire elixir scripture. The first line concerns Qian’s affair—Wood Mercury, belonging to oneself. The second line concerns Dui’s affair—lead, belonging to another. The third line generates beings. The fourth line can refine the elixir. The fifth line is entering the chamber to practice. The sixth line is guarding against danger and blocking peril. The seventh line is the elixir’s nine revolutions complete. The eighth line is the merit of three thousand deeds fulfilled."

chunks.original_text: 仙师布流此诗者，惟欲指出先天混元真一之气，即太一所舍之物气，学者可不求师乎。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之三竟 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之四 象川无名子翁葆光注武夷陈达灵传集庆空玄子戴起宗疏 绝句六十四首以按六十四卦 赫赫金丹一日成，古仙实语信堪听。 若言九载三年者，总是推延拟日程。 注曰：金丹大药，下工不逾半时辰，立得吞饵。 此言一日者，皆圣人促一年气候於一月之中，又促一月气侯於一日之中，又促一日气候於一时之中。 通而言之，谓之一日成仙也。 故仙翁曰：以时易日法神功是也。 金丹入口，立跻圣地，明验如之速，岂三年九载，迁延岁月，以拟日程乎。 古仙张果老诗曰：赫赫金丹一日成，黄芽不离水银坑。 功成虽未三周变，开炉已觉放光明。 即此道也。 上阳子曰：炼丹之法，要知他家活子时也。 非天下之至妙，孰能与於此哉。 日月三旬一遇逢，以时易日法神功。 守城野战知凶吉，增得灵砂满鼎红。 注曰：太阳太阴，一月一次相交，人知而则之，移一月为一日，移日圣为一时。 守城则沐浴罢功，野战则龙虎交斗。 神功者，进水之度也。 苟或阴阳错乱，日月乖戾，外火虽动而行，内符闲静而不应。 有道之士，进退水火知吉凶，旋斗历箕时合天度，自然灵胎密运，神鼎增辉矣。 疏曰：以时易日者，时中自有子午，其阴阳始终，皆与天地日月同度。 箕斗之缠在艮寅之位，阳火在子，火丑未畅，束北艮乡，去寅不远。 太阴魄藏亦在艮乡，箕斗之宿，又为火长生之位，皆与同度。 《参同契》云：始於东北箕斗之乡是也旋而右转，为三日，月生於震庚。 旋而左转，为正月，火生於寅月，卦为泰。 月才天际半轮明，早有龙吟虎啸声。 便好用工修二八，一时辰内管丹成。 注曰：月之半轮者，一八之数也。 仙翁指龙虎，皆一八之数，合而成二八也。 此时水源至清，有气而无质者也。 一年之中止有一日，一日之中止有一时，一时之中分为六侯。 下工不出两候，立得金丹一粒服饵，余四候别有妙用。 此皆天机，不书竹帛，口传心授。 仙翁亦不敢成文漏露，但寓意於篇诗中，混而言之日．．一时辰内管丹成。 叶文叔不明此理，不得斯卫，却言药成於一时，非止用一时，茫然不知指归，私意妄揣，诚可笑也。 若言非用一辰，又得转旋日程也，奚为至简至易耶。 玄哉妙哉，斯道非人问世上可得而闻也。 馑按：大丹火既，日伏睹。 圣工｀人始於下手工夫之际，造铅之初，盗混元一大周天之气，夺三万六千之正数，聚於乾坤之鼎，会於生杀之舍，夺尽天地之数，夺尽日月之数，夺尽龙虎之数，夺尽生成之数，夺尽阴阳之数，夺尽五行之数。 擒於一时辰内，制造金丹一粒，其大如黍，其重一斤，至灵至贵，至圣至神，至简至易，为天地之精，作一身之主宰，可谓贼天、贼地、贼阴、贼阳，宇宙在乎手，万化在乎身。 成至真仙，子宾于上帝。 故我仙黄日．．一时辰内管丹成，岂妄语哉，此其证也。 疏曰：半轮者，一八也。 上弦之八金，阳也。 下弦之八水，阴也。 合二八於一时，立得金丹一粒。 此神仙之亲传天地之玄机，非俗士可以妄猜。 世之用一时者，或遁德合，或遁戊己，或遁癸，或取月建，或用将，或取天呈所指，或取冬至，或取阳兴，或取癸降，或以意到中官，或取钻簇七政，或取五行都聚，或取五行生旺墓，或取甲庚丙壬，或取三日四时，或用活子时，或用本生时，或陕倒生，或用日月之正中，或用日月相望，或用日月合壁，或用心肾交媾时，或＇取亥子人问，或取地气三元，或取上下二弦，或取东星成室，或日月宿直，或取七元建时。

**Sixty-Four Quatrains Corresponding to the Sixty-Four Hexagrams**

Bright and resplendent, the golden elixir forms in a single day—
The ancient immortals spoke truly; their words are worthy of heed.
If one speaks of nine years or three years,
It is merely procrastination, scheming by the calendar.

**Annotation:** The great medicine of the golden elixir, once the work begins, is obtained in less than half an hour and immediately ingested. This "single day" means the sage compresses a year’s qi-cycles into a month, a month’s qi-cycles into a day, and a day’s qi-cycles into an hour. Broadly speaking, it is called "attaining immortality in a single day." Thus the immortal master said: "Exchanging hours for days is the method of divine work." Once the golden elixir enters the mouth, one ascends to the sacred realm—its efficacy is swift and manifest. How could it require three years or nine years, dragging out time as if planning by the calendar?

The ancient immortal Zhang Guolao wrote:
Bright and resplendent, the golden elixir forms in a single day;
The yellow sprout never leaves the cinnabar pit.
Though the work may not yet complete three revolutions,
Opening the furnace, one already perceives radiant light.
This is the Way.

Master Shangyang said: The method of refining the elixir requires knowing the "living midnight" of the other household. Who but the supremely subtle could attain this?

Sun and moon meet once every thirty days—
Exchanging hours for days is the method of divine work.
Defending the city or waging wild battle, know fortune and misfortune;
The crucible fills with numinous cinnabar, glowing crimson.

**Annotation:** The Great Yang and Great Yin conjoin once a month. Those who understand this compress a month into a day, a day into an hour. Defending the city refers to the work after bathing; waging wild battle refers to the union of dragon and tiger. Divine work is the measure of advancing water. If yin and yang are disordered, sun and moon discordant, the external fire may move while the internal tally remains quiescent and unresponsive. The adept, advancing and retreating with water and fire, knows fortune and misfortune. When the Dipper and Winnowing Basket align with celestial degrees, the numinous embryo circulates in secret, and the divine crucible shines ever brighter.

**Commentary:** "Exchanging hours for days" means that within each hour, there is a midnight and noon; the beginning and end of yin and yang all align with the degrees of heaven, earth, sun, and moon. The coil of the Winnowing Basket and Dipper lies in the position of Gen and Yin. The yang fire resides in Zi; the fire of Chou and Wei is not yet flourishing. The northeast region of Gen is not far from Yin. The Great Yin’s lunar essence is also stored in the Gen region. The lodges of the Winnowing Basket and Dipper are also the positions where fire attains long life, all aligning with the same degrees. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "It begins in the northeast, the region of the Winnowing Basket and Dipper." Rotating rightward forms three days, and the moon is born in Zhen and Geng. Rotating leftward forms the first month, and fire is born in the Yin month, corresponding to the hexagram Tai.

The moon, barely half a wheel bright at the sky’s edge,
Already bears the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl.
It is best to begin the work of refining the two eights—
Within a single hour, the elixir is assuredly complete.

**Annotation:** The moon’s half-wheel is the number eight. The immortal master refers to the dragon and tiger, each as the number eight, combining to form sixteen. At this time, the water’s source is utterly pure, possessing qi but no substance. In a year, there is only one such day; in a day, only one such hour; in an hour, divided into six periods. The work does not exceed two periods, and one immediately obtains a grain of golden elixir to ingest. The remaining four periods have other wondrous uses. These are all celestial secrets, not recorded on bamboo or silk, transmitted only orally and mind-to-mind. The immortal master dared not commit them to writing or reveal them outright, but embedded their meaning within the poem, vaguely stating: "...within a single hour, the elixir is assuredly complete." Ye Wenshu, not understanding this principle and failing to grasp this teaching, claimed that the medicine forms in an hour but is not refined in an hour alone. Bewildered, he knew not the true reference, idly speculating—truly laughable. If one says it does not require a single hour, then it becomes a matter of rotating through the calendar. How could it remain supremely simple and easy?

Profound! Wondrous! This Way is not something one can hear about in the world of men.

**Editor’s Note:** The fire of the great elixir is hidden at dusk. When the sage begins the initial work of crafting lead, they steal the qi of the primordial Unity’s great celestial cycle, seizing the correct tally of thirty-six thousand. Gathering it in the crucible of Qian and Kun, converging in the chamber of life and death, they seize the tally of heaven and earth, the tally of sun and moon, the tally of dragon and tiger, the tally of generation and completion, the tally of yin and yang, the tally of the five phases. Capturing it within a single hour, they forge a grain of golden elixir, as large as a millet seed, weighing one catty. Utterly numinous, supremely noble, most sacred and divine, supremely simple and easy, it is the essence of heaven and earth, the master of the body. One may call it the thief of heaven, the thief of earth, the thief of yin, the thief of yang. The cosmos is in one’s hands; the myriad transformations are within one’s body. Attaining the perfection of true immortality, one becomes a guest of the Supreme Emperor. Thus our immortal master said: "...within a single hour, the elixir is assuredly complete." How could this be empty words? This is the proof.

**Commentary:** The half-wheel is eight. The eight metals of the waxing moon are yang; the eight waters of the waning moon are yin. Combining the two eights in a single hour, one immediately obtains a grain of golden elixir. This is the celestial mystery personally transmitted by the immortals, not something worldly scholars can idly guess. Those in the world who speak of "a single hour" may refer to aligning with virtue, or aligning with Wu and Ji, or aligning with Gui, or following the lunar station, or using the general, or following the celestial indications, or taking the winter solstice, or taking the rise of yang, or taking the descent of Gui, or focusing the mind on the Central Palace, or gathering the seven luminaries, or assembling the five phases, or taking the five phases’ positions of generation, flourishing, and storage, or taking Jia, Geng, Bing, and Ren, or taking three days and four hours, or using the "living midnight," or using one’s birth hour, or reversing the sequence of generation, or using the exact center of sun and moon, or using the opposition of sun and moon, or using the conjunction of sun and moon, or using the union of heart and kidney, or taking the time between Hai and Zi, or taking the earth’s three origins, or taking the upper and lower crescents, or taking the Eastern Star forming the chamber, or the lunar lodge’s duty, or the seven origins’ established hours.
