chunks.original_text: 皆云始於一时交媾，从此用功。 世人行之未有神仙者，盖不知一时管丹成，丹之成不出於一时之内，立得服饵，又何在推延日程耶。 先把乾坤为鼎器，后搏乌兔药来烹。 既驱二物归黄道，争得金丹不解生。 注曰：日月本是乾坤精，故圣人以乾坤喻为鼎器，日月喻为药也。 乾坤即真龙真、虎也，药物即龙虎之弦气也。 魏真人曰：鼎鼎元无鼎，药药元无药。 圣人假托名立象，借喻如此，其要只此真龙真虎初弦二气，交媾凝炼，真一之精，结於北海中官之内。 既驱二物归黄道，争得金丹不解生。 黄道即中官，金丹凝结生成之处也。 疏曰：仙经此云以乾坤为鼎器，坎离为药物。 乾坤、坎离、鼎器、药物一类，向无形无名，只以乾坤真龙虎，此金丹外龙虎也。 彭真人所注《参同契》，坎戊月精，象水中生金虎。 离己日光，象火中生木龙。 此金丹内龙虎也。 名曰体异，皆借喻也。 二物若龙归黄道，自然交媾成丹，蛮强分何者，为龙虎之定体，但息不能知黄道媒合尔。 离坎若还无戊己，虽含四象不成丹。 只绿彼此怀真土，遂使金丹有往还。 注曰：《参同契》曰：离己日光，坎戊月精。 故离之己，象龙之弦气也。 坎之戊，象虎之弦气也。 未戊与己，是真土之一体，分居龙虎二体之中，故日彼此怀真土也。 龙虎苟无土，安能合并四象，会於土而成丹也哉。 只缘彼此各有土气，二土乃合并而成刀圭。 是以龙虎交，则戊己合也。 戊己合为一体，则四象合而成丹也，所以金丹有返还者也。 吕真人云：二物会时，为道本五行全处，得丹名者此也。 疏曰：离阳也，己阴也。 火以地二生，天七成，中含五土。 火内暗外明，离卦中虚，皆阳含阴也。 坎阴戊阳也，水以天一生，地六成，中含五土。 水外暗内明，坎卦中实，皆阴含阳也。 坎中有金，离中有木，为四象。 坎中流戊，离中就己，各怀真土。 四象合，则戊己阴阳二土会而为一，则五行全矣。 返本还源，七返九还，金丹即成。 日居离位反为女，坎配蟾宫却是男。 不会个中颠倒意，休将管见事高谈。 注曰：日中乌属阴，故为离女。 月中兔属阳，故为坎男。 苟不知颠倒之妙，徒自高谈，亦犹以管窥天者也。 疏曰：颠倒者，不以阴为阳，是为阴中取阳。 不以阳为阴，是以阳中取阴。 阴为阴，阳为阳，顺行者，世之常道也。 阴取阳，阳取阴，逆行者，仙之盗机也。 五行颠倒，阴阳互用，世罕知之，故日五行逆兮，丹体常灵常存。 又日皆因兄产母，此之谓也。 天下之兔皆牝，惟月中兔皆牡，兔望月成孕，故知月兔属阳。 震龙汞出自离乡，兑虎金生在北方。 二物总因儿产母，五行全要入中央。 注曰：汞为震龙，属木。 木生火，木为火母，火为木子，此常道之顺也。 及乎朱砂属火，火为离，汞自砂中出，却是火返能生木，故日儿产母也。 太白真人歌曰：五行颠倒卫，龙从火裹出是也。 仙翁所以言汞生离，不言砂中汞生者，盖砂中汞谓之真汞，又日火中汞。 故取其真汞而言之，是以言汞而不言砂也。 铅为兑虎，属金。 金生水，金为水母，水为金子，此常道之顺也。 及乎黑铅属水，水为坎，银自铅中生，却是水返能生金，故日儿产母也。 太白真人歌曰：五行不顺行，虎向水中生是也。
chunks.translated_text:
All speak of beginning at the moment of union, from which one applies effort. Yet among those who practice this, none have attained immortality—this is because they do not know that while the union governs the completion of the elixir, the elixir’s formation does not occur within that single moment, nor is it immediately ingested. Why then should one delay the schedule?

First, take Qian and Kun as the crucible and vessel;
Then, gather the Crow and Hare as the medicine to refine.
Once the two are driven into the Yellow Path,
How could the golden elixir fail to take form?

**Annotation:** The sun and moon are the essence of Qian and Kun, so the sages use Qian and Kun as metaphors for the crucible and vessel, and the sun and moon as metaphors for the medicine. Qian and Kun are the true Dragon and Tiger, while the medicinal substances are the primal *qi* of the Dragon and Tiger’s initial tension. Master Wei said: *"A crucible is fundamentally no crucible; medicine is fundamentally no medicine."* The sages borrowed names and established images through such metaphors, but the essential point lies solely in the union and refinement of the true Dragon and Tiger’s initial *qi*, whereby the essence of the true One coalesces within the Central Palace of the Northern Sea. *"Once the two are driven into the Yellow Path, how could the golden elixir fail to take form?"* The Yellow Path is the Central Palace, the place where the golden elixir congeals and takes shape.

**Exegesis:** The immortal scriptures state that Qian and Kun serve as the crucible and vessel, while Kan and Li serve as the medicinal substances. Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li—crucible, vessel, and medicinal substances—are of one category, originally formless and nameless. They are merely the true Dragon and Tiger of the golden elixir, the external Dragon and Tiger. In Master Peng’s commentary on the *Cantong Qi*, *"Kan’s Wu is the moon’s essence, resembling metal born within water—a Tiger. Li’s Ji is the sun’s light, resembling wood born within fire—a Dragon."* These are the internal Dragon and Tiger of the golden elixir. Though their names differ, all are metaphors. If the two substances—like the Dragon returning to the Yellow Path—naturally unite to form the elixir, why forcibly distinguish which is the Dragon or Tiger’s fixed body? The key lies in not knowing how the Yellow Path serves as the mediator for their union.

If Kan and Li lack Wu and Ji,
Though they contain the Four Images, no elixir forms.
Only because each harbors true Earth,
Does the golden elixir gain its cycle of return.

**Annotation:** The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Li’s Ji is the sun’s light; Kan’s Wu is the moon’s essence."* Thus, Li’s Ji symbolizes the Dragon’s primal *qi*, and Kan’s Wu symbolizes the Tiger’s primal *qi*. Wu and Ji are one body of true Earth, yet they reside separately within the Dragon and Tiger’s two bodies—hence the phrase *"each harbors true Earth."* Without Earth, how could the Dragon and Tiger merge the Four Images to unite in Earth and form the elixir? It is precisely because each contains Earth’s *qi* that the two Earths combine to form the *daogui*. Thus, when the Dragon and Tiger unite, Wu and Ji merge. When Wu and Ji become one, the Four Images unite to form the elixir—this is why the golden elixir achieves its return. Master Lü said: *"When the two substances meet, the Dao’s root lies where the Five Phases are complete—this is what earns the elixir its name."*

**Exegesis:** Li is yang, and Ji is yin. Fire is born from Earth’s two, completed by Heaven’s seven, and contains the central Five Earths. Fire is dark within and bright without; the Li trigram is hollow at its core—all yang containing yin. Kan is yin, and Wu is yang. Water is born from Heaven’s one, completed by Earth’s six, and contains the central Five Earths. Water is dark without and bright within; the Kan trigram is solid at its core—all yin containing yang. Kan contains metal, and Li contains wood—these are the Four Images. Kan’s flowing Wu and Li’s congealing Ji each harbor true Earth. When the Four Images unite, the yin and yang Earths of Wu and Ji merge into one, completing the Five Phases. Returning to the root and reverting to the source, the seven returns and nine reversions—thus the golden elixir is formed.

The sun resides in Li’s position yet becomes the maiden;
Kan pairs with the Toad Palace yet becomes the youth.
If you do not grasp the reversal within,
Do not presume to discourse on such matters with limited insight.

**Annotation:** The Crow within the sun belongs to yin, hence it is the maiden of Li. The Hare within the moon belongs to yang, hence it is the youth of Kan. Without understanding the marvel of reversal, one’s lofty discourse is no different from gazing at the sky through a tube.

**Exegesis:** Reversal means not taking yin as yang—this is extracting yang from within yin. Not taking yang as yin—this is extracting yin from within yang. Yin as yin, yang as yang—this is the ordinary path of the world. Extracting yang from yin, extracting yin from yang—this is the thieving mechanism of immortals. The Five Phases reverse, yin and yang interchange—few in the world comprehend this, hence the saying: *"When the Five Phases reverse, the elixir’s body remains eternally numinous and enduring."* It is also said: *"All arise from the child giving birth to the mother"*—this is what it means. All hares under heaven are female, yet only the moon’s hare is male. The hare conceives by gazing at the moon, thus the moon’s hare belongs to yang.

The Zhen Dragon’s mercury emerges from Li’s homeland;
The Dui Tiger’s metal is born in the northern realm.
Both arise from the child giving birth to the mother;
The Five Phases must enter the center to be complete.

**Annotation:** Mercury is the Zhen Dragon, belonging to wood. Wood generates fire, wood is fire’s mother, and fire is wood’s child—this is the ordinary sequence of the common path. Yet cinnabar belongs to fire, fire is Li, and mercury emerges from within cinnabar. This is fire’s reversal to generate wood—hence the phrase *"the child giving birth to the mother."* The *Song of the Supreme White Realized One* states: *"When the Five Phases reverse, the Dragon emerges from within fire."* The immortal elder speaks of mercury being born in Li, not of mercury being born within cinnabar, because mercury within cinnabar is called true mercury, also known as *"mercury within fire."* Thus, he refers to true mercury, speaking of mercury without mentioning cinnabar.

Lead is the Dui Tiger, belonging to metal. Metal generates water, metal is water’s mother, and water is metal’s child—this is the ordinary sequence of the common path. Yet black lead belongs to water, water is Kan, and silver is born within lead. This is water’s reversal to generate metal—hence the phrase *"the child giving birth to the mother."* The *Song of the Supreme White Realized One* states: *"When the Five Phases do not proceed in order, the Tiger is born within water."*

chunks.original_text: 仙翁所以言铅生在坎，不言银生者，盖铅中银谓之真铅，又日水之铅。 故取其真铅而言之，是以言铅而不言银也。 二物互相生产而成四象，会合中央而成五行。 五行合，则金丹结也。 故日五行全要入中央。 中央，即中官太极也。 后人以心肾气液为龙虎、铅汞，言虎是肾之气，而肾属水为虎，向水中生。 言龙是心之液，而心属火为龙，从火裹出。 此言有同儿戏尔，欲成大药，岂可戾乎。 疏曰：或问予曰：养命者，皆以心肾为龙虎，铅汞气液为水火，冀其升降交媾，以结圣胎。 至於施肩吾所编《锺吕传道集》亦云：肾中生气，气中真一之水。 心中生液，液中正阳之气。 内丹药村出於心肾配合交娠，日得黍米名个金丹大药。 今《悟真篇序》乃云：分心肾为坎离，欲望结成还丹，一不亦远乎。 无名子於取坎离之诗注云：以心肾为坎离，则天地远矣。 此诗之注又云：以心肾气液为龙虎铅汞，有同兄戏。 然则心肾气液非金丹大药乎，予应之曰：正阳云：心肾即非为水火，不知水火是何物。 石杏林云：气产元非肾，神居不在心。 道光云：握固休推心肾。 陈泥丸云：心肾元来非坎离。 今《传道集》以心肾气液传子母，行夫妇，为铅汞龙虎坎离，盖借人身心传气液，以曲譬阴阳，明其妙用耳。 昧者不得真传，遂一为实言，大道远矣。 何不参究《传道集》中有，云：体用不出於阴阳，造化皆因於交媾。 至哉其言乎。 咽津纳气是人行，有物方能万物生。 鼎内若无真种子，犹将水火煮空铛。 注曰：世人所谓咽津纳气者，皆后天地生，至阴之物也，非真服气也。 夫真服气者，先伏而后服气也。 经曰：伏气不复气，不服顺服气。 服气不长生，长生须伏气是也。 夫真一之气，混於杳冥恍惚之中，难求难见，圣人以法伏之，故得杳冥中有精，恍惚中有物，变化毁炼成丹，服归丹田之中，则万物化生也。 故日有物方能万物生也，以其有真种子故也。 若无真种子，万般作用，劳而无功，空铛水火，望作何为。 所为真种子，即真铅也。 疏曰：运金液入脑，自上将入丹田，亦是咽津也。 运外阴阳真气，亦是纳气也。 非以咽津纳气为非，特以无真种子，则徒劳无功。 若无真种，则咽者咽纯阴之精，纳者纳后天之气。 内无后天之母气，则天地阴场、之真气，不与一身之子气相恋合而凝结矣。 伏者，如猫捕鼠，制而伏之，不敢动也。 服者，如鱼吞水，入者即出，不能存也。 又日伏者，伏天地之气，结而成丹也。 服天地之气，结而成丹，吞入丹田，而后阴符阳火，天地皆归以育金液还丹，而成圣胎也。 华岳岩前雄虎啸，扶桑海底牝龙吟。 黄婆日解相媒合，遣作夫妻共一心。 注曰：华岳者，西山月出之处，以象虎也。 雄虎，乃虎之弦气也，阴中之阳，故号於雄虎也。 扶桑者，束方日出之处，以象龙也。 牝龙，乃龙之弦气也，阳中之阴，故号於牝龙也。 二物问隔，在束在西。 媒者，黄婆使之交合，结为夫妇，以产玄珠黄芽也。 疏曰：《参同契》龙呼虎吸、龙夫虎妻，以二物之本体相克，而为雌雄。 《悟真篇》雄虎牝龙，以二物之阴阳相交，而为雌雄。 是以龙虎互为雌雄，不可以一言论也。 调和铅汞要成丹，大小无伤两国全。 若问真铅何物是，蟾光终日照西川。
chunks.translated_text:
The immortal elder speaks of lead being born in Kan, not of silver being born within it, because silver within lead is called true lead, also known as *"lead of water."* Thus, he refers to true lead, speaking of lead without mentioning silver.

These two substances mutually generate and produce the Four Images, converging at the center to form the Five Phases. When the Five Phases unite, the Golden Elixir coalesces—hence the saying, *"The Five Phases must all enter the center."* The center is the Central Palace, the Great Ultimate.

Later generations take the qi and fluids of the heart and kidneys as Dragon and Tiger, lead and mercury, claiming the Tiger is the qi of the kidneys, and since the kidneys belong to water, the Tiger is born within water; the Dragon is the fluid of the heart, and since the heart belongs to fire, the Dragon emerges from within fire. Such words are but child’s play—how could the Great Medicine be thus perverted?

A commentary states: Someone asked me, *"Those who cultivate life all take the heart and kidneys as Dragon and Tiger, the qi and fluids of lead and mercury as water and fire, hoping for their ascent and descent to unite and form the Sacred Embryo. Even Shi Jianwu’s* Zhong Lü’s Transmission of the Dao *says: ‘Within the kidneys, qi is born; within qi, the true unity of water. Within the heart, fluid is born; within fluid, the right yang of qi.’ The ingredients of the Internal Elixir arise from the heart and kidneys’ union and conception, daily gathering like a grain of millet to become the Great Medicine of the Golden Elixir. Yet the preface to the* Awakening to Reality *states: ‘To divide heart and kidneys as Kan and Li, hoping to congeal the Reverted Elixir—is this not far from the mark?’ The Unnamed Master, in his commentary on the poem about Kan and Li, says: ‘To take heart and kidneys as Kan and Li is to distance oneself from heaven and earth.’ This commentary further says: ‘To take the qi and fluids of heart and kidneys as Dragon and Tiger, lead and mercury, is but child’s play.’ If the qi and fluids of heart and kidneys are not the Great Medicine of the Golden Elixir, then what is?"* I replied: *"Zhengyang said: ‘Heart and kidneys are not water and fire—do you know what water and fire truly are?’ Shixinglin said: ‘Qi is not produced in the kidneys; spirit does not reside in the heart.’ Daoguang said: ‘In grasping firmness, do not push heart and kidneys.’ Chen Niewan said: ‘Heart and kidneys were never Kan and Li.’ Now,* Transmission of the Dao *takes the qi and fluids of heart and kidneys to transmit mother and child, enact husband and wife, and serve as lead and mercury, Dragon and Tiger, Kan and Li—this is merely borrowing the qi and fluids of the human body to metaphorically illustrate yin and yang and clarify their wondrous function. The unenlightened, failing to receive the true transmission, take it as literal speech, and the Great Dao becomes distant. Why not ponder the words in* Transmission of the Dao*: ‘Substance and function do not depart from yin and yang; creation arises from their union.’ How profound are these words!*

*‘Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi is what people do—only with the proper substance can the myriad things be born. If the crucible lacks the true seed, it is like boiling an empty cauldron with water and fire.’*

A commentary says: *"What the world calls ‘swallowing saliva and absorbing qi’ are all postnatal, earth-born, utmost yin substances—this is not true qi absorption. True qi absorption first subdues and then absorbs qi. As the classic says: ‘Subduing qi does not mean replenishing qi; not absorbing qi in sequence is true absorption. Absorbing qi does not grant longevity; longevity requires subduing qi.’ The true unity of qi blends into the boundless, indistinct void—difficult to seek, difficult to see. The sage subdues it with method, thus obtaining essence within the boundless and substance within the indistinct. Through transformation and refinement, the Elixir is formed, then ingested into the Cinnabar Field, where the myriad things are transformed and born. Hence the saying, ‘Only with the proper substance can the myriad things be born’—for it possesses the true seed. Without the true seed, all efforts are labor in vain; boiling an empty cauldron with water and fire—what can one hope to achieve? The true seed is true lead."*

A commentary states: *"Directing the Golden Fluid into the brain and then guiding it into the Cinnabar Field is also a form of swallowing saliva. Directing the true qi of external yin and yang is also a form of absorbing qi. This is not to say swallowing saliva and absorbing qi are wrong—only that without the true seed, efforts are futile. Without the true seed, what one swallows is pure yin essence, and what one absorbs is postnatal qi. Without the mother qi of the postnatal, the true qi of heaven and earth’s yin and yang will not unite and congeal with the child qi of one’s body.*

*‘To subdue’ is like a cat stalking a mouse—restraining and subduing it so it does not dare move. ‘To absorb’ is like a fish swallowing water—what enters immediately exits and cannot be retained. It is also said: ‘To subdue is to subdue the qi of heaven and earth, congealing it into the Elixir. To absorb the qi of heaven and earth, congealing it into the Elixir, then swallowing it into the Cinnabar Field—thereafter, yin tally and yang fire, heaven and earth all return to nurture the Golden Fluid Reverted Elixir, forming the Sacred Embryo.’*

*The male Tiger roars before Mount Hua’s cliffs,
The female Dragon hums beneath Fusang’s seas.
The Yellow Dame daily mediates their union,
Sending them as husband and wife to share one heart.*

A commentary says: *"Mount Hua is where the moon rises in the west, symbolizing the Tiger. The male Tiger is the Tiger’s latent qi—yin within yang, hence called the male Tiger. Fusang is where the sun rises in the east, symbolizing the Dragon. The female Dragon is the Dragon’s latent qi—yang within yin, hence called the female Dragon. The two are separated, one in the east, one in the west. The matchmaker, the Yellow Dame, causes their union, binding them as husband and wife to produce the Mysterious Pearl and Yellow Sprout."*

A commentary states: *"The* Cantong Qi *speaks of the Dragon’s exhalation and the Tiger’s inhalation, the Dragon as husband and the Tiger as wife—taking the two substances’ inherent opposition as male and female. The* Awakening to Reality *speaks of the male Tiger and female Dragon—taking the two substances’ yin-yang union as male and female. Thus, Dragon and Tiger alternately serve as male and female; this cannot be settled with a single word.*

*Harmonizing lead and mercury to form the Elixir,
Neither great nor small harms the two realms’ wholeness.
If you ask what true lead truly is—
The toad’s glow shines all day upon the Western River."*

Lead is the Dui Tiger, belonging to metal. Metal generates water, metal is water’s mother, and water is metal’s child—this is the ordinary sequence of the common path. Yet black lead belongs to water, water is Kan, and silver is born within lead. This is water’s reversal to generate metal—hence the phrase *"the child giving birth to the mother."* The *Song of the Supreme White Realized One* states: *"When the Five Phases do not proceed in order, the Tiger is born within water."*

chunks.original_text: 注曰：驱龙则火汞飞扬，驾虎则水铅闪炼，捆缢造化一粒黍米，先天气成，何伤之有，故日大小无伤两国全也。 夫龙大虎小，阳尊阴卑之义也。 金丹因上下两弦金水溶成，名日真铅。 蟾光者，金水之精，属阴也。 经曰：照者，与日交光之旨，象阴阳交合之义。 西者，金方也。 川者，水也。 圣人於八月十五日，合金水二气，结成金。 液之精者此也。 月上弦属水，下弦属金，故仙翁以西若金之方，以川为水之体。 然月．未尝能终日照，惟下弦之月，日初出现，来畔金之光，於南方丙上，至日午时，没於西方庚。 上弦之月，日午时现西畔半轮，水之光出於东方甲上，至日没时，升到南方丁上。 两个半轮月，合为金水圆图之光，共成终日之照。 喻如龙虎合两孩之气而生丹也。 故日若问真铅何物是，蟾光终日照西川也。 疏曰：上下二弦月与日相照於昼，取其金水之至清也。 望日月与日相望於夜，取其金水之至旺也，清者有气而无质也，旺者无质而有质也。 清时二八互为阴显，旺时二八全为一体，则而象之，金丹立成。 上经云上弦金半斤，今日上弦属水。 上经云下弦水半斤，今日下弦属金。 是知上弦金半斤，无月之日者一半。 上弦属水，言月之黑者一半。 白者金，黑者水，故互言之，以显二弦金水各半斤，而成二八之妙。 下弦亦然，或者不其妙，则疑之矣。 竹破须将竹补宜，覆鸡当以卵为之。 万般非类徒为巧，争似真铅合圣机。 注曰：竹器破矣，用金木之类补之可乎。 此叉以竹补之，然后器用完也。 雏将覆矣，土石之物抱之可乎。 此叉以卵覆之，．然后谷音生焉。 陶真人曰：竹断须竹续，木破须木补。 屋破用瓦盖，人衰以类生。 修真者若非同类，功用徒劳。 《参同契》曰：同类易施功，非类难为巧。 欲作服食仙，当以同类者。 盖人察天地之秀气以有生，真铅是天地之母气，托同类之物，孕而育之。 故真铅为母气，我真气为子气，岂非同类之至妙者乎。 是以合至圣之深机，自然之大道也。 疏曰：陶真人名植，有别录三品至药秘传於世。 唐敬宗朝，宝历元年八月十五日，浙束明州鄞县四明山大梅峰梅福仙人台上，白日上升，具有碑记在台下。 药逢气类方成象，道在虚无合自然。 一粒灵丹吞入腹，始知我命不由天。

A commentary states: Driving the Dragon causes the fiery mercury to soar; harnessing the Tiger makes the watery lead gleam and flash. Binding and refining Creation into a single grain of millet, the primordial qi coalesces—how could harm come to either? Thus it is said, "Neither great nor small harms the two realms’ wholeness."

The Dragon is great, the Tiger small—this reflects the principle of yang’s nobility and yin’s humility. The Golden Elixir arises from the fusion of the upper and lower crescent moons’ metallic and aqueous essences, called True Lead. The toad’s glow is the essence of metal and water, belonging to yin. The scripture says: "To illuminate" signifies the intent of the moon’s light intermingling with the sun’s, symbolizing the union of yin and yang. The west is the direction of metal; the river is water. On the fifteenth day of the eighth month, the sage conjoins the two qi of metal and water to congeal the essence of liquid gold. This is the essence of the moon’s radiance.

The moon’s upper crescent pertains to water, the lower crescent to metal. Thus the immortal elder takes the west as the direction of metal and the river as the body of water. Yet the moon never shines all day—only the lower crescent moon appears at sunrise, its golden light lingering at the southern *bing* position, vanishing in the western *geng* at noon. The upper crescent moon emerges at noon as a half-wheel on the western horizon, its aqueous light rising in the eastern *jia* and ascending to the southern *ding* by sunset. The two half-moons combine into the full orb of metal and water’s light, completing the day’s illumination. This is likened to the Dragon and Tiger uniting the two children’s qi to generate the Elixir. Hence it is said, "If you ask what true lead truly is—The toad’s glow shines all day upon the Western River."

A further commentary states: The upper and lower crescent moons illuminate the day alongside the sun, drawing forth the utmost clarity of metal and water. At the full moon, the moon faces the sun at night, drawing forth the utmost abundance of metal and water. Clarity possesses qi but no form; abundance possesses form yet no form. In clarity, the two eights alternately manifest as yin and yang; in abundance, the two eights merge into one body. Modeling this, the Golden Elixir is instantly achieved.

The preceding scripture says, "The upper crescent’s metal weighs half a catty," yet today it is said the upper crescent pertains to water. The preceding scripture says, "The lower crescent’s water weighs half a catty," yet today it is said the lower crescent pertains to metal. Thus the upper crescent’s half-catty of metal refers to the moon’s sunlit half, while the upper crescent’s water refers to its dark half. The white is metal, the black is water—hence the alternate phrasing reveals the two crescents’ metal and water each weighing half a catty, forming the marvel of the two eights. The lower crescent is likewise. Those who fail to grasp this marvel will doubt it.

"When bamboo splits, only bamboo can mend it;
When a chick is overturned, only an egg can right it.
Though myriad methods may seem clever,
None compare to true lead uniting with the sage’s mechanism."

A commentary states: If a bamboo vessel breaks, can it be mended with metal or wood? Only by using bamboo is the vessel made whole again. If a chick is overturned, can it be righted with earth or stone? Only by using an egg does the fledgling’s cry arise. Master Tao says: "When bamboo breaks, only bamboo can join it; when wood splits, only wood can mend it. When a roof is damaged, tiles must cover it; when a person declines, only their kind can revive them." If the cultivator of the Dao does not employ the same kind, their efforts are in vain. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Work is easily done with the same kind; skill is difficult with the unlike. If you wish to become an immortal through ingesting elixirs, you must use those of the same kind."

For humans receive life from the essence of Heaven and Earth’s radiance; True Lead is the mother-qi of Heaven and Earth, entrusting its kindred substance to conceive and nurture. Thus True Lead is the mother-qi, and my true qi is the child-qi—are these not the most wondrous of the same kind? Therefore, uniting with the profound mechanism of the utmost sage is the great Dao of spontaneity.

A further commentary states: Master Tao, styled Zhi, left behind three scrolls of *Secret Transmissions on the Supreme Medicines* for the world. In the first year of Baoli during the reign of Emperor Jingzong of Tang, on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, he ascended to immortality in broad daylight at the Plum Immortal’s Terrace on Great Plum Peak in Yin County, Mingzhou, in eastern Zhejiang. A stele recording this event stands below the terrace.

"Only when medicine meets its kindred qi does it take form;
The Dao resides in emptiness, uniting with spontaneity.
A single grain of numinous elixir swallowed into the belly—
Only then do you know your fate is not ruled by Heaven."

chunks.original_text: 注曰：有物混成，先天地生，圣人故强名之曰道，强名之日混元真一之气。 视之不见，听之不闻，搏之不得，圣人以同类二八初弦之气，感而遂通，降灵象空玄之中，一粒如黍，饵在腹中，立乾己汞，化为纯阳之躯，与天地同久。 朝元子曰：死生尽道由天地性命，元来属汞铅，此非我命在我不在天乎。 西山白虎正猖狂，束海青龙不可当。 两手捉来令死斗，化成一片紫金霜。 注曰：此言外象也，释在前律诗：五行全处龙虎蟠注内。 紫金霜，即金丹也。 海蟾翁曰：左手捉住青龙头，右手拽住白虎尾。 一时将来一口吞，思量此物是甘美。 算来只是水中金，妙达玄机真要理。 此其证也。 或有未闻至道者，以意乱猜，以两手作两兽解‘，可笑也哉，远之远矣。 安炉立鼎法乾坤，缎炼精华制魄魂。 聚散捆组成变化，敢将玄妙等闲论。 注曰：积诸阳气为天，在上而不润下。 积诸阴气为地，在下而不炎上。 即天地不交也。 不交，焉能造化而生万物也哉。 盖天虽为至阳之物，而有一阴之气在其中，故能降地。 地虽是至阴之物，而有一阳之气在其中，故能升天。 二气捆缢，万物化醇，此以二气交合而成变化。 金丹之道，安炉立鼎，暖炼精华，以制魂魄，莫不取法於天地子母。 歌曰：精交无用药，气合无言语。 金丹以气与类，结而成之，故日药逢气类方成象也。 始自无中生有，复自有中生无。 无形而能变化，是以变化无穷，此乃天机，安敢饶舌。 疏曰：始自无中生有，此言外药，凭虚无真一之气，无质生质。 非是有中生有，以有质之物而为之也。 复自有中化无，此言内药因外药成象，吞入五内，点化四肢百骸之有形而为气也。 无形而能变化，此言内外既成，化气成神，抱元九载，神而无形，变化不测。 人能知无中有至道，则可渐次而化矣。 俗谓常言合至道，宜向其中细寻讨。 能於日用颠倒求，大地尘沙尽成宝。 注曰：真铅真汞，不为日用之问，颠倒修之，大地尘沙尽成宝。 古歌曰：朝朝只在君家舍，日日随君君不知。 异名同出少人知，两者玄玄是要机。 保命全形明损益，紫金丹药最灵奇。 注日．； 太上曰：无名，天地之始。 有名，万物之母。 又曰：此两者同出而异名。 方其无也，真一之气不可见也，故为天地之始。 及其有也，真一之气化而为黍，现於空玄之中，故为万物之母。 在天日离为汞，在地日坎为铅。 其本则同，其出则异。 同谓之玄玄之又玄。
chunks.translated_text:
A commentary states: There is a thing formlessly formed, born before Heaven and Earth. The sage thus forcibly names it the Dao, forcibly names it the Primordial Chaos of the True Unity of qi. Invisible to sight, inaudible to hearing, intangible to grasp, the sage uses the kindred qi of the first crescent of the second and eighth months to resonate and thus communicate, descending the numinous image into the void of the Mysterious. A single grain like a millet seed, ingested into the belly, immediately transmutes mercury into pure Yang, transforming the body into one of pure Yang, co-eternal with Heaven and Earth.

Master Chaoyuan said: Life and death are entirely governed by the nature and destiny of Heaven and Earth—yet originally they belong to mercury and lead. Is this not "my destiny lies within me, not in Heaven"?

The White Tiger of the Western Mountain rages wildly,
The Azure Dragon of the Eastern Sea cannot be withstood.
Seize them with both hands and force them to battle—
They transform into a sheet of purple-gold frost.

A commentary states: This speaks of external imagery, explained in the earlier verse: *"Where the Five Agents are complete, Dragon and Tiger coil within."* Purple-gold frost is the Golden Elixir.

Master Haichan said:
With the left hand seize the Azure Dragon’s head,
With the right hand drag the White Tiger’s tail.
Bring them together and swallow in one gulp—
Reflecting, this thing is sweet and fine.
Yet reckon it is merely gold within water,
Mastering the mystery reveals the true principle.
This is its proof.

Some who have never heard of the Supreme Dao wildly guess at its meaning, interpreting "both hands" as "two beasts"—how laughable! They are far, far astray.

The method of setting the furnace and establishing the crucible follows Heaven and Earth,
Refining the essence to subdue the hun and po.
Gathering and dispersing, binding and weaving to enact transformation—
How dare one treat such profound mysteries as trivial discourse?

A commentary states: Accumulating all Yang qi forms Heaven, which remains above and does not moisten below. Accumulating all Yin qi forms Earth, which remains below and does not flame upward. This is Heaven and Earth not conjoining. If they do not conjoin, how can they create and transform to generate the myriad things? Though Heaven is the most Yang of things, it contains within it a single qi of Yin, and thus can descend to Earth. Though Earth is the most Yin of things, it contains within it a single qi of Yang, and thus can ascend to Heaven. When these two qi intertwine, the myriad things transform and mature—this is how their union enacts transformation. The Dao of the Golden Elixir, in setting the furnace and establishing the crucible, warming and refining the essence to subdue the hun and po, all take their model from the Heaven-Earth mother-child relationship.

A song says:
When essence conjoins, no medicine is needed;
When qi harmonizes, no words are spoken.
The Golden Elixir is formed by qi uniting with its kind—
Thus it is said: *"Only when medicine meets its kindred qi does it take form."*

It begins with nothing generating something,
Then returns to something generating nothing.
Formless yet able to transform—
Thus its transformations are inexhaustible. This is the Heavenly mechanism;
how dare one prattle on?

A commentary states: *"Beginning with nothing generating something"* refers to the external medicine, relying on the True Unity of qi in emptiness to generate form from the formless. It is not *"something generating something"*—using a thing with form to create it. *"Returning to something generating nothing"* refers to the internal medicine: once the external medicine takes form and is ingested into the five viscera, it transmutes the corporeal forms of the four limbs and hundred bones into qi. *"Formless yet able to transform"* refers to the completion of both internal and external, transmuting qi into spirit. Embracing the Origin for nine years, spirit becomes formless, its transformations unfathomable. If one can know the Supreme Dao within nothingness, one may gradually transform.

The common saying goes: *"If ordinary words align with the Supreme Dao, one should delve deeply into their meaning."* If one can seek within daily life’s inversions, the dust and sand of the great earth all become treasures.

A commentary states: True lead and true mercury are not found in daily inquiries. If one inverts and cultivates them, the dust and sand of the great earth all become treasures.

An ancient song says:
Day after day, it dwells only in your home,
Day after day, it follows you, yet you remain unaware.
Few know these different names arise from the same source—
Both are the profound mystery’s essential mechanism.
Preserving life and perfecting form clarifies gain and loss;
The Purple-Gold Elixir is most wondrous and rare.

A commentary states: The Most High said: *"The Nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth; the Named is the mother of the myriad things."* He also said: *"These two emerge together yet bear different names."* When it is in its formless state, the True Unity of qi is invisible—thus it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth. When it takes form, the True Unity of qi transforms into a millet grain, manifesting in the void of the Mysterious—thus it is the mother of the myriad things. In Heaven it is called *li* and is mercury; on Earth it is called *kan* and is lead. Their root is the same, though their manifestations differ. This sameness is called *"the mystery within the mystery."*

chunks.original_text: 修真之功，执此二者玄机，以明损益，以治修身，则形可全而命可保也。 所谓二者，阴阳二气而已。 所谓损者，五行顺兮，常道有生有灭是也。 吁，纯阳紫金之丹，立为天地之始，出为万物之母。 其日紫金丹药最灵奇，当知仙翁叹莫不尽之深意也。 疏曰：在天日离为汞，火炎上为离。 本乎天者亲上，木中生火为铅。 天阳而含阴，肃肃之阴降自天。 在地日坎为银，水润下为坎。 本乎地者亲下，水中生金为铅。 地阴而含阳，赫赫之阳升自地。 夫天地奠位，日月成象，皆是水阴火阳二气所变。 火炎而轻清，外明内暗。 水润下而重浊，内明外暗。 天地日月既有形矣，而后五行又各成形於天地之问。 金击之有火，溶之成水。 木钻之有火，绞之成水。 土以火生，以水润金。 木者，非火之交也。 金木土之中，水火二气无所不在。 水火不能自生人、自杀人。 至於金木土不能自杀人，叉待人用之，而后能此。 五行之水火，又得其气之全者也。 天地万物，皆不出乎五行，五行又不离於阴阳，阴阳同出於太极，此出同而名异也。 其本则同者，玄牝之根，同出於真一之太极。 其出则异者，真一之气各分，为阴阳之玄牝，此本同而出异也。 玄牝两者同出於太极混一之气，既成形矣，禀性得其纯，分居得其所，颠倒修之，紫金丹药可以成矣。 黑中有白曰丹母，雄裹藏雌是圣胎。 太一在炉宜慎守，三田宝聚应三台。 注曰：铅中取银，是为丹母。 朱裹抽汞，乃为圣胎。 二物能感化真一之气，结在太一炉中。 惟在精调火候，恬守规模，不使分毫差惑，方得三性会合，结成丹宝，上应三台。 太一者，真一之气也，故日太一含真气也。 疏曰：铅中取银，朱裹抽汞，皆是假借外物，以寓阴阳互用之理。 世人不知，妄以修炼服饵，妄以笺注迷作，误人多矣。 无名子於金鼎欲留朱裹汞，赤龙黑虎合束西二诗注文，皆言亦犹铅中银、朱裹汞。 犹者，譬如也。 参三诗而深究之，乃知二物之妙，果能感化真一之气，岂几铅、几汞之所能为哉。 偃月炉中玉药生，朱砂鼎内水银平。 只因火力调和候，种得黄芽渐长成。 注曰：偃月炉者，阴炉也。 中有玉药之阳气，虎之弦气也。 朱砂鼎者，阳鼎也。 中有水银之阴气，即龙之弦气也。 金丹只因此二弦之火，调停和合之力，种得真一之芽，长在黄家结黍珠也。 未炼还丹莫隐山，山中内外尽非铅。 此般至宝家家有，自是时人识不全。 注曰：龙不在束淇，虎不在西山。 家家自有，逆而修之，还丹可冀。 纵识朱砂及黑铅，不知火候也如闲。 大都全藉修持力，毫发差殊不作丹。 注曰：金丹造化，全藉丁公。 毫发差殊，失之千里。 是以圣人传药不传火，须共神仙子细论。 疏曰：朱砂黑铅，非有质之物，真龙真虎是也。 识此而不识火侯，亦不成丹。 道光词云：三人同志慎忘危，进火工夫子细。 陈泥丸诗云：若无同志相规觅，时恐炉中火候非。 是以修持多赖真友，若使毫厘有差，丹不可成。 铃遇真师，方明大道。 心传火侯，不载文字。 渊乎玄机，上天所视。 风生有绿，知之速修。 四象会时玄体就，五方行处紫光明。 脱胎入口通神圣，无限神龙尽失惊。 注曰：龙虎交娠，则四象会而五方行矣。 四象五方会合，则真一之体结如黍珠，紫色光明矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The practice of the True Work lies in grasping these two mysteries of yin and yang to clarify gain and loss, and to cultivate the body—thus may form be preserved and life be safeguarded.

What are these two? They are simply the two qi of yin and yang. What is meant by "loss"? It is the sequential flow of the Five Phases, the constant Dao of arising and perishing. Ah! The Pure Yang Elixir of Purple Gold stands as the beginning of Heaven and Earth, emerges as the mother of the myriad things. When it is said that *"the Purple-Gold Elixir is most wondrous and rare,"* one must recognize the profound intent in the Immortal Elder’s sigh, which knows no end.

A commentary states: In Heaven it is called *li* and is mercury, for fire flames upward as *li*. That which is of Heaven inclines upward; fire is born within wood as lead. Heaven is yang yet contains yin—solemn yin descends from Heaven. On Earth it is called *kan* and is silver, for water moistens downward as *kan*. That which is of Earth inclines downward; metal is born within water as lead. Earth is yin yet contains yang—radiant yang ascends from Earth. When Heaven and Earth are established in their positions and the sun and moon take form, all are transformations of the two qi: water-yin and fire-yang. Fire flames upward, light and pure, bright without yet dark within. Water moistens downward, heavy and turbid, bright within yet dark without. Once Heaven and Earth and the sun and moon have taken form, the Five Phases then each assume their forms between Heaven and Earth. When metal is struck, fire appears; when smelted, it becomes water. When wood is drilled, fire appears; when pressed, it yields water. Earth is born of fire and moistened by water to nurture metal. Wood is not the union of fire. Within metal, wood, and earth, the two qi of water and fire are omnipresent. Water and fire cannot spontaneously give life to or kill humans. As for metal, wood, and earth, they too cannot kill humans—only when employed by humans do they gain such power. The water and fire of the Five Phases are those that possess the fullness of qi. All things between Heaven and Earth do not transcend the Five Phases, and the Five Phases do not depart from yin and yang. Yin and yang both emerge from the Supreme Ultimate—this is emergence together yet bearing different names. Their root is the same: the Mysterious Female’s root, which together emerges from the True One’s Supreme Ultimate. Their emergence differs: the True One’s qi divides into the yin and yang of the Mysterious Female—this is sameness in root yet difference in emergence. These two, the Mysterious Female, both emerge from the undifferentiated qi of the Supreme Ultimate. Once they take form, if they receive their nature purely and reside in their proper places, then through inversion and refinement, the Purple-Gold Elixir may be accomplished. Within black there is white—this is the Elixir Mother. Within the male is concealed the female—this is the Sacred Embryo. The Supreme One abides in the furnace; guard it with care. The Three Fields’ treasures gather, corresponding to the Three Terraces.

A commentary states: Extracting silver from lead is called the Elixir Mother. Drawing mercury from cinnabar is called the Sacred Embryo. These two substances can attract and transform the True One’s qi, congealing it within the Supreme One’s furnace. It depends entirely on precisely regulating the firing times, calmly adhering to the model, and ensuring not the slightest deviation or confusion—only then may the three natures unite, the Elixir Treasure form, and the upper correspond to the Three Terraces. The Supreme One is the True One’s qi—thus it is said the Supreme One contains the True qi.

A commentary states: Extracting silver from lead and drawing mercury from cinnabar are both metaphors for external substances, illustrating the principle of yin and yang’s mutual employment. The world does not understand this, mistakenly engaging in alchemical refinement and ingestion, or composing deluded annotations—many are led astray. Master Wu Ming, in his verses on the Golden Crucible’s desire to retain cinnabar-wrapped mercury, and the Red Dragon and Black Tiger uniting East and West, all speak of the same as silver within lead and mercury within cinnabar. "Same" here means "for example." By studying these three poems deeply, one comes to know the marvel of these two substances—they truly can attract and transform the True One’s qi. How could mere lead or mercury achieve this?

Within the Crescent Moon Furnace, the Jade Medicine is born;
Within the Cinnabar Tripod, the mercury levels.
Only through the harmonizing power of the firing times
Is the Yellow Sprout planted, gradually growing to maturity.

A commentary states: The Crescent Moon Furnace is the yin furnace. Within it is the yang qi of the Jade Medicine—the bowstring qi of the Tiger. The Cinnabar Tripod is the yang tripod. Within it is the yin qi of mercury—the bowstring qi of the Dragon. The Golden Elixir arises solely from the harmonizing power of these two bowstring fires, planting the True One’s sprout to grow within the Yellow House and form the Millet Pearl.

Do not hide in the mountains before refining the Returning Elixir—
Within and without those mountains, all is not lead.
This supreme treasure exists in every household;
It is only that people of this age fail to recognize it fully.

A commentary states: The Dragon is not in the Eastern River; the Tiger is not in the Western Mountains. Every household possesses it—reverse the process and refine it, and the Returning Elixir may be attained. Though one may recognize cinnabar and black lead, without knowing the firing times, it is as if idle. It depends entirely on the power of cultivation—even a hair’s deviation will fail to produce the Elixir.

A commentary states: The creation of the Golden Elixir depends wholly on Master Ding. Even a hair’s deviation leads one astray by a thousand miles. Thus the sages transmitted the medicine but not the fire—one must discuss it in detail with an immortal.

A commentary states: Cinnabar and black lead are not material substances—they are the True Dragon and True Tiger. Recognizing them yet not knowing the firing times will still not produce the Elixir. The *Daoguang Ci* says: *"Three people of like mind must cautiously guard against peril; advance the fire with meticulous care."* Master Chen Nin Wan’s poem says: *"Without like-minded companions to seek and correct, one fears the furnace’s firing times may err."* Thus cultivation relies greatly on true companions. If even a hair’s breadth is amiss, the Elixir cannot form. Only upon encountering a true teacher is the Great Dao made clear. The transmission of the firing times is heart-to-heart, not recorded in writing. Profound and wondrous is this mystery—Heaven above observes it. When the wind arises with cause, know to swiftly cultivate.

When the Four Images unite, the Mysterious Body is complete;
When the Five Directions move, the Purple Light shines.
Once the embryo is shed and enters the mouth, it communicates with the divine and sacred—
Countless divine dragons all lose their awe.

A commentary states: When Dragon and Tiger intermingle, the Four Images unite and the Five Directions move. When the Four Images and Five Directions converge, the True One’s body congeals like a millet pearl, radiant with purple light.

When it takes form, the True Unity of qi transforms into a millet grain, manifesting in the void of the Mysterious—thus it is the mother of the myriad things. In Heaven it is called *li* and is mercury; on Earth it is called *kan* and is lead. Their root is the same, though their manifestations differ. This sameness is called *"the mystery within the mystery."*

chunks.original_text: 密运于时，夺归入口，通圣远神，无限神龙，孰不惊愕而钦仰也哉。 始於有作人争觅，及至无为众始知。 但见无为为道体，不知有作是根基。 注曰：世有学释氏性道，执此一切有为皆是妄者，以其语毁老氏命道。 此乃知其一不知其二，窥其门墙而未升堂入室者也。 乌知修命之道，始於有作，炼丹以化形，中则有为，炼形以化气，终则无为自在。 面壁九年，抱一以空其心，以见其性，性即神也。 神性一体，变现无方，九载功毕，气自成神，神自合道。 故形与神俱妙而不测，神与道合而无形。 形既无已，可得谓之有为有作而为幻化乎。 安知性非命，命非性耶。 强而分之日性、日命二混而一之，未始有以异也。 故自有作以至於无作，有为以至於无为，有形以至於无形也。 斯道至大，非中下根气所能知。 故仙翁作诗以示后学，勿但见无为为要妙，而不知有为为有作，实无为为无作之根基也。 别本注曰：始於有作人争觅者，於一阳来复之时，取两弦金水之气，人须有知觉者，虽鬼神莫能知，着龟莫能测也。 及乎金丹成就，变化无穷，则众人不得而知也。 人但见无为之为要妙，又岂知探取阴阳，凝结铅汞，实在於起首下手之立根基而有作也哉。 疏曰：有为无为，分性命二宗。 先须循序各备，自始而中，自中而终。 结丹一时，怀胎十月，抱一九载，方能混而一之为无形之妙，方能至於命非性、性非命之玄矣。 世人混以性宗为金丹命卫，既无自悟之真空，诅以口耳之学，弃有执无之顽空，以敌生死，以为本来天性是金丹者多矣，安能各尽性命之大道乎。 恍惚之中寻有象，杳冥之内觅真精。 有无由此自相入，未见如何想得成。
chunks.translated_text:
At the moment of secret refinement, seize the opportunity to draw it into the mouth, communicating with the sacred and transcending the divine—countless divine dragons, who would not stand in awe and reverence? At first, in the stage of effortful practice, people vie to seek it; only when it reaches effortless attainment do the many begin to understand. Yet they see only that the Dao’s essence is effortless non-doing, unaware that effortful practice is its very foundation.

A commentary states: Those who study the Buddhist path of nature, clinging to the notion that all conditioned action is delusion, use such words to slander the Daoist path of life. These know only one side and not the other, having glimpsed the gate but never ascended the hall or entered the chamber. How could they know that the Dao of cultivating life begins with effortful practice, refining the Elixir to transform form; proceeds through conditioned action, refining form to transform qi; and culminates in effortless spontaneity? Facing the wall for nine years, embracing the One to empty the heart and perceive its nature—nature is spirit. Spirit and nature are one, manifesting without limit. After nine years of practice, qi naturally becomes spirit, and spirit naturally unites with the Dao. Thus, form and spirit together attain the wondrous and unfathomable; spirit and Dao merge, becoming formless. Since form is no longer confined, how can this be called conditioned action or delusory transformation? How can they claim nature is not life, or life is not nature? Forcibly dividing them into "nature" and "life" is to merge two into one—there was never any difference. Thus, from effortful practice to effortless action, from conditioned doing to non-doing, from form to formlessness. This Dao is so vast that those of middling or lesser capacity cannot comprehend it. Therefore, the Immortal Elder composed a poem to instruct later learners: do not see only effortless non-doing as the essential mystery, unaware that effortful practice is the foundation of effortless attainment.

Another commentary states: "At first, in the stage of effortful practice, people vie to seek it"—this refers to the moment when the yang revives at the solstice, when one gathers the qi of the two bowstrings (metal and water). Only those with awareness can perceive it, though even spirits and divination cannot fathom it. Once the Golden Elixir is accomplished and its transformations become boundless, the multitude cannot comprehend it. People see only that effortless non-doing is the essential mystery, yet how could they know that the gathering of yin and yang, the congealing of lead and mercury, truly begins with the foundational effort of establishing the root at the outset? A discourse states: Conditioned action and non-doing divide the two schools of nature and life. One must proceed in order, fulfilling each stage—from beginning to middle, from middle to end. The Elixir is formed in an instant, the embryo gestates for ten months, and the One is embraced for nine years. Only then can the two merge into the wondrous formlessness, only then can one attain the mystery where life is not nature and nature is not life. The world confuses the school of nature with the Golden Elixir of life; lacking true emptiness of self-realization, they rely on superficial learning, abandoning the conditioned to cling to the empty void, hoping to overcome birth and death. Many claim that original nature is the Golden Elixir, yet how can they fully master the great Dao of nature and life? Within the indistinct, seek the image; within the profound darkness, find the true essence. From this, being and non-being naturally interpenetrate—without such vision, how can one ever succeed?

chunks.original_text: 注曰：恍惚之中有象者，龙之弦气也。 杳冥之内有精者，虎之弦气也。 二弦皆有气而无质者也。 恍恍惚惚，杳杳冥冥，视之不见，听之不闻者，真一之气也。 真一之气，至灵而无形者也。 真一子曰：无者，龙也。 有者，虎也。 无者，汞气也。 有者，铅气也。 无因有激之而有象，有因无感之而有灵。 故得黍珠悬空，紫霜耀日也。 彼哉兀兀存想尘埃心地者，亦可悲矣。 疏曰：《参同契》 云：有无相制，上闲则称有，下闲则称无。 彭真人通二十义，分作两义解之。 今无名子引有无相制意义，此乃大丹之要秘，在铅火二字之义。 今详此诗，上列恍惚杳冥，下总以有无，则当从上闲、下闲之义q然则又不可拘於注文也。 有无相制，《金碧上经》云：以为两无宗一有矣。 达士悟道，岂在执文，若能透彻，随用皆合。 欧冶亲传铸剑方，锁娜金水配柔刚。 炼成便会知人意，万里诛凶一电光。 注曰：欧冶铸剑，天常遣神女为之传炉，制以金水，配以柔刚，炼成宝剑之后，诛凶剪恶一电光，顷其灵如此。 圣所作还丹，铸剑亦如之。 以天地为炉冶，以阴阳为水火，配以五行，制以神气，炼成之后，能曲能直，能柔能刚，能善能恶，能圆能方。 心有所思，意有所适，则已知人之意，而飞动诛剪一电光耳。 此乃自然神剑也。 修丹之士若无此剑，犹取鱼兔而无荃蹄也。 仙黄托欧冶铸剑之事而言之，实玄珠之罔象也。 罔象者，天机秘诀也。 疏曰：炼铸之剑，用所当用。 自然之剑，乃还丹还质变化之神，亦犹欧冶所铸之剑，而有灵神也。 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之四 紫阳真人悟真篇注疏卷之五

A commentary states: Within the realm of the indistinct, the image that appears is the qi of the Dragon’s bowstring. Within the profound darkness, the essence that emerges is the qi of the Tiger’s bowstring. Both bowstrings possess qi yet lack substance. That which is faint and indistinct, dark and obscure—seen yet unseen, heard yet unheard—is the true One qi. The true One qi is supremely numinous yet formless.

Master True One says: The None is the Dragon; the Some is the Tiger. The None is the qi of mercury; the Some is the qi of lead. The None, stirred by the Some, takes on image; the Some, moved by the None, gains numinosity. Thus the millet pearl hangs in empty space, and the purple frost gleams in the sunlight. How lamentable are those who, dull and fixed, cling to the dust of deluded thought!

A subcommentary states: The *Cantong Qi* says, “None and Some restrain each other: when the upper barrier is closed, it is called Some; when the lower barrier is closed, it is called None.” Master Peng expounded twenty meanings, dividing them into two interpretations. Now the Nameless Master draws upon the meaning of None and Some restraining each other—this is the crucial secret of the Great Elixir, contained in the two words “lead” and “fire.” Examining this poem, the upper lines list the indistinct and the profound darkness, while the lower lines summarize None and Some; thus one should follow the meaning of the upper and lower barriers. Yet one must not be rigidly bound to the commentary.

None and Some restrain each other, as the *Scripture of Golden Radiance* states: “From the two Nones, the One Some arises.” Those who awaken to the Dao do not cling to the text; if they penetrate it fully, all applications align.

Ouye received the sword-casting method in person:
Gold and water blend, soft and hard unite.
Once refined, it knows the wielder’s intent—
A thousand miles to slay the wicked in a flash of lightning.

A commentary states: When Ouye cast his sword, Heaven often sent a divine maiden to transmit the furnace’s art. He tempered it with gold and water, matched it with soft and hard, and after forging the sacred blade, it could slay the wicked and cut down evil in a flash of lightning—so swift was its numinosity. The Sage’s creation of the Returned Elixir is likewise. Taking heaven and earth as the furnace, yin and yang as water and fire, matching them with the Five Phases, and tempering them with spirit and qi, once refined, it can bend or straighten, soften or harden, do good or evil, be round or square. When the mind conceives a thought and the intent turns toward a goal, it already knows the person’s will and flies forth to slay in a flash of lightning. This is the natural spirit-sword.

The cultivator of the Elixir, without this sword, is like one who seeks fish and rabbits without a net or snare. Immortal Huang invoked Ouye’s sword-casting to illustrate the elusive image of the Mysterious Pearl. This elusive image is the secret celestial mechanism. A subcommentary states: The forged sword is used as needed. The natural sword is the spirit of the Returned Elixir’s transformation of substance—just as Ouye’s cast sword possessed numinous power.

chunks.original_text: 象川无名子翁葆光注武夷陈达灵传集庆空玄子戴起宗疏 内外药 用将须分左右军，饶他为主我为宾。 劝君临阵休轻敌，恐丧吾家无价珍。 注曰：此章明火候作用也。 将者，火也。 左为文火，右为武火。 圣人缩一年火侯於一月之内，缩一月火候於一日之中。 夫运火自子至巳六辰属阳，蒙春夏发生之德，故为文火，居左谓之阳火。 自午至亥六辰属阴，蒙秋冬肃杀之刑，故为武火，居右谓之阴符。 饶他为主我为宾者，主为阳而雄，好争也。 宾为阴而雌，好静也。 即是守雌而不雄，持静而不争，此虑险防危之意，畏敬之至也。 兵法曰：以逸待劳。 又曰：致人而不致於人。 此之谓也。

Xiangchuan’s Anonymous Master Weng Baoguang’s *Annotations on the Collected Transmissions of Perfection from Wu Yi’s Chen Daling*, with *Subcommentary by Kongxuanzi Dai Qizong*

**Inner and Outer Medicines**

When deploying troops, one must divide the left and right armies;
Let the other be host while I remain guest.
I urge you, when facing battle, do not treat the foe lightly—
Lest you lose our priceless treasure of the household.

*Annotation:*
This verse clarifies the firing times and their application.
The *general* is fire.
The left is civil fire; the right, martial fire.
The sage condenses a year’s firing time into a single month,
and a month’s firing time into a single day.
Now, the firing process from *zi* to *si* spans six yang hours,
endowed with the virtue of spring and summer’s generation—
thus it is civil fire, stationed on the left and called *yang fire*.
From *wu* to *hai* span six yin hours,
endowed with the punitive force of autumn and winter’s austerity—
thus it is martial fire, stationed on the right and called *yin tally*.
“Let the other be host while I remain guest”:
the host is yang and male, fond of contention;
the guest is yin and female, fond of stillness.
This means guarding the female without striving to be male,
maintaining stillness without contention—
a caution against peril and vigilance against danger,
the height of reverence.
The *Art of War* states: “Rest to await the weary.”
It also says: “Draw the enemy to you; do not be drawn by them.”
This is the meaning here.

chunks.original_text: 道之用，存乎水火。 水火之用，存乎人。 先言刻漏以分子午，次接阴阳以为化基，搬六十四卦於阴符，鼓二十四气於阳火。 天关在手，地轴由心。 回七十二侯之要津，钻归鼎内。 夺三千六百之正气，辐奏胎中。 运用有方，抽添有序。 动则防危虑险，靡敢差武毫厘。 外接阴阳之符，内生真一之体。 苟或运心不馑，节侯差殊，致使媳女逃亡，鼎内灵胎不结，而还丹无价之珍失之矣。 修丹之士，临阵可不守雌，而敢於轻敌乎。 上阳子曰：左为我，右为彼，饶他为主我为宾。 若使居上而我在下，彼欲动而我欲静也。 疏曰：自子至巳左为文火，自午至亥右为武火。 以发生之德为文，肃杀之刑为武。 《参伺契·鼎器歌》云：首尾武中问文。 其文武则又以火候之盛衰为文武矣。 无名子曰：鼎器乃丹之骨髓，故并举《鼎器歌》内文武之火候，用各有宜。 此诗明内药火侯作用，非明外药也。 外药妙用在一时，内药妙用在一日。 一时一日火候以同，而用之有异。 自搬六十四卦止胎中，乃真一子序《参同契》之文。 六十四卦非尽是阴符，二十四气非尽是阳火。 特举一年之火数，总以成文耳。 休泥丹宠费工夫，炼药须寻偃月炉。 自有天然真火育，何须柴炭及吹嘘。 注曰：叶文叔指两肾中闲为偃月炉，亦有指为两睛者。 靡肯自思己错，更将错处教人，何不揣之甚耶。 此炉之口仰开如偃月之状，故谓之偃月炉，即北海也。 元始之祖气在焉，何假柴炭吹嘘之耶。 疏曰：偃月炉中玉药生，彼为阴炉外药也，此为北海内药也。 皆假借以喻反反复复，人故反之，倘不明师旨，泥其名而迷之，铃不通贯，难达玄理。 天然真火，世於大小炉鼎之中，夺归吾身，以产金液还丹，非身中之阴也。 玄珠有象逐阳生，阳极阴来渐剥形。 十月霜飞丹始熟，此时神鬼亦须惊。 注曰：金液还丹所以有象者，盖自冬至住一阳火，逐阳而生金液之质，蛊夏至进阴火，剥至十月，还丹始熟。 脱胎神化为纯阳之仙，岂不使神鬼惊愕而宾伏哉。 要知炼养还丹法，自向家园下种栽。 不假吹嘘并着力，自然果熟脱灵胎。 注曰：此物只自家裹同类之物也。 此道甚近，初不远人，亦犹家园下种，其物自生，其近可知。 种非其类，难以成功。 种得其类，易若返掌。 《参同契》曰：同类易施功，非类难为功。 疏曰：前诗云：馒守药炉看火候。 又曰：自有天然真火育。 今之不假吹嘘并着力，其旨皆同，总言内药作用也。 又云：安炉立鼎、探归缎炼、太乙在炉，其旨皆同，总言外药作用也。 此物者，阳丹也。 阳丹与吾同类，易而成胎。 泥九云：身中一亩为家园是也。 不得师傅，妄意强猜。 予幸得传，所愿人人易知，同登仙果。 是以因其注之未畅明，更疏其义。 又以诗词各分入类。 然易知之中，又有难知者，不敢轻泄於竹帛　也。 学仙之士，夙有仙缘，得其书者有注、有疏，坦然明白蹊径不差。 若能悟彻，终有至大道之日。 斯文仙笈所秘，自有神灵，在在处处为之营卫，可不珍藏而深究之乎。 兔鸡之月及其时，刑德临门药象之。 到此金丹宜沐浴，若还加火必倾危。 注曰：二月为德，八月为刑，皆当沐浴，加火倾危。 疏曰：今注云：二月为德，八月为刑。 又於否泰才交万物盈注云：二月为刑，八月为德。
chunks.translated_text:
The application of the Dao lies in water and fire;
the application of water and fire lies in the person.
First, mark the clepsydra to divide *zi* and *wu*,
then connect yin and yang to establish the foundation of transformation.
Deploy the sixty-four hexagrams within the *yin tally*,
stoke the twenty-four qi with *yang fire*.
The celestial pivot rests in the hand,
the earthly axis turns by the heart.
Revolve the seventy-two seasonal nodes through their crucial passes,
drill them back into the crucible.
Seize the three thousand six hundred breaths of primordial qi,
concentrate them within the embryo.
In operation, there is method;
in withdrawal and addition, there is order.
When moving, guard against peril and contemplate danger—
not a hair’s breadth of error is permitted.
Externally, align with the tally of yin and yang;
internally, generate the true unity of the body.
Should the mind’s operation falter or the seasonal nodes diverge,
the maiden flees and the numinous embryo within the crucible fails to form—
thus the priceless treasure of the returned elixir is lost.
O adepts of elixir refinement, when facing the crucible,
can you fail to guard the female and dare to treat the enemy lightly?

Master Shangyang said: “The left is I, the right is the other;
let the other be host while I remain guest.
If the other occupies the superior position and I the inferior,
the other desires movement while I desire stillness.”
The commentary states: From *zi* to *si*, the left is *civil fire*;
from *wu* to *hai*, the right is *martial fire*.
The virtue of generation is civil,
the punitive force of austerity is martial.
The *Cantong Qi: Ode to the Crucible* says: “At the head and tail, martial; in the center, civil.”
Here, civil and martial are further determined by the waxing and waning of the fire’s timing.
Master Wuming said: The crucible is the marrow of the elixir,
thus the *Ode to the Crucible* is cited to distinguish civil and martial fire—
each has its proper use.
This verse clarifies the application of internal medicine’s fire timing,
not that of external medicine.
External medicine’s marvel lies in a single moment;
internal medicine’s marvel lies in a single day.
Though the fire timing of a moment and a day are the same,
their application differs.
From the deployment of the sixty-four hexagrams to the embryo’s formation
follows the preface of Master Zhenyi’s *Cantong Qi*.
The sixty-four hexagrams are not entirely *yin tally*,
nor are the twenty-four qi entirely *yang fire*—
they merely represent the fire’s annual reckoning to complete the text.

Do not cling to the elixir’s glory or waste effort;
to refine the medicine, seek the recumbent moon furnace.
Within it, the natural true fire nurtures—
what need is there for kindling or bellows?
The commentary states: Ye Wenshu identifies the space between the two kidneys as the recumbent moon furnace,
while others point to the two eyes.
Rather than reflect on their own errors,
they teach others their mistakes—how can this not be excessive?
The mouth of this furnace opens upward like the recumbent moon,
hence its name, the recumbent moon furnace—it is the Northern Sea.
The primordial qi of the Original Beginning resides there;
what need is there for kindling or bellows?
The commentary states: Within the recumbent moon furnace, the jade medicine is born.
That refers to the external medicine of the yin furnace;
this refers to the internal medicine of the Northern Sea.
All are metaphors for the ceaseless reversal—
people invert them, and if the master’s intent is unclear,
clinging to names leads to confusion,
failing to penetrate the thread of the mystery.
The natural true fire exists within the great and small crucibles,
seized and returned to the body
to produce the golden liquid returned elixir—
it is not the body’s yin.

The mysterious pearl takes form as yang arises;
when yang reaches its peak, yin arrives and gradually strips away its form.
After ten months of frost, the elixir ripens—
even spirits and ghosts must tremble at this time.
The commentary states: The golden liquid returned elixir takes form
because from the winter solstice, one yang fire is stationed,
and as yang gradually generates the golden liquid’s essence,
by the summer solstice, yin fire advances,
stripping away until the tenth month,
when the returned elixir ripens.
Shedding the embryo’s transformation into a pure yang immortal—
how could this not astonish spirits and ghosts into submission?

To know the method of refining, nurturing, and returning the elixir,
plant the seed within your own garden.
No bellows or force are needed—
naturally, the fruit ripens and the numinous embryo is freed.
The commentary states: This thing is of the same kind as what lies within your own home.
The Dao is very near, never far from people—
like planting a seed in your garden,
the thing grows of itself; its nearness is evident.
Planting a different kind yields no success;
planting the same kind is as easy as turning the palm.
The *Cantong Qi* says: “With the same kind, effort is easily applied;
with a different kind, effort is difficult.”
The commentary states: The earlier verse says:
*“Guard the medicine furnace and watch the fire’s timing,”*
and *“Within it, the natural true fire nurtures.”*
Now it says: *“No bellows or force are needed,”*
all referring to the application of internal medicine.
Elsewhere it says: *“Establish the furnace and set the crucible,
gather and refine the medicine,
the Great One resides in the furnace,”*
all referring to the application of external medicine.

This thing is the yang elixir.
The yang elixir is of the same kind as we are,
easily forming the embryo.
Master Nijiang said: “Within the body, one *mu* is the home garden.”
Without a master’s guidance, one may wildly guess—
I, fortunate to have received the transmission,
wish for all to easily understand and together ascend the immortal fruit.
Thus, where the commentary was unclear,
I have further elucidated its meaning,
and arranged the verses and lyrics by category.
Yet within what is easily known, there are also difficult points—
I dare not lightly disclose them on bamboo and silk.
O adepts of immortal study,
if you are destined for immortality and obtain this book,
with its commentary and exegesis,
the path will be clear and unerring.
If you can fully awaken,
you will one day attain the great Dao.
This text is a treasure of the immortal’s satchel,
guarded by spirits everywhere—
can you fail to cherish and deeply study it?

In the months of the hare and the rooster, when the time is right,
punitive and virtuous forces arrive at the gate—
the medicine’s image appears.
At this point, the golden elixir should be bathed;
if fire is added, it will surely topple into danger.
The commentary states: The second month is virtue, the eighth month is punishment—
both require bathing; adding fire leads to peril.
The commentary states: Here it says the second month is virtue, the eighth month is punishment,
while in the annotation on the exchange of *Pi* and *Tai* hexagrams,
it says the second month is punishment, the eighth month is virtue.

chunks.original_text: 盖二月於发生之德而揄策落，德中有刑。 八月为肃杀之刑而麦苗生，刑中有德。 是以互言刑德。 否泰才交万物盈，屯蒙受卦禀生成。 此中得意休求象，若究草爻漫役情。 注曰：冬夏二至为一阴一阳之首，子午二时为一日一夜之元。 圣人运动阴符阳火，协天地升降之道，日月往来之理，攒簇四时、八节、二十四气、七十二候，环列鼎中，而生真一之体。 此理甚简，其功不繁，无可云为，故托诸卦象，分於一月三十日之中，以阐玄机，以明火用。 爻象者，筌蹄也。 屯蒙为众卦之首，以象运火生成之始，造化禀受之源，故朝以屯，暮以蒙。 否泰者，阴升阳降於四时之中，至二月春分之节，阳气升於天地之中，阴阳相半，不寒不热为温，故为泰卦 ，亦如月之上弦气侯也。 此时阴阳二气自然相交，故圣人不进火，谓之沐浴也。 至八月秋分之节，阴气降到天地之中，亦阴阳相半，不热不寒而凉，故为否卦 ，亦如月之下弦之气候也。 此时阴阳二气自然相交，故圣人进水，不亦谓之沐浴也。 故仙翁曰：兔鸡之月及其时，刑德临门药象之。 二月为刑，八月为德故也。 修丹之士，若能於此四卦之中得意，何必执滞群爻而劳心役思哉。 仙翁慈悲，直指其捷径如此。 疏曰：否泰者，沐浴之月。 一年十二月，用十月结胎，除两月沐浴。 屯蒙者，日月两卦也。 两卦共十二爻，以象一日十二时。 六十四卦除乾坤坎离牝牡四卦，只用六十卦，以应一月三十日。 以天地八万四千里升降之理，至春秋二分，恰行二万四千里，正在天地之中。 故借否泰二卦，阴阳上下两停以喻之。 是以日之昼夜时刻，二八月亦两停。 月之上下二弦，亦金水各半斤。 若以月卦论人，阴阳进退之节，泰为正月，否为七月，不在二月之卦。 《参同契》云：大壮卯门观察，仲秋以息符候。 二八月乃大壮观卦矣。 彭真人於泰之注则云：阴阳气停，夫妇交接。 於否之注：天地俱息，阴阳不交。 盖两停则不交，一多一少则交。 阳上阴下则不交，阴下阳上则交。 此物之理也。 既知其理，则不爻泥卦爻以役情矣。 卦中设法本仪刑，得象忘言意自明。 举世迷人惟泥象，却行卦气望飞升。 注曰：卦象者，火之筌蹄也。 魏伯阳真人因读易而悟金丹作用，与易道一洞，故作《参同契》，演大易卦象，以明丹旨，开示后人。 故比喻乾坤为鼎器，象灵胎神室在我丹田中也。 又以坎离喻为药物，象铅汞之在灵胎神室中也。 夫乾坤为众卦之父母，，坎离为乾坤之真精，故以四卦居於中官，犹灵胎铅汞在丹田中也。 处中以制外，故四卦不系运火之数。 其余诸卦，并分在一月之中，搬运符火，始於屯蒙，终於既未。 周而复始，如车之轮运转不已。 一日两卦直事，三十日计六十卦。 连乾坤坎离四卦为鼎器、药物，共六十四卦，总三百八十四爻，象一年并闺余，共三百八十四爻也。 又象金丹二八一斤之数，一斤计三百八十四铢。 此皆比喻设象如此，学者观此卦象，可以悟运火之作用。 苟明火用，卦象皆可忘言而无用也。 今之学者不晓此旨，而反泥此以行卦气，劳形苦思而望飞升，不亦愚乎。 得鱼忘荃，得兔忘蹄，今反泥荃蹄而为鱼兔，去道愈远矣。 锺离公曰：大道安能以语通，伯阳假《易》作《参同》。
chunks.translated_text:
For the second month, amidst the virtue of generation, the counting rods fall—yet within virtue lies punishment. In the eighth month, amidst the punishment of withering decay, wheat sprouts arise—thus within punishment lies virtue. Hence the mutual reference to punishment and virtue. When *Pi* and *Tai* first exchange, the myriad things flourish; the *Zhun* and *Meng* hexagrams receive the mandate of generation and completion. Here, grasp the meaning and cease seeking images; if you exhaust yourself in divining lines, you will only weary the spirit.

The commentary states: The winter and summer solstices mark the inception of yin and yang; the *zi* and *wu* hours serve as the origin of day and night. The sage moves in accord with the tally of yin and the fire of yang, harmonizing with the Dao of Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent, the principle of the sun and moon’s coming and going. Gathering the four seasons, eight nodes, twenty-four qi, and seventy-two seasonal markers, they array them within the crucible to generate the true unity of the body. This principle is most simple, its practice not cumbersome—nothing need be contrived. Thus it is entrusted to the hexagrams, distributed across the thirty days of a month to unfold the mystery and clarify the use of fire.

The lines and images are but the trap and snare. *Zhun* and *Meng* stand at the head of all hexagrams, symbolizing the inception of fire’s movement and the origin of creation’s mandate. Hence, *Zhun* governs the morning, *Meng* the evening. *Pi* and *Tai* represent yin ascending and yang descending amid the four seasons. When the second month’s *Chunfen* node arrives, yang qi rises to the center of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang stand in equal measure—neither cold nor hot, but temperate—thus forming the *Tai* hexagram, like the moon’s first quarter and its qi. At this time, yin and yang naturally converge, so the sage does not advance fire, calling it "bathing." When the eighth month’s *Qiufen* node arrives, yin qi descends to the center of Heaven and Earth, again with yin and yang in balance—neither hot nor cold, but cool—thus forming the *Pi* hexagram, like the moon’s last quarter and its qi. Here, yin and yang naturally converge, so the sage advances water, also calling it "bathing." Thus the immortal elder said: "In the months of the hare and the rooster, when the time is right, punitive and virtuous forces arrive at the gate—the medicine’s image appears." For the second month is punishment, the eighth month virtue.

If the cultivator of the elixir can grasp the meaning within these four hexagrams, why cling to the myriad lines and exhaust the mind in labored thought? The immortal elder, in his compassion, has directly pointed out this shortcut.

The commentary states: *Pi* and *Tai* correspond to the months of bathing. Of the twelve months in a year, ten are used to gestate the embryo, excluding the two months of bathing. *Zhun* and *Meng* are the hexagrams of the sun and moon. Together, their twelve lines symbolize the twelve hours of a day. Of the sixty-four hexagrams, excluding *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, *Li*, and the four hexagrams of the female and male, only sixty are used, corresponding to the thirty days of a month. The principle of Heaven and Earth’s ascent and descent over 84,000 *li* reaches the spring and autumn equinoxes, traversing exactly 24,000 *li* to the center of Heaven and Earth. Thus the *Pi* and *Tai* hexagrams, with yin and yang evenly balanced above and below, serve as metaphors. So too do the hours of day and night in the second and eighth months stand in balance, as do the moon’s first and last quarters, where metal and water each weigh half a *jin*.

If one discusses the hexagrams in relation to humans, the nodes of yin and yang’s advance and retreat place *Tai* in the first month and *Pi* in the seventh, not in the second month’s hexagram. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Observe the *Da Zhuang* hexagram at the *mao* gate; in mid-autumn, await the tally of rest." The second and eighth months thus belong to the *Da Zhuang* and *Guan* hexagrams. Master Peng’s commentary on *Tai* reads: "Yin and yang qi stand in balance; husband and wife unite." On *Pi*, it states: "Heaven and Earth both rest; yin and yang do not converge." For when they stand in balance, there is no convergence; when one is greater and the other lesser, they converge. When yang rises and yin descends, they do not converge; when yin descends and yang rises, they do. Such is the principle of things. Once this principle is understood, one need not cling to the lines of hexagrams and weary the spirit.

The methods set forth in the hexagrams are but models; grasp the image, forget the words, and the meaning will become clear. Yet the world’s deluded ones cling only to images, practicing hexagram qi in hopes of ascension.

The commentary states: The hexagrams are but the trap and snare of fire. The true man Wei Boyang, through studying the *Yi*, awakened to the workings of the golden elixir, seeing the Dao of the *Yi* as one. Thus he composed the *Cantong Qi*, expounding the hexagrams of the *Great Yi* to illuminate the elixir’s essence and guide later generations. He likened *Qian* and *Kun* to the crucible and vessel, symbolizing the divine embryo’s chamber within our elixir field. He compared *Kan* and *Li* to the medicinal substances, symbolizing lead and mercury within the divine embryo’s chamber. For *Qian* and *Kun* are the parents of all hexagrams, and *Kan* and *Li* are their true essence. Thus the four hexagrams reside in the central palace, like the divine embryo’s lead and mercury within the elixir field. Placed at the center to govern the exterior, these four hexagrams are not bound to the reckoning of fire’s movement. The remaining hexagrams are distributed across the month, circulating the tally and fire, beginning with *Zhun* and *Meng* and ending with *Jiji*. They cycle endlessly, like a wheel in ceaseless motion. Each day, two hexagrams govern affairs; in thirty days, sixty hexagrams are reckoned. Including *Qian*, *Kun*, *Kan*, and *Li* as the crucible, vessel, and medicinal substances, the sixty-four hexagrams total 384 lines, symbolizing the year’s 384 days, including intercalary days. They also symbolize the elixir’s weight of two times eight, one *jin*, with one *jin* equaling 384 *zhu*. All these are metaphors and images. By observing the hexagrams, the scholar may awaken to the workings of fire’s movement. Once the use of fire is understood, the hexagrams and their words may be forgotten as no longer needed.

Yet today’s scholars, failing to grasp this essence, cling instead to these images to practice hexagram qi, exhausting body and mind in hopes of ascension—is this not folly? "Having caught the fish, forget the trap; having caught the hare, forget the snare." Now they cling to the trap and snare as if they were the fish and hare, drifting ever farther from the Dao.

Master Zhongli said: "How could the great Dao be communicated through words? Boyang borrowed the *Yi* to compose the *Cantong Qi*."

chunks.original_text: 后人不识神仙喻，妄执荃蹄便下工。 此其证也。 疏曰：世传卦气图分六十卦，每爻以息数准之，为水火阴阳之，则泥象行之。 焉知金丹大道，以卦为荃蹄也。 夫六十卦，皆本．於乾坤之纯阴阳而变，独坎离得乾坤中气而正，故除此四卦为牝牡，乾坤为体，坎离为用，六十四卦为符，分为鼎器药物，总为周天火侯。 丹道与天地同，《易》象与天地合，故假易以明道。 未炼还丹须急炼，炼了还须知止足。 若也持盈未已心，不免一朝遭祸辱。 注曰：男子二八而天癸至，八八而天癸竭。 方其至也，满纯乾重．一斤。 逮至弱冠，汞走一两。 岁当三十，汞走四两。 岁当六十，剥状及肤。 八八数终，纯坤传尽。 乌飞兔走，时不待人。 活汞须藉铅擒，还丹急须下手。 炼之既毕，抱一守诚。 若不知足，持不已之心，反遭祸辱。 锺离公曰：丹熟不须行火候，更行火候叉伤丹。 只宜保守无亏损，渴饮饥养困则眠。 更能明心见性，面壁九年，斯道愈弘矣。 疏曰：吕纯阳六十四岁遇正阳，葛仙翁六十四遇郑真人，马自然六十四岁遇海蟾，皆方修金丹之道成仙。 炼了止足，十月脱胎，即当沐浴，不待一年皆满，不待冬至下工。 《金丹四百字》云：冬至不在子，及其沐浴时，卯酒亦虚比。 石杏林云：冬至不在子，沐浴非卯酉。 道光云：脱胎并沐浴，携养镇天生是也。 三仙皆於六十四岁修道，而成其所修之道何也？ 可得闻其略乎？ 予应之曰：三仙皆是壮年募道，持戒积符，至六十四方得金丹真传，故成道之速。 若夫世人嗜欲丧精，思虑损神，痕劳耗气j真阳既失，虽闻大道於六十四岁之前，亦难成功。 倘然绝欲於早年，求道於壮岁，及色身未坏，精气未耗，遇师得旨，下手速修。 如其未遇，毋摇尔精，毋劳尔形，积功累行，以伺有遇，庶几可冀。 三仙可得之道，载在方册，可睹 瑞绪。 正阳以丹数粒示纯阳？ 曰：此非世问五金八石，乃世间异宝合成，虽有质而无形，如云如火，如光如影，可见而不可执，服之与人，魂识合为一体，轻虚彻妙，非有形之丹。 葛仙翁《流珠歌》云：流珠流珠，役我区区。 云游四海，历涉方书。 茫茫汲汲，忘寝失哺。 参遍知友，烧竭汞朱。 二十年内，日日长吁。 吾今六十，应赴三涂。 赖师传授，元气虚无。 先定金鼎，后定玉炉。 离火激发，坎水规模。 玉液既润，洞房流苏。 真人所授，要大丈夫，念兹在兹，记吾记吾。 马自然《金丹歌》曰：六十四岁皆谓休，得遇海蟾亲弟子。 当时为我说一句，见得从前皆乱做。 元来只此是还丹，近在眼前不知处。 是岁庚子戊寅月，得遇至人亲口诀。 如玉在石不曾镌，及至镌开白如雪。 内有丹，二八两，生在丹田黄芽长。 若得此物镇丹田，寿数无穷不计年。 是三仙所传之道，与《悟真篇》同一至理。 紫玄张真人在世九十六岁，於元丰五年壬戌三月初五日尸解，距熙宁二年乙酉於成都遇师传道，是时真人年已八十有二矣。 其修炼又在六十四岁之后者，保养於平日深有功也。 《黄庭经》曰：百二十年犹可还，过此守道诚甚难。 唯待九转八琼丹，要复精思存七元。 右言内药。 取将坎内中心实，点化离宫腹裹阴。 从此变成乾健体，潜藏飞跃总由心。 注曰：离卦@#外阳内阴，坎卦@#外阴内阳。
chunks.translated_text:
Later generations, failing to recognize the immortals’ metaphors, mistakenly seize upon the trap and snare and set to work—this is the proof. The commentary states: The world transmits the *Hexagram Qi Diagram*, dividing sixty hexagrams, each line aligned with the breath-count to model water, fire, yin, and yang—thus they cling to the images and practice accordingly. How could they know that the great Way of the Golden Elixir employs hexagrams as mere trap and snare?

The sixty hexagrams all derive from the pure yin and yang of *Qian* and *Kun*, yet only *Kan* and *Li* obtain the central qi of *Qian* and *Kun* and stand upright. Thus, excluding these four hexagrams as the female and male, *Qian* and *Kun* serve as the body, *Kan* and *Li* as the function, the sixty-four hexagrams as the tally, divided into the cauldron, vessel, medicine, and ingredients—all governed by the fire phases of the celestial cycle. The Way of the Elixir aligns with heaven and earth, and the images of the *Yi* correspond to them; thus, the *Yi* is borrowed to illuminate the Dao.

Before refining the Returned Elixir, refine it with urgency; once refined, know when to stop and be content. If you persist with an insatiable heart, you will not escape one day meeting with misfortune and disgrace.

The annotation states: A man’s *tian gui* arrives at two times eight, and is exhausted by eight times eight. When it first arrives, it is full, pure *Qian*, weighing one *jin*. By the time he reaches twenty, one *liang* of mercury has fled. By thirty, four *liang* have fled. By sixty, the *Bo* hexagram’s pattern reaches the skin. When the eight-times-eight count ends, pure *Kun* transmits all. The crow flies, the hare runs—time waits for no one. Living mercury must be captured by lead; the Returned Elixir must be grasped without delay. Once refinement is complete, embrace the One and guard sincerity. If you know no contentment, persisting with an unceasing heart, you will instead meet with misfortune and disgrace.

Master Zhongli said: "Once the Elixir is ripe, there is no need to apply fire phases; applying them further will harm the Elixir. It is best to preserve and guard it without loss—drink when thirsty, eat when hungry, sleep when weary. If you can further clarify the mind and perceive the nature, facing the wall for nine years, this Dao will flourish even more."

The commentary states: Lü Chunyang met Zhengyang at sixty-four; Ge the Immortal met Master Zheng at sixty-four; Ma Ziran met Haichan at sixty-four—all had just begun cultivating the Way of the Golden Elixir and attained immortality. Once refinement is complete and contentment is known, after ten months the embryo is shed, and one should bathe; within a year, all is fulfilled, and there is no need to begin work at the winter solstice. The *Four Hundred Words on the Golden Elixir* says: "The winter solstice is not at *zi*; when it is time for bathing, *mao* wine is but an empty comparison." Shi Xinglin said: "The winter solstice is not at *zi*; bathing is not at *mao* or *you*." Daoguang said: "Shedding the embryo and bathing, nurturing and stabilizing—this is the celestial birth."

All three immortals cultivated the Dao at sixty-four—how did they succeed in their practice? May I hear a brief account?

I replied: All three immortals sought the Dao in their prime, upheld precepts, and accumulated merit. Only at sixty-four did they receive the true transmission of the Golden Elixir, thus attaining the Dao swiftly. As for worldly people, desires deplete essence, thoughts harm spirit, toil exhausts qi, and true yang is lost. Even if they hear the great Dao before sixty-four, they will struggle to succeed. If one cuts off desire in youth, seeks the Dao in the prime of life, preserves the physical body before it decays, and essence and qi before they are spent, meeting a teacher and receiving the teaching, one may swiftly begin cultivation. If one has not yet met a teacher, do not scatter your essence, do not weary your form; accumulate merit and deeds, awaiting the encounter—perhaps success may still be hoped for.

The Dao attained by the three immortals is recorded in texts, its auspicious threads visible. Did Zhengyang show Chunyang a few grains of the Elixir?

He said: This is not the five metals or eight stones of the world, but a wondrous treasure of the world compounded. Though it has substance, it has no form—like clouds, like fire, like light, like shadow—visible yet ungraspable. Consuming it, one’s soul and consciousness merge into one body, light and empty, utterly wondrous, not a tangible elixir.

Ge the Immortal’s *Song of the Flowing Pearl* says:
*Flowing pearl, flowing pearl,*
*You drive me to toil endlessly.*
*Wandering the four seas, traversing texts,*
*Vast and hurried, forgetting sleep and meals.*
*Seeking all wise friends, burning all cinnabar,*
*For twenty years, sighing daily.*
*Now at sixty, I must descend to the three paths.*
*By the teacher’s transmission, the primordial qi is emptiness.*
*First stabilize the golden tripod, then the jade furnace.*
*Li fire sparks, Kan water takes form.*
*Jade liquid moistens, the bridal chamber streams with tassels.*
*The true person’s teaching: only the great man*
*Keeps this ever in mind—remember, remember!*

Ma Ziran’s *Song of the Golden Elixir* says:
*At sixty-four, all say it is too late,*
*Yet I met Haichan’s true disciple.*
*At that time, he spoke a single phrase—*
*I saw all my past efforts were in vain.*
*It turned out this alone was the Returned Elixir,*
*Near at hand, yet unknown where.*
*In the year *gengzi*, the month *wuyin*,*
*I met the perfected one and received the oral teaching.*
*Like jade in stone, uncarved,*
*Once carved, white as snow.*
*Within it is the Elixir, two times eight in weight,*
*Born in the cinnabar field, the yellow sprout grows.*
*If this treasure guards the cinnabar field,*
*Lifespan is boundless, years uncounted.*

The Dao transmitted by these three immortals shares the same ultimate principle as the *Awakening to Reality*. The Perfected Zhang Zixuan lived ninety-six years. In the fifth year of Yuanfeng, on the fifth day of the third month, he achieved liberation in the flesh. From the second year of Xining, when he met his teacher in Chengdu and received the Dao, the Perfected was already eighty-two. His cultivation began after sixty-four, yet his daily preservation and nurturing were profoundly effective.

The *Scripture of the Yellow Court* says:
*One hundred twenty years may still be restored;*
*Beyond this, guarding the Dao is most difficult.*
*Only await the ninefold transmutation, the eightfold jade elixir,*
*To recover essence and contemplate the seven origins.*

The above speaks of the inner medicine.

Take the true center within *Kan*,
Transform the yin within *Li*’s belly.
From this, become the vigorous body of *Qian*;
Hidden or soaring, all is governed by the mind.

The annotation states: The *Li* hexagram has yang without and yin within; the *Kan* hexagram has yin without and yang within.
